PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Equality in Employment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

That numerous provisions exist in industrial legislation and awards which purport to provide special protection to women workers but which have been shown to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article ll of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women to which Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to equality be removed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crowley (from 13 citizens) and Reid (from 16 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Request the Government to introduce a Bill providing:
That the LD50 Test, whereby animals are used in the testing of cosmetics, industrial and household substances, be abolished.
That, at this moment, animal experimentation be limited to medical research only and that accurate records be kept of all animal research in Australia.
That, over the next 10 years, animal experimentation be phased out completely.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are greatly concerned that the Australian Bill of Rights does nothing to protect the rights of parents to choose to send their children to non-government schools and the rights of individuals and groups to establish educational institutions, which are rights set down in the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, ratified by Australia.

That the Australian Bill of Rights contains no provision to protect Australians against coercion and discrimination in the work-place to ensure that both unionists and non-unionists should have equal rights to employment opportunities.

That the Australian Bill of Rights will give the Federal Government unwarranted powers to override state laws, and that the Human Rights Commission will possess draconian inquisitorial powers which will abrogate the rights of individuals and state and local governments.
We your petitioners humbly pray that the Australian Bill of Rights Legislation be opposed in the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the proposed Bill of Rights because it adversely affects areas of the liberty and freedom of Australians. It will operate against:
The States and our Federal system of Government
Criminal Justice
The Police
Education
Families
Employer/Employee relations

It will remove the power of the people through Parliament, by giving power to a new more powerful Human Rights Commission which is not elected, but can act as a Star Chamber. We do most earnestly wish to keep our system of Common Law.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will
Restrict our rights to those listed in the Bill
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this or any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustifiable power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject the Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap terminates on 19 October 1986.
2. In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
3. Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
4. The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should decide that-
1. The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap not be extended beyond October 1986.

2. Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
3. Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we oppose the deregulation of housing interest rates without adequate safeguards to protect homebuyers.
2. That we condemn the Government for breaking its unequivocal promise not to deregulate these interest rates.
3. We express our concern that the Government's decision will cause undue hardship to many Australian families.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
urge the Government to reverse its decision and re-impose the interest rate ceiling.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Parer (from 183 citizens), Walters (from 51 citizens) and Watson (from 31 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
that the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural and small business sectors, which will severely affect their long term viability.

that the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament, full details of which still had not been revealed after it had legally been in operation for more than six months, has caused confusion and hindered farmers and small business people in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax Legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
that the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
that the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: that the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill
1. offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should: Completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Oppoeruniry Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to ``the storyline'' of a film screened,

because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights because:
This Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as:-
The right to own your own home and other property and not to be deprived of it without just compensation.
The right to insulate our children from radical forms of education and the right to choice of schools.
The right to a referendum for constitutional amendments.
The right to true freedom of speech.
The Bill gives dangerous, unlimited powers to an unelected Human Rights Commission with no appeal, no legal representation and closed hearings.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote to reject the Bill, believing that such a Bill should only be determined by the people at a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:

We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill. The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not to be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

The Government's proposed Bill of rights legislation has been introduced into Parliament with haste and without regard for the adverse effects it would have in many areas essential to the liberty and freedom of the Australian people.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should-
Delay any further debate on the Bill of Rights until sufficient time has elapsed to allow public discussion, after which it seek the consent of the people of Australia in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: African National Congress and South West Africa People's Organisation
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: that the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress and the South West Africa People's Organisation should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the provision of:-
1. Official recognition of A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia.
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the African National Congress and the South West Africa People's Organisation to promote the anti-Apartheid cause.
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid.
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. education departments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should-
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, humbly pray that the Parliament act to outlaw the practice of the large petrol companies also controlling petrol retail outlets in competition with independent petrol distributors and retailers who they supply, thus acting in a position of unfair competition, and leading to the large companies exerting unconscionable pressure on those independent distributors and retailers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That certain Trade Unions are currently forcing employers and employees to join union-controlled Superannuation schemes through industrial blackmail, thereby extending the Unions' economic power and at the same time infringing individual rights.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
(i) Guarantee that Occupational Superannuation is a matter of individual choice.
(ii) Declare illegal industrial standover tactics which force people to join superannuation schemes controlled by, or sponsored by, trade unions.
(iii) Protect those companies and their employees who establish their own superannuation arrangements at the enterprise level.
(iv) Ensure that union or industry-based schemes are not disguised pay rises by providing that em- ployees must also make contributions.
(v) Provide that control of the funds of such schemes is vested in the elected representative of the contributors to those schemes.
(vi) Oppose any backdoor attempts at achieving compulsory unionism.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Drug: Dilantin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Government has imposed an additional patient contribution on the cost of a subsidised pharmaceutical, namely the drug Dilantin.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should

Bear in mind all the additional costs incurred by people suffering from chronic illness and therefore request the Government to reverse its decision to increase the price of the drug Dilantin to the consumer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that the proposed Fringe Benefits Tax recently introduced into the House of Representatives by the Labor Government will increase the costs and inhibit future growth of small business in this great Nation.
Your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this regressive legislation as a matter of utmost urgency in the interests of the well being of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Goldmining Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament, the petition of the undersigned showeth:

That the goldmining industry is vitally important to Australia and under the existing taxation laws is a growth industry, creating increased employment opportunities in many parts of Australia, producing increased revenue for governments and increased exports, at a time when many other sectors of the economy are in a depressed state.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate call on the Hawke Government to reject any recommendation from the current Inquiry, or take any other action which would lead to any new tax being imposed on the goldmining industry, because such a tax would:

Cost thousands of jobs in the industry, depress local economies affected by the industry, thus causing a lowering of living standards, in certain non-urban areas of Australia and ultimately a further decline in the national economy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

There is a threat to medicine by an alliance between some greedy doctors, private health funds and private hospitals who, since the inception of Medicare have run a campaign to destroy Medicare. People, especially pensioners, are suffering.
We call on the Government to investigate why our taxes are being spent to prop up private hospitals.
To carry out an overhaul of the Medicare legislation to close the loopholes to prevent this exploitation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting-

(a) the comments of a trustee of the National Party and prominent businessman in Queensland, Sir Roderick Proctor, who said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in May 1986 that ``The Queensland economy is not in good shape, and in some respects at the moment we don't compare well with some of the other States which just happen to have Labor State Governments'';
(b) that this grave message has been conveyed in this Chamber and by the Opposition in the Queensland Parliament for some time; and
(c) that the perilous state of the Queensland economy has at last been realised by National Party members in Queensland, urges the current Queensland Government-

Senator Chaney-Mr President, I take a point of order. I understand that fairly wide latitude is given in the Senate for notices of motion. However, it seems to me that Senator Colston's notice of motion is a cross between a conversation and a debate, Mr President. I ask you to rule on whether the very odd nature of it, which includes quotations-the point the honourable senator is at now seems to consist of argument rather than being a normal notice of motion-is in order.

Senator Grimes-On the point of order: I almost agree with Senator Chaney on this matter. The only difficulty is that since Senator Michael Baume's arrival in this place we have had from him notices of motion which go on for pages, which are much more discursive and much more like a debate than the notice of motion Senator Colston is giving now. Like Senator Chaney, I also believe that it is about time we considered the new practice in this place of delivering notices of motion which go on for about 20 minutes. I think it worth while, Mr President, that you seriously consider the situation. If you do not, perhaps the Senate Standing Orders Committee could consider the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of the order that has been raised by the Leader of the Opposition, I have been concerned for some time about the way in which a number of notices of motion are being presented to the chamber in that they seem to be points of argument rather than notices of motions to be debated and considered ultimately by the Senate. I have been having discussions with the Clerk on this matter for some time. I will take on board the suggestion made in Senator Chaney's point of order without necessarily ruling on it at this stage. I will hear the rest of the content of Senator Colston's notice of motion but I strongly suggest that the subject is a matter for consideration by the Standing Orders Committee.
—Mr President, I will resume at the last paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) that the perilous state of the Queensland economy has at last been realised by National Party members in Queensland, urges the current Queensland Government, in its dying days in office, to cease using rhetoric to explain away the State's ills and take positive efforts to boost the Queensland economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Cooney and on his behalf, pursuant to his notice of intention given on 27 May 1986, I now withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in Senator Cooney's name for 30 May 1986, which relates to a matter concerning the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate requests the Government to bring on for debate the Notice of Motion given by Senator Michael Baume on 17 October 1985 in the following terms:
That the Senate:
(a) expresses its concern at Australia's worsening balance of payments position, evident from the 18 per cent rise in the current account deficit for the September quarter to $3,345m;

(b) requests the Treasurer, Mr Keating, to make available any advice from the Treasury on which he relied for his forecast to an Economics Society meeting on 16 October 1985, that the current account deficit would fall to 4.1 per cent of Gross Domestic Product by June next year and then continue the trend downwards; and

(c) regrets that the Treasurer intends to try to defend the Australian dollar that is being weakened largely as a result of inappropriate Government fiscal policy, by maintaining a high interest rate policy that will inevitably damage economic growth.

Senator Grimes-I raise a point of order. What we have seen now is a refinement of the practice that has been introduced by Senator Michael Baume. He has now used notices of motion to repeat the notice of motion he introduced before. Under the guise of a point of order I request that, in line with Senator Chaney's previous comments, this matter be dealt with by the Standing Orders Committee, otherwise we will be spending all of most mornings in tit for tat exercises of this type.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take on board the point that has been made by the Manager of Government Business in that Senator Michael Baume, by giving a notice of motion this morning, has recapitulated an earlier notice of motion. Perhaps it would be sufficient merely to cite the number of the notice of motion rather than recite the wording of the earlier notice of motion. I strongly suggest that the matter is one of concern to the Senate generally and the question of notices of motion should be the subject of discussion at the next meeting of the Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the announcement by the Reagan Administration that it intends to override the terms of the SALT II agreement late in 1986 by deploying Air Launched Cruise Missiles on B52 bombers;
(b) views with disquiet the same Administration's recent reinterpretation of the Anti Ballistic Missiles Treaty;
(c) recognises that the Soviet Union has also broken both the spirit and the letter of the SALT agreements; and

(d) calls on the Federal Government to maintain its strong stand on arms control and to make a strong condemnation of both the United States of America and the Soviet Union for breaking arms control agreements that already exist and for failing to reach any agreement on current proposals, such as a comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, while continuing to escalate the arms race at every level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the many Notices of Motion dating back to October 1985 given by Senator Michael Baume pointing out the continual deterioration of Australia's balance of payments deficit on current account and the need for remedial action by the Government, not one of which has been allowed to be debated by this Government;

(b) notes the recent belated admission by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the Australian people should now be told `truthfully, honestly and correctly just what kind of a hole Australia is in' because of the record and deteriorating balance of payments deficit on current account, all of which confirms the concerns expressed in Senator Michael Baume's Notices of Motion;
(c) regrets the Government's delays in responding to the worsening in Australia's economic position which has been evident for many months, so making it more difficult to correct; and

(d) calls on the Government to adopt the requests made in Senator Michael Baume's Notices of Motion for an immediate mini-Budget to implement the major reductions in Government spending Mr Keating now says are needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Michael Baume in his notice of motion. Senator Michael Baume claimed that the Government had failed to bring on his notices of motion and debate them and, as Manager of Government Business, I believe that reflects upon me. I point out that Senator Michael Baume's notices of motion would normally be dealt with in this place in General Business, and General Business is in the hands of the Opposition. It is clearly the Opposition which does not wish to debate Senator Michael Baume's notices of motion. It clearly does not want to do so because the notices of motion are inane. I make the point that people who wish to break down the normal parliamentary procedures act in an undemocratic way. We are not surprised at that, having come from someone of Senator Michael Baume's extreme right wing views.

—by leave-I would just like to put on the record in the Senate this morning that the Opposition has sought from the Government a proper and full economic statement for debate. That request was made in the House of Representatives earlier this week, and the Government has indicated it is not prepared to make such a statement. I make it quite clear that the Opposition believes that the economic debate is one of major importance, given the Government's recent statements on the perilous state of the Australian economy, and we would certainly desire to see a full statement on Australia's economic position put down by the Government so it could be properly debated. It is rather sad that it has to be up to the Opposition to raise a matter so important to Australia when the Government clearly has the major responsibility in the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) recognising that the present Hawke Socialist Government is a very big-spending Government;
(b) aware that big spending and big taxes must go hand-in-hand if Australia is to avoid getting even further in debt both internally and to overseas banking organisations;
(c) convinced that Australia is already too far in debt for the good of future generations;

(d) aware that Australia will spend more of its Budget in the 1985-86 financial year on the national debt interest than it does on either of health, education, or defence, and about 5 times as much as we do on housing; and
(e) mindful that this country is already one of the most indebted in the world with liabilities per head far in excess of Argentina, Mexico, Chile, Poland or Brazil,
calls upon the Federal Government to issue a statement to the people of Australia explaining just what long-term action it intends to take to solve the national debt crisis.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, Government Business take precedence of General Business on Thursdays for the remainder of the Autumn sittings.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill re-introduces the provisions of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 blocked in the Senate on 8 October 1985, except for those that concerned the structure and composition of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. In addition, the opportunity has been taken to include a number of new amendments that are not related to the Trust amendments but which are necessary to ensure that the Commonwealth superannuation scheme operates in an appropriate manner. It is because some of these new amendments are likely to affect an ongoing appropriation that the Bill was originated in the House of Representatives.
The primary function of the Bill is, as it was of the 1985 Bill, to implement essential reforms relating to the Trust. These reforms are intended to:
clearly define the Trust's objectives and duties;
strengthen the Trust's ability to manage and invest the superannuation fund in the most effective and efficient manner;
enhance its accountability both to the Parliament and the contributors; and
enable it to operate in competitive financial markets with a degree of freedom and flexibility in investment no less than that afforded the larger private sector superannuation funds.
I remind honourable senators that the pressing necessity for reform, the general thrust of this legislation, and its urgency, were recognised and supported by all when the 1985 Bill was debated.

That previous Bill was the culmination of a comprehensive process of review by this Government of the operations of the Trust; a review process which included an inquiry into the management and operations of the Trust by the now Auditor-General Mr J. V. Monaghan, and an examination of a number of matters associated with the conclusions and recommendations of Mr Monaghan's report by a working party.

In addition, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations examined and reported on the 1985 Bill. While approving generally of the provisions and welcoming the Government's prompt action in introducing the Bill, the Standing Committee made four recommendations proposing the insertion of additional material.

On behalf of the Government, I accepted three of the Standing Committee's recommendations. The relevant amendments were incorporated in the previous Bill in the Committee stage of its consideration. Of the three amendments, that relating to the method of selection of Trust members is no longer relevant because this Bill does not seek to alter the existing basic structure of the Trust or the existing method of selection of Trust members. The other two amendments form part of the Bill now before the Senate.

None of the provisions of the 1985 Bill concerning the accountability of the Trust, its objective and duties and its power to manage and invest the superannuation fund drew unfavourable reaction during debate. The sole matter of contention was the proposed structure of the Trust.

Criticism of that proposed structure focused on what the Opposition and the Australian Democrats wrongly characterised as ACTU control. That criticism failed to recognise that the proposed structure of the Trust did not provide for ACTU control but rather for the ACTU to act as a channel, a conduit, through which industrial organisations representing the bulk of the contributors to the fund could put forward persons suitable for nomination to the Trust. The ACTU is the peak council of these organisations and it was cast solely in that co-ordination role.

As honourable senators will be aware, the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations issued a joint statement on 16 December 1985 concerning guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision and draft operational standards for superannuation schemes. The Government is seeking comment on the draft standards which are a framework for further discussion and development in co-operation with interested groups.

One part of the draft operational standards proposes standards for control of new superannuation funds which envisage equal numbers of trustees nominated by members and employers (or unions and employer organisations where appropriate). It is also the Government's intention that, where the productivity award is paid into existing schemes, member-union representation should be encouraged in respect of those schemes. Until the details of the control aspect of the draft operational standards have been firmed up and there is general agreement on the most suitable structure for the controlling bodies of superannuation funds, it would not be appropriate to make any significant change to the structure of the Trust.

Accordingly, for the time being, the Trust will remain as presently constituted under the Act, that is, a full-time member and two part-time members-all members of the Trust being nominated by the Minister for appointment by the Governor-General.

One change, however, that is being made is to remove the provision that permits the part-time position of members' representative on the Trust to be held by a pensioner and which requires pensioner organisations to be involved in the nomination process. Because members' accumulated contributions are paid out of the fund on retirement, pensioners and their organisations have no further interest in the performance of the Trust and the fund. For this reason this part-time member position has, in practice, only ever been held by a contributor to the scheme and the amendment being made will ensure that this arrangement continues.

The Government recognises that, in today's intensely competitive business environment, the task of managing and investing the fund, one of the largest superannuation funds in Australia, will demand all the skill and expertise of the members of the Trust. The Government is confident that the present Trust members are equal to this task. However, the question of the size and structure of the Trust will be re-examined in the light of both developments in operational standards for superannuation funds and the demands placed on the existing Trust members.

In recognition of the nature of the Trust's operations and that the independence of those operations free from direction is essential, the Bill enables the Trust to employ the staff necessary to carry out its functions under terms and conditions determined with the approval of the Minister. Trust staff not covered by the mobility provisions of the Public Service Act will be able to compete for all advertised vacancies in the Australian Public Service.

The present staff attached to the Trust are officers of the Department of Finance. They will have the option of accepting offers of employment with the Trust or remaining as departmental officers. It is expected that there will be few, if any, of the present staff who decline offers of employment with the Trust.
In addition to the implementation of reforms essential to the efficient and effective operation of the Trust, the Bill incorporates a number of other amendments to the Superannuation Act 1976.

The powers of a secretary of a department under the Public Service Act will be conferred on the Commissioner for Superannuation, who is charged with administering all elements of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme not relating to the management and investment of the fund.

An anomalous situation arising from a deficiency in the original drafting of the Act that has the effect of unintentionally making certain spouses and children of deceased pensioners ineligible for benefits will be corrected. (This is one of the new amendments that may affect future appropriations.)

The provisions relating to the issue of benefit classification certificates are designed to protect the Commonwealth against the risk, and thus the cost, of premature retirement or death because of a physical or mental condition existing at the time the person became a contributor. They are being amended following the recent decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to set aside the decision of the Commissioner for Superannuation to issue a benefit classification certificate in relation to Mr P. J. Bewley. The Bewley decision is at odds with an earlier decision of the Tribunal and interprets those provisions in a manner which was never intended and is contrary to the basic principles of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme.

This is the most recent example of the propensity of courts and tribunals to capriciously change long standing applications of the law in ways which significantly increase outlays. These amendments will establish the desirable precedent that legally capricious and fiscally irresponsible decisions by courts and tribunals will be set aside by the legislature. The proposed amendments clarify that the provisions are to have the meaning attributed to them prior to the Bewley decision rather than the meaning that has now been adopted by the Tribunal. The amendments are to have effect from 1 July 1976, the date of commencement of the principal Act, but will not affect the Tribunal's decision in relation to Mr Bewley.

The amendments are retrospective only in a technical sense. Indeed failure to enact these amendments would have a retrospective effect because they would impose on taxpayers a liability to pay enriched benefits which were neither intended nor expected. They do not remove any past benefit. They simply restore the status quo and ensure that past and future cases are treated on a common basis. Clearly it would be quite wrong in principle if contributors to the scheme who are currently subject to a benefit classification certificate could seek to take advantage of an unintended interpretation of the provisions and have their certificates revoked. As there are 66,000 certificates now in force, failure to apply the amendments retrospectively could lead to protracted and expensive legal proceedings and very significant administrative costs. The capitalised cost of the increased pensions that would have been payable to contributors who retired on invalidity grounds in 1984-85 if there had been no benefit classification certificates in force in relation to them has been estimated at $35m. Failure to ensure restoration of the status quo could mean costs of that order would be incurred by the taxpayer for the next decade or more.

The Bill also introduces a new provision to allow flexibility in arrangements where persons transfer from the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme to another Superannuation Scheme without necessarily changing employment. (This amendment may also affect further appropriations).
Finally, the Bill contains amendments to the cost recovery arrangements under the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976. The amendments will enable the Minister to:
Limit an employer's liability to the cost of the employer-financed share of any benefit that accrued under the scheme to an employee for service with that employer;
Determine that employers who, prior to 1 July 1981, were treated as if exempt from the requirement to meet the cost of superannuation benefits, are formally relieved of the pre-1981 liability; and
Require an employer to meet his liability to the Commonwealth on a pay-as-you-go basis as if the scheme were funded, rather than let the liability build up until benefits are eventually paid.

There is no financial impact on the Government as a result of the changes in respect of the trust. By regulations made under the Act, all costs involved in the management and investment of the fund, including staff costs, are borne by the fund. The Government expects that removal of restrictions on the investment powers of the trust as proposed in this Bill will enable greater returns to be generated by the fund for the benefit of contributors.
There are no implications for additional expenditure or revenue by conferring secretary powers on the Commissioner for Superannuation.

Minimal future additional costs will result from the changes correcting the anomalous disentitlement from benefits of certain children and spouses. To date, only one case of disentitlement has been identified.

The interpretation of the medical classification provisions adopted by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in its recent decision is not only contrary to the purpose of the provisions, but would have significant additional cost implications if allowed to stand. The Commonwealth would have little or no protection against the risk, and thus the cost of premature retirement or death because of a physical or mental condition existing at the time a person became a contributor. Thus, the amendments will ensure that the cost of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme does not increase as a result of the Tribunal's decision.

While speaking of the cost of the Commonwealth scheme, I would also like to emphasise that, as indicated in my press release dated 5 December 1985, allowances to be treated as salary for contribution and benefit purposes are to be confined to those presently contemplated by the Superannuation (Salary) Regulations. Where moves are made to have further categories of allowances recognised, immediate legislative action will be taken to ensure that they are not treated as salary.

The proposed power to modify the Act by regulations in relation to contributors transferring to other superannuation schemes will not of itself have any financial implications. Additional cost (if any) will depend upon the particular arrangements adopted in specific cases.

The employers who, under the cost recovery arrangements operating prior to 1 July 1981, were treated as if exempt from any liability would, but for the proposed changes, technically have a legal liability to the Commonwealth for the unpaid amounts. However, in practice, because the employers concerned would require additional funds from the Budget to meet the unpaid contributions, the payments by, and to, the Commonwealth would balance out, leaving the budgetary situation no different from what will be the case under the proposed amendment.

All parties have acknowledged the urgency of the reforms in relation to the trust incorporated in this Bill. To further delay their introduction will compound the damage already done to the interests of the more than 300,000 contributors to the fund by the failure to pass the 1985 Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Departure Tax Collection Act 1978 to transfer the responsibility for the collection of departure tax to air operators.

As honourable senators will be aware the Government, as part of its decision on the recommendations of the Bosch Committee on Aviation Cost Recovery, has decided that departure tax will be an attributable revenue for aviation cost recovery purposes from 1 July 1986.

Collection of the tax by air operators will have the major advantage of the removal of departure tax collection booths from airports, with the consequent benefit of achieving more efficient passenger flows through our international terminals.
In addition, the Government will be able to reduce existing expenditures of approximately $1 million each year directly incurred in collecting the tax, plus associated overhead costs.

In taking this step, the Government is bringing the Australian situation into line with practice in a number of other countries, including New Zealand, United States, Hong Kong, Singapore, Fiji and the Philippines where similar taxes are collected by the airlines.

Consultations with air operators have been undertaken and are continuing. The Board of Airline Representatives of Australia, which represents the majority of carriers serving Australia, has been requested to put forward its proposals on how the new collection arrangements should operate.

The amendments provide for these arrangements to be provided for in regulations to be made pursuant to the Act, and this will be done when consultations with the operators have been finalised. This approach will also ensure that any necessary changes to arrangements in the future can be speedily made.
Consultations held to date with operators indicate that sale of stamps at check-in at airports will be necessary, plus some additional outlets off airports.

Clause 5 of the Bill makes it a requirement for international air operators to make tax and exemption stamps available for sale and issue respectively to passengers, and provides that the Government can specify by regulation how this is to be carried out.

Operators responsible for making stamps available will include not only the scheduled airlines, but also operators who carry out international charter flights. Clause 5 however exempts from this responsibility operators who undertake private flights and aerial work as these operate few flights, often from non-major airports.

The Government has also decided that it would be unreasonable to expect small charter operators, who operate infrequent flights and carry few passengers, to have to comply with the requirements of the Bill. The Minister will therefore be able to exempt individual charter operations, having particular regard to the scale of operations involved.

The Act nevertheless requires non-exempt passengers on such private, aerial work or exempted charter flights to pay departure tax, and it is intended that existing arrangements for collection of the tax in these cases will continue.
The penalties for offences of failing to make stamps available, without reasonable excuse, is to be $2,000 where the offender is a natural person, or $10,000 where the offender is a body corporate.
The Bill leaves unchanged existing arrangements for the collection of departure tax from passengers who depart from Australia by sea.

As regards the financial impact of the proposed legislation, I have already referred to the approximately $1 million savings each year in direct costs that will accrue to the Commonwealth. Ongoing administrative costs to the Government arising from the proposal will be minimal. Costs of modifying counters at airports have yet to be quantified, and are to be determined following consultation with the airlines as to requirements.

While the cost of collecting the tax currently borne by the Government will now be borne by the airlines, the government considers this to be reasonable, against the background of its decision to make revenue from the tax attributable. Moreover, it should be noted that these are costs which the airline are often required to beat in other countries where they operate.

In conclusion, the Bill will achieve an ongoing reduction in Government expenditure on the costs of collecting departure tax, while facilitating more efficient processing of international passengers using our airports. The regulations to be made pursuant to the provisions of the Bill will also ensure that there is no loss of revenue to the Commonwealth.
I commend the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This bill proposes new arrangements for the introduction and implementation of Bounty Assistance whenever such assistance is proposed following the Government's consideration of appropriate Industries Assistance Commission Reports.
At present, Bounty Assistance to industry can only be introduced by way of an act of this Parliament.

The Government believes that an inordinate amount of time is spent by the Parliament in considering legislation to implement this form of Industries Assistance which is essentially non-contentious. We consider that the introduction of Bounty Assistance would be more efficiently made through a ministerial notification process, which on the one hand, would preserve and ensure Parliamentary scrutiny by a General Disallowance Right, and, on the other, would not infringe on Parliament's sitting time to the same degree as the current procedure requiring numerous bills and amending bills.

To this end part two of the bill proposes that Bounty schemes be implemented by Bounty notices, declared in writing by the Minister and published in the Gazette. Such schemes would of course only be introduced following the receipt of an Appropriate Industries Assistance Commission Report on the particular industry or industries concerned. This is for the reason that the Minister is required to comply with section 23 of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 which prohibits Ministerial action related to the provision of Industries Assistance without a current report on the industry from the Commission.

The new procedure proposed by this bill should not be interpreted as a diminution in the importance of this type of assistance. In fact quite to the contrary. The Government has attached and will continue to attach considerable importance to bounties as one of the key elements in its Industries Assistance Policy of providing direct support to industry against import competition.
A most important feature of the new arrangements is the ability of the Parliament to disallow Ministerial Bounty Notices.
That procedure, which is set out in clause 10, is the same as the disallowance procedure applicable to regulations.

I mentioned earlier that the introduction of Ministerial Notices, in conjunction with the disallowance procedure, is designed to save valuable Parliamentary time without derogating from Parliament's opportunity to scrutinise each notice and, if considered necessary, to reject a particular measure.

It is appropriate at this point for me to provide some historical facts in relation to bounties. The first bounty legislation was introduced in 1907 by Act No. 12 of 1907 and provided for Bounty Assistance on the production in Australia of a variety of agricultural products and fish. Since that time a considerable number of schemes have been introduced, covering a wide range of Australian Industry, generally, I am pleased to say, with the bi partisan support of the Parliament.
There are 18 bounty schemes currently in operation, the most recent being that for metal working machines and robots effective from 1 July 1985.
Almost invariably each Parliamentary sitting deals with about 3 or 4 pieces of bounty legislation, with the majority operating retrospectively.
It is this retrospective operation which has concerned the Government for some time because the Bounty Assistance cannot be given to industry until the legislation has the royal assent.

The new arrangements, proposed by this bill, are designed to eliminate the need for retrospective operation of bounties. Indeed the arrangements will probably overcome the anomalous situation which exists at present whereby a manufacturer or importer can enjoy the benefit of a change in Tariff Rates almost instantly, while an intended bounty recipient might be denied the benefit of Bounty Assistance for some months.

This is because tariff changes, which are linked to the bounty, can be effected by gazette notification whereas bounties can only be effected by an act of Parliament. A similar gazette notification procedure for bounties will enable their immediate introduction following the Government's consideration of the relevant Industries Assistance Commission Report. I am sure that industry will welcome this bill for that reason alone.

Let me illustrate the current time lag, and the benefit to industry which should result as a result of the proposed notice procedure on this bill, referring again to the Government's assistance measures for metal working machines and robots. The legislation to implement that matter was introduced into the Parliament on 11 September 1985 and received the royal assent on 22 November 1985. Because it operated from 1 July 1985 there was a delay of nearly six months before the bounty could be paid and the Australian producers accorded the benefit from the assistance intended for them.
In the absence of this bill such delays will no doubt continue because of the complexity of some bounty legislation and the bi-annual of Parliamentary sitting times.

Under the arrangements proposed by this bill a bounty notice for metal working machines and robots could have been gazetted in late June, 1985 immediately following the government's decision, with bounty payments starting at least 5 months sooner than would have been possible under existing arrangements.
I now turn to the other important elements in the bill.

Parts 3, 4 and 5 will standardize the administrative provisions for all bounty schemes-a vast improvement on the current plethora of provisions which have evolved in the different schemes over the past 15 years.

This standardization is expected to result in better administration of bounties-an important consideration in today's public service environment where the government is intent on achieving the best possible use of expensive resources.

Further, clause 8 of the Bill will provide the necessary flexibility to amend schemes introduced under this Bill so as to deal with changing technological or economic circumstances. These provisions, which do not apply to schemes now on foot, will allow a scheme to be modified by regulation in very limited circumstances so as to enable for example, an extension of the scheme for up to 6 months, a variation in the rates of bounty payable, the range of goods eligible for bounty or the eligibility criteria for the payment of bounty. The government is of the view that such a facility is essential if bounty schemes are to remain relevant in the face of changing economic or technological developments which could not have been reasonably foreseen at the introduction of the original scheme. The difficulty in applying the books bounty legislation, dating from 1969, to today's printing industry which has undergone vast technological change, is a good case in point. The proposed amendment procedure for bounty schemes, by regulation, will of course preserve the parliament's ability to scrutinise any proposed changes through the disallowance mechanism applying to regulations. Amendments to schemes on foot at this moment will need to be made by appropriate amending legislation in the usual way.

Because of the significance of bounties as an element of the government's industries assistance policies, a joint management review of bounty administration was undertaken in 1984 by an experienced team led by a senior partner in the consultancy firm of Arthur Young Services. Many of the provisions of parts 3 and 4 of the Bill respond to the recommendations made by that consultancy firm and will enable the Australian Customs Service to build on the improvements in bounty administration already achieved.

The government believes the measures contained in this Bill, which will standardise the administrative procedures for bounty schemes and make their implementation and variation much more relevant to today's circumstances will benefit not only industry, but also the administrators of bounty schemes and the parliament itself.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill does not it itself involve any outlays by the Commonwealth. However, bounty schemes established under the Bill will involve outlays, the extent of which will vary from scheme to scheme. For established schemes, estimates of expenditure will be given in the budget papers in the usual way. For new schemes, financial details will be provided at the time of announcement by the government of the establishment of the scheme.
I present the explanatory memorandum on this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
