Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
DAIRY PRODUCE BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill and five other related Bills is to enhance the capacity of the Australian Dairy Industry to market its produce. Measures are proposed to make the industry more market responsive. Government regulation of marketing is to be reduced. Assistance is to be provided in a less distortionary way, as recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission. Also provided for is reform of the Australian Dairy Corporation.
One year ago Bills were introduced to reform dairy marketing arrangements. The House of Representatives gave passage to those Bills; the Senate did not.

Following the failure of the 1985 Bills to pass both chambers, The Australian Dairy Industry Conference sought Commonwealth Government support for its own plan which, while incorporating most of the features of the arrangements proposed in the 1985 Bills, also incorporated a production restraint device. The Government agreed to assist the implementation of this plan if it were shown to have broad industry and State Government support. Subsequently the Chairman of the Conference reported to me that there was insufficient support in the industry for this so called ``ADIC Plan'' to proceed.

Last year the Minister for Primary Industry outlined the genesis and dimension of the problems facing the Australian dairy industry. He also demonstrated that the current assistance and marketing arrangements were inequitable and inefficient. These arrangements stimulate overproduction while discouraging domestic consumption; distort returns to individual manufacturers so that the Australian product mix is not the best; provide greatest assistance to exports to the least profitable markets, encourage imports and constrain industry unnecessarily by regulation.

The passage of one year has not changed the nature or dimension of the problem nor the Government's concern to see the end to a system that is, demonstrably, serving the industry badly. Some reform has been able to be achieved within the framework of existing legislation, in particular the discontinuance of ``allowances'' on 1 July 1985. However the need for thorough reform remains.

The Government's basic objective is the development of a more efficient and profitable dairy industry, able to respond as quickly as possible to changing market conditions and technology. Only through such industry development can we hope to maintain the largest Australian dairy industry that is viable at an acceptable level of industry assistance.

The strategy to achieve this objective is directed both to the domestic market and the export market. In respect of the domestic market, the need is a system that encourages the local industry to improve its competitiveness so that it can maintain its dominance of this market. In regard to the export market, the strategy is to encourage the exploitation of the more profitable export markets, and in particular to discourage production for export that returns a net loss to Australia.
This strategy is to be given effect by the following measures:

(1) One, the cessation of export pooling arrangements so that exporters become more market responsive. A criticism that has oft been levelled at the current arrangements is that people are encouraged to ``play the system'' rather than to work the market.

(2) Second, the replacement of current stabilization arrangements, which provide an encouragement to the production and export of some dairy products more than others by arrangements designed to provide a more uniform level of assistance to all products. This change should, over time, encourage a more profitable mix of production.
(3) Third, the market support arrangements which are to replace the current stabilization arrangements will be financed in the least distortionary way, by a levy on all milk production.

(4) Fourth, the progressive reduction in domestic price support to a level no higher than the price level at which New Zealand dairy products could be sold in Australia on a fair trade basis. Our industry must, over time, put itself in the position where it can defend its position in the Australian market of the basis of its competitiveness.

(5) Fifth, the local industry will continue to be protected against unfair import competition. The industry has been able to achieve redress by invoking anti-dumping and countervailing measures where unfair competition has been shown to damage or to threaten damage to the industry. If, in the future, these measures should prove to be inadequate, other measures will be considered by the Government.
(6) Sixth, the Australian Dairy Corporation is to be reformed to enhance its effectiveness, and to upgrade the accountability of the Corporation to the dairy industry.
(7) Seventh, assistance is being made available for specific purposes-for adjustment, for marketing innovation, for research, and for dairy underwriting.

Last year the Minister for Primary Industry announced that the Commonwealth would be prepared to participate with the States, on a one-to-one basis, in a joint $40 million adjustment program for the dairy industry. Subsequently, the Commonwealth decided that where a dairy specific program was undertaken within the Rural Adjustment Scheme, the Commonwealth would contribute according to the general provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme. This means that, for Rural Adjustment Scheme special dairy assistance, the States are now required to match the Commonwealth dairy adjustment contribution only in respect of ``carry-on'' assistance. Arrangements covering dairy adjustment have now been finalised with most of the States.

On 15 April last, the Minister for Primary Industry announced the establishment of a $25 million special fund for new marketing initiatives. The dairy industry is one industry that could be expected to take advantage of this Fund.

The dairy industry has advised the Government that the operative rate of research levy should be increased. Parliament recently increased the maximum rate specified by legislation, thus enabling an increase in the operative rate. The increased industry contribution to expenditure on research will be matched by a similar increase in Commonwealth assistance for research.
I will speak about underwriting later.

Let me now turn to the particulars of the Dairy Produce Bill 1986. This Bill provides the necessary elements of the arrangements to assist the marketing of dairy products. The Bill includes provisions to reform the Australian Dairy Corporation, to control the export of Australian dairy products, to enable the collection of levies for various purposes, to enable the making of market support payments, and to reform the Dairying Industry Stabilization Fund.
Reform of the Australian Dairy Corporation

The Bill provides for significant reforms in relation to the Australian Dairy Corporation. These reforms stem principally from the Government's general Program for Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities and from the role of the Corporation is to have in administration of the proposed new market support system.
The reforms to the Australian Dairy Corporation proposed in this Bill have been decided on by the Government only after extensive consultation with industry representatives.
Objectives and Functions

The most basic plank of our policy on the reform of Statutory Marketing Authorities is that the functions and objectives of each authority are to be clarified and clearly stated in its enabling legislation. This Bill details the functions of the Australian Dairy Corporation, all of which involve an aspect of the marketing of Australian dairy produce. The objective to be given to the Corporation is that it should discharge these functions efficiently so as to enhance the profitable production and marketing of Australian dairy produce.

In a number of important areas the Corporation is to have significant discretion as to how it discharges it functions. These areas include, for example, the range of dairy produce to be assisted, the basis on which particular dairy products are to be assisted, and the availability of stock-holding finance from the Corporation. The proposed legislation requires the Corporation to make decisions in these matters having regard to its objective, and in some cases requires the Corporation to set down the criteria to be used to test whether a course of action would further the objective of the Corporation.
Accountability
As with other Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities, the Australian Dairy Corporation has dual accountability. One line is to the Parliament. The other line is to the dairy industry.

The Commonwealth Government recognizes the Australian Dairy Industry Conference as the industry organisation best able to speak for the Australian dairy industry as a whole, and the Council of that body as the appropriate organisation that should be consulted by the Corporation on the Corporation's activities generally. The Council of the Conference consists of representatives of dairy farmer organisations and representatives of dairy product manufacturing and trading organisations. The Conference has agreed to expand this membership to include a representative of the market milk sector and a representative of employees in the industry.

The proposed legislation will require the Council to be consulted by the Corporation when the Corporation is planning its strategy for the years ahead and when the Corporation is planning its operations for the forthcoming year. The Corporation will also need the approval of the Council if it wishes to undertake certain activities.

A significant degree of accountability to the industry will be achieved through the required inter-action of the Corporation and the Council. To complement this, the annual report of the Corporation is to be presented to a meeting of the Conference at large and the Chairperson of the Corporation will report on the activities of the Corporation and answer questions arising. It may also be appropriate for the Chairman of the Council to report to the meeting on the Council's dealings with the Corporation, but that is a matter for the Council. It would be desirable for this meeting to be open to all persons involved in the Australian dairy industry.
The proposed legislation provides for accountability to Parliament in the normal way through the tabling of an annual report.

It should be noted that the legislation is to be tightened to require that the activities of any subsidiary companies that the Corporation may be permitted to form must fall within the functions given to the corporation by the Parliament.

In regard to Asia Dairy Industries, an already existing subsidiary of the Corporation, the Corporation will be required to ensure that the company only undertakes activities that are specifically allowed for by the legislation.

It is also proposed that the Minister may in exceptional circumstances give directions to the Corporation. Where this is done, the directions are to be tabled in the Parliament within 15 sitting days unless there is a commercial or national interest reason why the direction should not be disclosed.
Powers

Subject to certain restrictions the Corporation is to be empowered to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done in connection with the performance of its functions. In general, the Corporation will be subject to less Ministerial control in operational matter than it is under current legislation. However this reduction is to be matched by new corporate and annual operational plan requirements and by the greater legislated interface between the Corporation and the Council of the Conference. I say ``legislated interface'' because much of what is in the proposed legislation is in fact occurring now without it being a legislative requirement.

There are to be two restrictions imposed on the power of the Corporation to deal in diary produce. The first, which is in line with past practice, is that the Corporation's trading activities-in the broad-are to be approved by the Council of the Conference. The second is that Council and Ministerial approval is to be required where the Corporation wishes to engage in transactions that it anticipates will result in a loss. Loss-making sales involve a cross-subsidy from other dairy industry industry activities, and hence have the potential to thwart the objectives of the new marketing arrangements. Loss-making sales should not be absolutely ruled out because they may be necessary in exceptional circumstances. However they need to be controlled, and for this reason industry and Ministerial approval is needed.

The Corporation will retain the power to make loans to assist manufacturers hold stocks of their dairy produce. Such loans have become a part of the Dairy Industry, allowing the farmer to be paid for his milk soon after its delivery.

The requirement for all loans to be secured will continue. The Government has been advised by the Corporation that one factor to influence the Corporation's decision on the rate at which loans can be made is the ability of the Corporation to meet any losses arising from a borrower's default should the security, on realisation, fail to cover the debt. As the reserves of the Corporation are relatively low the Government has decided to advise the Corporation that it should, until otherwise advised, determine loan rates on the basis that the Commonwealth would, if needed, be prepared to supplement the Corporation's Reserves by up to $10 million. There is no provision covering this in the Bills-an appropriation will be needed if ever this ``guarantee'' has to be called upon.
Corporate and Annual Operational Plans

The Corporation will be required to prepare, and update each year a corporate plan covering 3 to 5 years ahead. The Corporation will also be required to prepare operational plans annually that are consistent with the Corporate plan. The Council of the Conference is to be consulted during these processes. Both plans will require Ministerial agreement.
Membership of the Corporation

The Government's policy is that Statutory Marketing Authorities should be constituted on corporate lines and objective selection procedures used to seek out high calibre persons for appointment. The reasons for taking this approach, rather than an approach that constitutes Statutory Marketing Authorities on the basis of industry sector representation, are given in the policy paper of Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities that was tabled in this House recently.

Consistent with this policy, the Bill proposes that the Australian Dairy Corporation should be restructured to include a Chairperson, a Government member, the Managing Director and eight other appointed members. Members in the last category are to be chosen by a Selection Committee that comprises a Chairman who is selected by the Minister and four other members nominated by the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference. The Selection Committee is given the task of selecting a Board that collectively possesses a range of specified skills or experience.
Export Control

The Bill provides for kinds of dairy produce to be prescribed by regulation as controlled dairy exports. Export of controlled dairy produce will only be permitted by the Corporation or by licensed exporters. The regulations may prescribe conditions to be complied with in relation to the export from Australia of controlled dairy exports. Compliance with GATT-International Dairy Arrangement minimum prices will be made a condition of export.

Under current arrangements export licences are issued by the Minister. This Bill provides for their issue by the Corporation. Criteria are provided for their issue, suspension or cancellation, and decisions are appealable.

The Bill provides that the Corporation may require licensees to consult the Corporation about their export intentions and performance. This provision will assist the Corporation in the discharge of its functions generally and may allow the Corporation to co-ordinate the activities of exporters to their individual and collective gain. It will also facilitate co-operation between the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries in third markets as provided for in the Memorandum of Understanding between the two industries pursuant to the Australian New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement.

The Minister for Primary Industry is aware of a concern expressed by some exporters that they may be commercially disadvantaged by being required to disclose to the Corporation their intentions in regard to specific market opportunities. To deal with this concern the legislation will require the Corporation to consider, in its planning process, the circumstances, if any, in which licensees will be required, in consultations with the Corporation, to disclose details of intentions in relation to specific possible future export sales. Since this consideration will be part of the planning process, the industry, through the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference will have to be consulted.

The Bill also provides for the Corporation to give directions to licensees in relation to matters specified in the Act or specified by regulation. However, the Corporation may not issue directions unless all licensees have been given 14 days notice and the Council of the Conference has agreed to the directions being given. Directions will need to be given by the Corporation if certain business, now exclusively handled by the Corporation with the agreement of the Conference, is to remain so.
Collection of Levies

This Bill provides for the collection of levies which are needed to finance the operations of the Corporation including the market support and promotion arrangements and to provide an industry contribution for research purposes. The proposed legislation follows existing legislation for the collection of research and promotion levies and stabilization levies.

Provision has been made to allow the delayed collection of the market support levy. Delayed collection is possible because export of dairy produce will occur some time after the delivery of milk used in its production. Delayed collection may be desirable at the commencement of the market support arrangements in order to assist industry cash flow.
Financial Provisions

Part VII of the Bill deals with financial aspects of the ADC activities and updates current provisions having regard to the increase in autonomy that is to be accorded to the Corporation. A number of matters warrant brief mention:
The means by which the Corporation can raise money are to be extended to include a wider range of contemporary financial instruments.
A specific provision is made to enable the Corporation to engage in futures trading within appropriate guidelines.
Investment in the short-term money market of money which is temporarily surplus is provided for.

To assist the better management of its moneys, the Corporation is to be empowered to make short-term loans from one fund that it administers to another fund that it administers. Such loans may only be made to meet a temporary deficit in the receiving fund.
A provision is included which requires the Corporation to credit any surplus and debit any deficit, stemming from sales it makes in its own right, to the market support fund.

The legislation provides for the appointment of a commercial auditor in lieu of the Auditor-General. The appointment of a commercial auditor will require the agreement of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Parliamentary Accounts.

Part VII of the Bill also establishes four funds under which significant areas of Corporation activity are controlled and accounted. These funds are the Dairy Industry Fund, the Promotion Fund, the Market Support Fund and the Supplementary Market Support Fund.
The Industry Fund
The Industry Fund is to be established as the successor to the Dairy Industry Stabilization Fund.
The Dairying Industry Stabilization Fund, or ``DISF'' as it is commonly known, is a longstanding fund administered by the Corporation.
At 30 June 1985 the accumulated funds of the DISF amounted to about $5.5 million of which $1.9 million comprises the value of investments in various companies and $3.6 million is in liquid assets.

Government policy has been that the moneys of the DISF are to be used for the benefit of the dairy industry at large. Accordingly the practice has evolved whereby, before any Ministerial approval is given to expenditure from the Fund the Australian Dairy Industry Conference is consulted.

The net effect of transforming the Dairying Industry Stabilization Fund in the Dairy Industry Fund is to specify in legislation the purposes of which the Fund may be used and to replace the requirement for Ministerial approval with a requirement that expenditures from the Industry Fund be approved by the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference. The Conference supports the approach that is being taken.
The Promotion Fund
The provisions in this Bill are essentially similar to those of current legislation.
The Market Support Fund and the Supplementary Market Support Fund
The market support arrangements provided for in this Bill are proposed to apply to production on or after 1 July 1986.

Central to the proposed new marketing arrangements are market support payments and supplementary market support payments. These are payments to be made by the Australian Dairy Corporation on export of all dairy produce. The making of such payments will improve the return on export, and mean that a domestic sale would have to be made at a higher price than would otherwise be the case for the domestic sale to be as profitable as an export sale. In this way the system will provide support for the domestic price structure.
The funds for the making of market support payments and supplementary market support payments will, apart from any Commonwealth contribution by way of underwriting, come from the industry.
The Market Support Fund

The market support fund can be regarded as the continuing element of the new market support arrangements. Key transactions are the payment into the fund of a market support levy, which is a levy raised on all milk produced, and the expenditure of fund moneys as market support payments.

Products eligible for market support payments are to be milk, cream, and dairy products declared for the purposes of the Act to be dairy produce by the Australian Dairy Corporation in the Commonwealth Gazette. The intention is that, subject to practical considerations, all products made from or containing milk or a constituent part of milk should be eligible for market support payments. The criteria adopted by the Corporation in deciding how far to go in declaring products to be dairy produce is to be stated in its corporate plan.

For each product that has been declared to be dairy produce the Australian Dairy Corporation will publish rates of market support payment and supplementary market support payment. Payment will then be made by the corporation at these rates to the manufacturer of the dairy produce on presentation of proof that export has occurred. However, special rates will apply in certain circumstances-I will mention these shortly.

The rate at which market support payments will be made will be the rate ruling at the time of export unless another rate has been guaranteed by the Corporation. In this regard, the Bill provides that the Corporation may determine, on application by a person prior to export, that the market support rate for a particular export will be the rate ruling at the time of application rather than the time of export. This facility should assist exporters in making sales by providing them with a firmer basis on which to make an offer to a potential buyer than would otherwise be the case. Any decision of the Corporation not to guarantee a rate for a particular export will be reviewable under standard Administrative Appeals Tribunal procedures.

The Bill provides for the standard rate of market support payment to be determined in one of two ways depending whether the product is prescribed or not. For prescribed dairy produce, the rate will determined as a percentage of the estimated average export price for the kind of dairy produce concerned. For other dairy produce, rates will be determined by the Corporation having regard to the rates established for prescribed dairy produce.

The Bill provides for the Corporation to decide which kinds of dairy products should be prescribed dairy produce. The criteria adopted by the Corporation in this decision are to be stated in its Corporate plan. Hence industry will be consulted. Initially, it is expected that prescribed products will include those products which are now prescribed for stabilization and export pooling purposes.

For each kind of prescribed dairy produce the market support rate is to be 30 per cent of the estimated average export price, unless a different percentage is determined by the Corporation. This level of assistance has been accepted by the Government as a reasonable medium term support level having regard to industry assistance considerations and the objective and strategy for the Australian dairy industry that I have already talked about. It should be noted that the 30% has been established in relation to estimates of average export prices under the export pooling system that has operated for many years. These estimates relate to a concept designed to reflect the value added in the process of producing the dairy product but exclude the value added in packaging, transport etc. It is anticipated that the Corporation will, initially at least, compile estimated average export prices under the new arrangements on this basis also. Should the Corporation consider that there is good reason to change radically the basis on which estimates of average export prices are to be compiled, the appropriate percentage to be applied in calculating market support rates would need to be considered by Government.

The Corporation will be required to reduce the percentage rate should it judge that a 30% rate will not be able to be sustained having regard to the funds likely to be available for market support purposes. The Corporation may reduce the rate for other reasons also provided that the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference agrees with the reasons for wanting to do so.

Let me now briefly mention special rates of market support payment. These may be paid in certain circumstances. These circumstances include where a foreign country has imposed quantitative restrictions on exports from Australia and where necessary to conform with international trade commitments. Special rates may also apply to exports under agreements entered into before 25 February 1986 where the products concerned are sourced from production on or after 1 July 1986. The last mentioned provision is necessary so that agreements entered into before the announcement of the new arrangements are not disadvantaged.

Special rates of market support payment may also apply for underwritten products. Underwritten products will be the products that have been traditionally underwritten-that is butter, cheese, whole milk powder, skim milk powder and casein. The market support arrangements for these products will work on a ``pot holing'' principle-when the export price falls below a specified figure the amount of market support payment will be increased above the level that would be calculated using the 30% rule. More specifically, ``pot holing'' will apply when the estimated average export price for any of the underwritten products is below 85% of what would be expected if export prices for the product concerned were on their longer term trend line. Where this ``pot holing'' is to apply, the market support rate will equal the difference between 110% of the longer term trend value and the estimated average export price. Funds for ``pot holing'' will be drawn from the market support fund.
Supplementary Market Support Payments
The legislation provides for supplementary market support payments to assist the transition from current arrangements.

Supplementary market support payments will be made whenever a market support payment is made. As with market support payments, supplementary market support payments for prescribed dairy produce will normally be determined as a percentage of the estimated average export price of the product concerned, with the percentage being the same for all products. Special rates of supplementary market support may also apply in certain circumstances.
Supplementary market support rates will decline over time as the product levies which provide their funding are reduced.

Initial rates of product levy and supplementary market support payment will be determined in line with a recommendation from the Australian Dairy Corporation that the theoretical domestic price support values under the new arrangements on 1 July 1986 should slightly exceed the theoretical domestic price support values (referred to as the DVLP) under current arrangements. The recommended increases are 5% in the case of butter and 8% in the case of cheese. The Government has accepted this recommendation in order to assist a smooth transition from current to new arrangements.
Underwriting
The Commonwealth will continue to underwrite average export returns for the traditionally underwritten products-butter, cheddar-type cheese, skim milk powder, whole milk powder and casein.

Currently underwriting applies in relation to the average export price received in respect of a year's production. The underwritten price is 90% of the estimated average export price received for production of the most recent three years including the year in question.

A somewhat different basis for underwriting will apply in the future. The average export price received in respect of a year's sales will be underwritten. The underwritten price will be 85% of the value that the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates would have obtained for the year in question if export prices were on their longer term trend line.

The change in the basis for underwriting has been made for a number or reasons. The new method will align better with the proposed new market support system, in particular with its orientation towards sales rather than production, and with its ``pot holing'' element. It also remedies a difficulty with the ``90% three-year-moving-average'' approach, namely, that underwriting can be triggered when prices are declining but still relatively good in absolute terms, but may not be triggered during a progressive decline into a price trough.

The new basis also makes sense against the current outlook for international trade prices of an extended downturn before restoration of more normal price levels. The change in the basis of underwriting is expected to work to the benefit of the Australian dairy industry.
Financial Impact

The impact of these Bills on net Government expenditure is expected to be minimal. The Australian Dairy Corporation will reimburse the Commonwealth the cost of collecting the new market support levies. The cost of collecting all other levies will be met by the Commonwealth as it is under current arrangements. Appropriation of moneys for underwriting purposes is not provided for in these Bills.
Other Matters
There are two other aspects that I would draw to the House's attention.

The first is the ``sunset'' clause providing for cessation of the market support arrangements after six years. Further legislation would thus be required for the arrangements to continue beyond June 1992.

One other aspect is a new provision concerning the liability of the Corporation for Asia Dairy Industries or any prescribed subsidiary companies. This provision makes the Corporation liable to meet any liabilities of ADI and any prescribed subsidiary that cannot be met from the subsidiary's assets in the event that the subsidiary is wound-up.

Should the Corporation ever be in this position, the cost of meeting the subsidiary's undischarged liabilities would become a charge against the moneys of the Corporation and could be expected to require a higher rate of Corporation levy than would otherwise be the case. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference has accepted this as a reasonable proposition in relation to Asia Dairy Industries. No prescription of any other existing company in which the Corporation has a shareholding is proposed.
Future Development and Review

I have already noted that the Australian Dairy Corporation is to have considerable discretion in the management of the market support system. This will allow the system to develop further in the light of the ex- perience gained in its operation. The planning process will ensure that industry is consulted and ultimate Government control will be maintained.
The Government will monitor the development of the system carefully and proposes to undertake, with the Corporation and the industry, major reviews in 1988-89 and 1991-92.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 1) BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill and the complementary Dairy Produce Levy (No. 2) Bill is to impose various levies. These levies are required to finance the operations of the Australian Dairy Corporation including its activities in promoting dairy produce, to finance new market support arrangements and to raise moneys from the dairy industry for dairy research.
The Bill imposes two types of levies-levies on milk fat produced on or after 1 July 1986, and levies on certain types of dairy products produced on or after 1 July 1986.
Levies on Milk Fat
There are four milk fat levies-the Corporation levy, the promotion levy, the research levy and the market support levy.

The Corporation levy, the promotion levy and the research levy are to replace levies for similar purposes which are currently imposed on milk and butterfat under the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972.

Under the new levy arrangements, the amount of levy payable by a producer will depend on the amount of milk fat contained in his milk. Under current arrangements where a producer delivers whole milk to a processor, the levy is calculated at a rate per litre regardless of fat content; only where the producer delivers cream is the levy based on fat content. The change to a standard milk fat basis arises from a decision to base the market support levy on milk fat and the desirability of having a standard base for all levies on milk.

The Bill provides a clause to cover the situation where it has not been possible to ascertain the milk fat content. This clause should only have to be resorted to for a small proportion of Australian production since most milk payment systems require the recording of milk fat content.

The Bill specifies maximum rates for all milk fat levies with the operative rates to be set by regulation. For market support levy the maximum rate of levy is to be 45 cents per kilogram of milk fat, which is equivalent to 2 cents per litre for milk of average fat content. In the case of the research levy, the maximum rate specified corresponds to the maximum rate of 2.5 cents recently set in the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Act 1986. The maximum rates for the promotion and Corporation levies are respectively 5.5 cents per kilogram fat and 2.5 cents per kilogram fat.
In prescribing operative rates of Corporation, promotion, or research levy, regard will be had to any recommendations by the Executive Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference.

The market support levy is to be imposed in order to provide funds for the making of market support payments. These payments have the effect of supporting the domestic price structure for exportable dairy products at a level higher than would otherwise prevail. As a consequence, manufacturers of exportable dairy produce are able to pay a higher price for their milk than would otherwise be the case. This tends to establish a base price for milk with premiums above this price being established in particular uses. As market support payments thus underpin the entire structure of milk prices, it is equitable that the market support levy apply across all milk production.

However, a particular concern of some States is the possible impact of the market support levy on market milk producers if it were being imposed at a time of significant disruption or change in that sector. To address this and other concerns about the impact of the market support levy, the legislation provides for the possibility of a suspension of the levy and hence market support payments.

Any State Minister with portfolio responsibility for the Dairy Industry may notify the Commonwealth Minister for Primary Industry that the levy should be suspended. In the event of such notification, urgent advice will be sought on this matter from the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference.

This advice is to be received by Australian Agricultural Council, considered, and a decision taken within 60 days of the notification being received by the Commonwealth Minister. At the expiration of the sixty days, unless Australian Agricultural Council, by majority decision, has resolved that the levy should not be suspended, the levy is to be suspended as soon as practicable.

The market support levy is to be imposed on milk fat. This is, in part, because overseas experience shows that levy avoidance through ``de-watering'' of milk could be a significant problem if the levy were cast in ``per litre'' terms. It also makes sense in that the rate of payment to the producer for his milk generally varies in direct proportion to the milk fat content.

The operative rate of market support levy will need to be a rate sufficient to finance the operation of the market support payments system. In prescribing a rate, regard will be had to any recommendation from the Australian Dairy Corporation.
Dairy Products Levy
Levies on certain dairy products are required to finance supplementary market support payments. Effectively, this levy will be imposed only on domestic sales of the product concerned.

Levies will not be imposed on other than those products which are currently subject to stabilization levies, and within this group only for products where a levy is considered necessary at the start of the new arrangements to support the domestic price for the product concerned. On current estimates of likely export returns, a levy will be required only for butter, butter oil and cheddar-type cheese. For butter, the levy required is likely to be of the order of $600-$700 per tonne, for cheese $250-$300 per tonne.

The levies imposed on dairy products are to be reduced over time. Levies imposed on 1 July 1986 will be maintained at their initial value throughout 1986-87 and then reduced in six monthly steps. The first reduction will occur on 1 July 1987. The intention is that all levies other than on butter and butteroil should be eliminated by 1 July 1989, and that the rate of levy for butter and butteroil should be halved by then. The future of the levies on butter and butteroil is to be reviewed in 1988-89. Levies will be set by regulation.
Levies on dairy products imposed by this Bill will apply to production on or after 1 July 1986. Stabilization levies will not apply to production after 30 June 1986.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 2) BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to complement the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill by imposing certain levies on the import of dairy produce that has been exported from Australia and subsequently imported back into Australia. The Bill is necessary to close off an opportunity to exploit the market support arrangements that would otherwise be possible through an export/ import procedure.

Two levies are imposed. The levy on exempted dairy products is designed to re-impose a levy in respect of which an exemption was given on export of the product. The levy on supported dairy product is designed to avoid re-imports of Australian dairy products from obtaining the benefit of the market support payments made on export as well as the supported domestic price.
Levy is payable by the importer.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND PROMOTION LEVY (TERMINATION OF LEVY) BILL 1986

The Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972 imposes levies on whole milk or butterfat produced in Australia and sold by the producer of the whole milk. These levies are used to fund the general expenses and the promotional activities of the Australian Dairy Corporation and to assist dairy research.
The Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill provides for new levies to raise the funds for these purposes. These new levies will apply to milk fat produced on or after 1 July 1986.
The purpose of this Bill is to limit the imposition of the old levies to production occurring before 1 July 1986.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY (TERMINATION OF LEVY) BILL 1986
Stabilization levy is imposed on the production of prescribed dairy products.

It is proposed that stabilization arrangements should cease to apply at the end of the current production season on 30 June 1986. The purpose of this Bill is to limit the imposition of stabilization levy to production occurring on or before 30 June 1986.
I commend the Bill to the honourable senators.
DAIRY LEGISLATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986
This Bill is one of six Bills, whose purpose is to establish new market support arrangements for the Australian dairy industry.

Apart from clause 10, all provisions of the Bill are in the nature of transitional or amending provisions consequent upon the enactment of the proposed Dairy Produce Act 1986 and the other related legislation.

Clause 10 is necessary to correct a typographical error in the Dairy Produce Act 1924 that came about when amendments were made to the Act in 1978. This error has only been detected recently and the Act has been administered over the years as it was intended to operate. The effect of the error is to make nonsense of the sub-section of the Act that enables advance payments to be made from the dairy produce export pools. Honourable members will note that the Bill provides that the amendment shall be deemed to have taken effect on 1 July 1978.

The Bill provides for the repeal of the Dairy Produce Act 1924 (as amended) and the Dairy Produce Sales Promotion Act 1958 (as amended). These Acts govern the operation of the Australian Dairy Corporation whose future operation is to be governed by the proposed Dairy Produce Act 1986. The Dairy Produce Act 1924 also provides for export pooling, which it is proposed should be terminated at the end of the current production season on 30 June 1986. The Bill provides for the continuation of those provisions necessary to allow the finalisation of current export pools in the normal way.

The Bill provides for the repeal of the Dairy Industry Assistance Act 1977 and the Dairy Industry Assistance Levy Act 1977. These Acts, which deal essentially with market milk, have never been operative.

The proposed Dairy Produce Act 1986 will provide for the membership of the Australian Dairy Corporation to be reconstituted. It will not be possible for this to be done on 1 July 1986. Consequently this Bill allows for the members of the Corporation who hold office on 30 June 1986 to continue in office until the membership of the Corporation is re-constituted. This is likely to occur on 1 October 1986.

The Bill also provides for current export licences, which are due to expire on 30 June 1986, to continue in force until 30 September 1986. The Australian Dairy Corporation will issue an advice on how licences may be renewed or a new licence issued well before 30 September 1986.
The Bill provides a number of other transitional or consequential measures that should be self-explanatory.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the following message from the House of Representatives:

INTERJECT.PARA: The House of Representatives returns to the Senate the Bill intituled ``A Bill for an Act to amend the `Customs Act 1901', the `Excise Act 1901', the `Spirits Act 1906' and certain other Acts'', and acquaints the Senate that the House of Representatives has agreed to the amendments made by the Senate with consequential amendments, including an amendment of the title, as indicated by the annexed Schedule.
The House of Representatives desires the concurrence of the Senate in the consequential amendments made by the House of Representatives.
That consideration of the Message in Committee of the Whole be made an Order of the Day for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes that Wednesday, 28 May 1986 marks the 25th Anniversary of the foundation of Amnesty International and records its continuing support for Amnesty's efforts in the promotion and protection of human rights.

Amnesty International is 25 years old today. It is appropriate that the Senate mark that anniversary in this way, as the concerns and work of the organisation are no less important today than they were when the movement was founded in London. Beginning from one person's sense of outrage and injustice at the seven years imprisonment of two Portuguese students, Amnesty International has now grown to over 3,400 local groups in 55 countries and individual supporters, members and subscribers number over half a million.

Amnesty's work is not centred on one political view. Despite the varied background of its membership its central concerns have remained the same-to seek the release of all prisoners of conscience, to ensure fair and prompt trials for all political prisoners and to abolish the use of torture and the death penalty. To those ends Amnesty International has established an annual Prisoners of Conscience Week to highlight the plight of those incarcerated and tortured around the world for their political beliefs. Amnesty works by trying to bring the maximum pressure to bear on governments which engage in these practices. The focus has remained on the plight of the individual prisoner.

A world-wide campaign to expose and end the use of torture as a tool of state policy was launched by Amnesty International in April 1984. This coincided with one of the most notable achievements of the United Nations which on Human Rights Day on 10 December 1984, adopted the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. The text was inspired by the 1975 declaration against torture.

As well as its work on securing the release of individual prisoners and its efforts in international organisations such as the United Nation, Amnesty has also tried to help in opposing the return of refugees to countries where they are likely to become prisoners of conscience. It provides relief aid to the families of prisoners. This anniversary of Amnesty International is also an appropriate time to recognise the dedication to Amnesty's aims and work of the late Alan Missen, formerly a senator in this place.

The work and objectives of Amnesty International are fundamental to the progress towards a more free democratic and civilised world. To many the world seems now a frightening place where the plight of the prisoner of conscience is no less than it was 25 years ago. The work of Amnesty International has helped to bring to the world's notice the appalling record of governments around the world in according basic human rights to prisoners of conscience. As a member of Amnesty International I want to mark this anniversary not with any sense of satisfaction among those of us who are members at what has already been achieved, but in the sense that after 25 years, despite great efforts, there is still far to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I support the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) noting the twenty-fifth anniversary of the foundation of Amnesty International and recording the Senate's continuing support for Amnesty's efforts in the promotion and protection of human rights. I do so both as Leader of the Opposition and as a member of Amnesty International. Amnesty has enjoyed very wide support in this Parliament, and the Australian Parliament set a precedent for the rest of the world in the formation of the Parliamentary Amnesty Group. Others around the world have followed or are in the process of following the lead set here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is peculiarly appropriate that politicians should take an interest in the work of Amnesty International because many of the prisoners of conscience with whom Amnesty is concerned have become prisoners because of their practice of politics. In this century it is involvement in the political process that usually gives rise to persecution. Historically, involvement in religion was probably more important in attracting fanatical retribution. Religion continues to provide a fruitful source of persecution in the world today. But in this century politics is probably pre-eminent and we, as practitioners of politics in this very peaceful country, are properly concerned about the fate of our fellows around the world. The record which Amnesty presents us all with reminds us that in a lot of the world transfer of political power is still a matter of the use of force. It is a continuing reminder of the positive values of the democratic system we enjoy in Australia and the relatively high freedom, and freedom from persecution, that we enjoy in this country.

I am grateful that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has referred to Alan Missen's role in Amnesty in this Parliament. It has been a very important role, and I think all of us remember his great zeal whenever an issue of human rights arose anywhere in the world. No one could ever have thought that the passion which he brought to bear on this subject related in any way to the particular creed, colour, religious affiliation or anything else. It was a totally open application of the principle that all individuals are entitled to freedom and to fair treatment.

Nearly half of the 159 members of the United Nations hold prisoners of conscience. Currently, there are reports on the use of torture in more than 60 countries around the world. In more than 50 countries people can be held without trial or charge, and in 34 countries the death penalty continues in force, many for crimes, or so-called crimes, that are politically related. So the work of Amnesty certainly remains ahead of it although a lot has been achieved in its first 25 years. Unfortunately, there seems to be no shortage of people rushing to continue the practices of the past.

The only other thing I wish to say is that Alan Missen's contribution was also a reminder of the contribution of the founder of Amnesty International, and a reminder that a single individual can make substantial changes not only to the lives of those who are immediately involved with him in a family sense and in his community but also to people around the world. I think it is worth remembering that the founder-I am advised by Senator Christopher Puplick who is very heavily involved in this area-was a Catholic lawyer of Jewish descent, born of English and Russian parents who took the first step that resulted in this great international organisation being founded.

One of the least healthy aspects of life in Australia at the moment is that we find people who believe that they cannot change aspects of the system that they think are oppressive or wrong. It is important to remember the contribution of people like Mr Peter Benenson and, more recently, of our colleague Senator Alan Missen. There is no excuse for anybody in our sort of free society to sit back and accept that what is wrong cannot be changed. We are reminded by Amnesty generally that the work of all individuals can contribute to the solution of some of the problems in the world which we find objectionable and often beyond our comprehension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia I support the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and is also supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). I suppose we are in an age when we constantly look to the great technological advances that have been made over recent times. It is unfortunate that in looking at those technological advances we seem to equate them with the advances of civilisation as such, when in reality the opposite is almost true.

SPEECH.PARA: For centuries now people have been denied what we almost flippantly say is their human rights. They have been denied them for many reasons other than for just breaking the law of their land. Even in Australia, where we are almost geographically isolated, we become quite blase about human rights and almost gloss over the fact that in other countries things are not quite as easy as they are in this great country of ours. At this time I think it is quite significant that we have reached this twenty-fifth anniversary and it is a fitting time to remind ourselves-each and everyone of us-of what we take for granted, but more importantly to remind ourselves of the fact that that cannot be taken for granted in many other countries of the world. Both Senator Button and Senator Chaney have alluded to that fact. Not only should we be reminded of it but we should make a conscious effort to do all that we can to bring those situations to an end and to inculcate in people of other nations the fact that we have human rights and that they should not be taken lightly and certainly should not be taken away for the reasons they have been taken away in many countries.

Mention was made of the contribution of former Senator Alan Missen. Those of us who have served in this place over the last few years-in other words at a time when Alan was amongst us-know that many are members of Amnesty International but I think we will always associate in our minds Amnesty with the efforts of our late colleague, Senator Alan Missen. He bore the torch higher than anybody else, if other members of Amnesty would excuse my saying that. I am sure that they will understand. With all our advances civilisation as civilisation has not advanced. Until such time as human rights are recognised right around the world we have a tremendous task ahead of us. In that role I see Amnesty International as the international conscience of us all. Long may it do its work. I hope, as all of us would hope, that in the not too distant future it will not need to do that job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring the enthusiastic support of the Australian Democrats to this motion. Speaking for my Party and as Vice-Chairman of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International, I thank the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, for moving the motion and I thank those honourable senators who have supported it in such warm terms. I think there are very good reasons why this should be an important action and I appreciate greatly, as does the whole of the parliamentary group of Amnesty, the moving of this motion in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty's profile has increased considerably during the 25 years of its existence, especially in more recent years. It makes world news regularly on the matters it brings forward and that happens for a significant reason. Amnesty is perhaps not the only organisation which raises issues of human rights and political prisoners but I think it is the most effective one and is seen as such. It is also seen as non-political, unbiased and as an organisation which goes to consider- able efforts to back up what it says with information which can be justified. That is very important and is a basic reason why Amnesty is attended to when it speaks and is also, of course, an important reason why, as an organisation, it deserves the support of the Senate.

Amnesty is seen by the media throughout the world and the public as a watchdog which has a unique status. Like any other organisation it is just as good as the people who make it up. It is fortunate that it has as members throughout the world, including Australia, many people of considerable integrity and considerable idealism, who are deeply dedicated to the ideals of personal freedom and who are prepared to back up those thoughts and ideals with some kind of action. It is also important that an organisation such as Amnesty needs to be protected from the influences that undoubtedly seek to suppress or to silence it. That was the main theme I wanted to mention briefly at this time.

Political persecution flourishes in an atmosphere of secrecy which is indeed necessary to it. Individual citizens of any country have been placed in situations in which they lose all real freedoms when that secrecy is allowed to flourish. It makes it too easy for authority to oppress, to destroy and to break down individual efforts, as we know from many celebrated cases that have come up over the years. It is interesting to look back and to see how many of those cases which became world news were brought to the attention of the world by Amnesty. As has always been the case, as one goes back through history, governments have chosen to break dissidents on the wheel and to break them secretly.

With the development during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries of the ideals of democracy and of individual human rights, there seemed promise of a new era in the world that would assert the importance of individual freedoms and make them paramount. Unfortunately, that has not been the case. As Senator Chaney said, the world's record now is appalling and is not getting any better. It has become just too easy for authoritarian governments to decide to push their point of view and suppress any dissenting point of view by imprisoning people, by torturing them and by doing it in secrecy.

It is worth going back to the basic truism that progress can come only through dissent. If one were to quell any kind of dissent and shut it up so that only one point of view prevails, one would have societies that wither on the vine, become less effective and, worst of all, become dedicated in the course of ordinary human nature to the preservation of and increase in the privileges and wealth of small elite groups rather than of whole communities. So dissent in any society, as we in this place recognise only too well, is absolutely essential.

There is much evidence that the letters and publicity generated by Amnesty, which perhaps in themselves seem small things, have a remarkable effect. Of course, these actions are organised to help political prisoners and their families in a number of countries. I have a feeling that those who persecute others in the conditions of secrecy that we deplore so much want desperately to preserve that secrecy. They do not want to be exposed as torturers. They do not want their brutality to be known to the rest of the world. In brief, I think that they are ashamed of it and I give them credit for that.

In saying that, I raise another very ugly spectre. I do not believe that torture, brutality and false imprisonment are sponsored by monsters, by creatures who are not really human beings but who live sadistically for brutality. If that were so, the world would be a much simpler place than it is. But that is not so. I believe that torture is probably a profession-there is some evidence of this-carried out by people who go home at night to their wives and families and eat a healthy dinner. If that is the case, the need for Amnesty and its support becomes even more urgent. Therefore, there should be public exposure of these people and of the evils they inflict or sponsor.

Of course, if one follows that line of thought, the key point is the word `sponsor'. There again, I suspect that in many countries where there are gross abuses of human rights, where there is torture and imprisonment of political dissenters, those who have overt political power tend not to notice it. It is too easy for them to think that it is a dreadful, appalling thing that is going on in their society but to say: `I will just duck out on it, walk around it and not really know anything about it'.

As we know from the years in nazi Germany and the dictatorships in Europe and other places, many people who lived through those societies felt that they had no involvement whatsoever in what was going on. Indeed, they were quite comfortable to have no knowledge of what went on. Again, that is a good reason for Amnesty to act, being as it is in a position to bring to the clear light of day and to expose, in whatever countries these abuses occur, the fact that those things are occuring and to nail home to those people who exercise overt political power in those countries the fact that they are responsible directly for those actions. I believe that, once that responsibility is brought home to them, they will look at it. I believe that that is why the actions of Amnesty and the publicity generated by the letters that Amnesty writes to governments have such an effect. They do have a very considerable effect.

My final point is perhaps the most important one and bears directly on this motion. Amnesty is an organisation that many people would like to shut up or suppress. There is no doubt about that. It flies directly in the face of the deliberate of perhaps non-deliberate actions of many governments in almost half of the world, as Senator Chaney has said, which use brutality and secrecy to suppress their people. On that basis, it is vitally important that this motion that the Senate records its continuing support for Amnesty's efforts be passed. It is of incalculable value that it was moved in the first place. I ask all honourable senators to support it, as I am sure in good conscience they can and will. On that basis, I commend it to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmatve.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Department of Special Minister of State

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Estimates for the Department of Resources and Energy, because debate in the Estimates Committees in recent weeks has shown that the Government has failed to understand the central nature of safeguarding the resources, specifically energy supplies, of this country. I do so also because in the community which at the moment is facing an enormous peril-heading towards a banana republic as the Government says-because of its high costs of production the Government is further aggravating cost structures in Australia. The Government has learned nothing from the oil and energy crisis of the 1970s. It has done the very reverse. It has gone the other way.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1970s three great principles were laid down and certainly were implemented by the Fraser Liberal Government: The first was that one should conserve energy so that one would not run out or be dependent upon imports; the second was that one should convert away from precious energy to other sources; and the third was that exploration and development must be given priority. Running through the whole of the evidence given to the Senate Estimates Committees was the very perversion of those goals. For example, back in the early 1980s a projection of an increase in oil demand throughout Australia was made by the department of the day and it was indicated that we ought to move to increase supplies by about half a per cent a year, or slightly more. Our demand for oil is increasing by just under 2 per cent a year even though our reserves are falling. That compares with the United States of America which is managing, by conservation, to increase demand by, I think, 0.6 per cent.

Whenever we look at the need to conserve energy we find that the reverse is happening. The previous Government as a leader in the field laid down a system whereby government vehicles should be converted to liquefied petroleum gas, a simple operation which is cheap and very efficient for commercial vehicles. Not only has the program not gone on; it has gone in a reverse direction. That is ridiculous when one considers the taxi fleets in Canberra, Melbourne and to a lesser extent in Sydney which are efficiently operating with an 80 per cent or 90 per cent use of LPG. Australia has a surplus of LPG and could therefore convert more vehicles to its use. At a time when our oil stocks are declining the Government is doing nothing to be a leader. There was an attempt under the Fraser Government to convert about 3,000 government vehicles a year to LPG-if my memory serves me correctly. The figure that I remember, which may need correction, is that the conversion number is in the hundreds, perhaps 300. That is an absolute nonsense.

The reason that I say these things is not simply to be nit-picking on a department or a government; this country is facing peril, as the Government has said, and it will deteriorate into a Third World position unless we are very careful-into a banana republic, as the Government has said. A government which knows that anything which imperils our cost of production adds to the dangers has a duty to save costs. Yet the program aimed to preach conversion and conservation throughout industry and to preach it to government departments is at the very most lukewarm. International energy agencies and other bodies have made it clear and nations have proven that we can save 30 per cent of our energy sources, including petroleum energy; we can save not only the precious, scarce and non-renewable fuels but also valuable money.

One would think that running through the whole Department would be an urgency to preach to the Australian people to get costs down. After all, that is the message that needs to be said. The reason that we have a trade deficit is not only the fall in primary product prices and mineral prices but also the fact that our manufacturers at home cannot compete on costs with the flood of imports. If we are to find jobs for the unemployed and overcome Australia's problems we need to get costs down and productivity up. The Department and the Government have the capacity and ability to save by bringing costs down. I have heard nothing and seen nothing of a drive to get a 30 per cent saving by energy conservation.

Australia has a great ability to produce electric power in abundance but we have great cost burdens including overseas debts because of the cost of building power stations. The best way to save capital debts on power stations is to save the necessity of building the next power station; in other words, to use electric energy as best we can. I recall that three or four years ago there was an electricity crisis on the east coast, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria. The crisis was causing blackouts in New South Wales. All that was necessary for the New South Wales Government to maintain electricity supplies to the people was that the installations should be working at 60 per cent capacity. The power stations could not be made to function at that capacity. Maintenance and industrial problems were such that the stations functioned at less than 50 per cent capacity. Snowy Mountains supplies had to be drawn on and there was juggling between States. We now have new power stations at a huge capital cost. The ability in New South Wales to provide power means that it must draw on less than 60 per cent of installed capacity.

Overseas, it is considered good practice to operate at 80 per cent of installed capacity-in other words, capital is being put to work. I see and hear nothing of a clarion call by the Government of the day saying: `Let us get a saving, a conservation, in every way'. It is no good saying: `Oil is cheap, therefore let us use it. We have coal in abundance; let us use it'. They are not the issues. Costs in Australia are keeping 600,000 people out of work and are lowering living standards. One of the greatest paradoxes of our time is that there is industrial protest today about a wage case when we ought to be considering the 600,000 people who are unemployed; not that the haves want to have more so that the numbers of have nots can be increased and have less. This is extraordinary. This is the confrontation society that Charlie Fitzgibbon talks about and that I have talked about. It is an ugly society. Unless governments and Ministers stand up and show the people of Australia a lead in getting costs down, we are in for a very serious situation indeed.

There is no evidence of massive conservation. I am aware of the various plans such as the national industry energy management scheme and other plans which, on paper, sound good. I walk around Canberra at night and see a massive misuse of electric power in buildings. I see that the program that was put into place to try to save energy in government buildings is being given only lip service. Yet we are being told that social security spending must be cut because governments do not have money to back up their obligation to help the poor. This is a monstrosity in itself.

Let us consider the current situation. We have been exporting our oil. Why have we been doing so? It is not because we have a surplus but because the balance of payments is in such a desperately poor state that we are willing to sell our precious oil, which we will run out of, at whatever price we can get overseas, just to try to palliate the balance of payments. Yet the Government has said that by 1991-these are government figures-Bass Strait oil production will fall by half, that is, it will fall from 400,000-odd barrels a day to 200,000-odd barrels. The Government has predicted that towards the end of the century Australia will need something like 900,000 barrels a day or more. In other words, the Government is saying that, whereas today, with some 400,000 to 440,000 barrels of oil a day, Australia is relatively self-sufficient at the light end of the barrel and needs to import only at the heavier end, eventually we will be in utter peril and will have a very serious shortage of the light end of the barrel. We will have to do one of two things. Either we will have to go without and experience the same kind of crisis as was experienced in the 1970s by other countries or we will have to import oil at a cost of billions of dollars.

The nonsense of it is that the Government has before it a table which shows that, unless it does something drastic in terms of exploration in Australia, exploration will fall away. That is not a prediction by some outside interest but a prediction by the Government. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing predictions by the Bureau of Mineral Resources regarding the number of exploration and development wells-a table which I think the Government has seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us attempt to understand the nature of this crisis. The BMR estimated in January that in 1986 the number of on-shore exploration wells would be 206. In March it modified that estimate to 130. Last year the number of on-shore exploration wells was 226. The BMR estimated in January 1986 that the number of off-shore exploration wells for 1986 would be 32. In March it modified the figure to 28. Last year's figure was 43. If one goes through the table, whether one takes the number of exploration wells, the number of development wells or the total number of wells, one finds that the estimate now is that this year we will have virtually half the activity of the previous year. The BMR's March estimate for the total number of on-shore wells was 159 on-shore wells compared with 301 wells last year. Its March estimate for the total number of off-shore wells was 49 compared with last year's figure of 60. The grand total is 208, the March estimate, compared with 361, last year's figure.

SPEECH.PARA: So it goes on-a picture of potential crisis. Yet nothing at all has come forward from this Government to increase exploration and development as a matter of policy. That in itself is an outrage. Although we have a balance of payments problem now, consider the balance of payments problem Australia would have if in five years time we needed to import oil, the very oil we have exported. The Minister will probably tell us that really it adds up to only six months supply or something like that-a lovely kind of euphemism. If my figures are right, we will be down on our knees praying to save our overseas balances. Because of the need to conserve, but primarily because of the need to reduce costs and employ people, the Department of Resources and Energy, its Minister, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), and the Government must concentrate on conservation, conversion and exploration and, above all, on saving costs wherever costs can be saved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Sir John Carrick canvassed a great many matters in his remarks. We could have a very long debate on those issues, but let me just make a few short points in reply, not least because that is all I think I am physically capable of at the moment.
—Perhaps we could have a statement by you at some other stage. A written statement would be handy.

—I make it clear that the Government has embarked upon the Energy 2000 exercise, which has produced a series of 10 discussion papers analysing all aspects of the Australian energy scene as we see it, both in the present day and through to the end of the century, in which exercise a lot of emphasis was given-I think quite properly, as Senator Sir John Carrick emphasised-to conservation issues. It is the Government's intention to follow up those discussion papers with a major conference, at which all interested-State and private sector, governmental and political interests-will be represented and to follow that up in turn with a major government statement at the end of the year or perhaps early next year.

SPEECH.PARA: That kind of exercise is a response-a very genuine response-by me and by the Government to the kinds of concerns which Senator Sir John Carrick has articulated. Many shorter term responses will need to be made and are being made. I will be making an announcement later today about a further import parity price adjustment because we recognise the need to maximise returns to on-shore producers in order, in turn, to keep exploration incentives going. Many shorter term policy responses of this kind will have to go on being made, but the important thing is to maintain our sense of bearing and direction as to the overall energy scene.

I readily acknowledge that we must not be led by the prevailing massive slump in world oil prices into any sense of apathy about the need not only to find new liquid fuel resources in this country but also to conserve very vigorously what we have. Whatever the overall situation may be in the world at large, the reality is that in Australia we face a situation of declining self-sufficiency as a result of Bass Strait drying up over the next few years. The predictions, as Senator Sir John Carrick indicated-although there is also predicted by the Bureau of Mineral Resources, at reasonable levels of probability, a self-sufficiency situation which is not quite as grim as Senator Sir John Carrick makes out-are that if we do not discover any new oil at all we will be down to self-sufficiencies of the order of 42 per cent by the early 1990s; but there is a 50 per cent probability at least of that self-sufficiency being in the 60 to 70 per cent range by that period and at least of around 50 per cent by the end of the century. But it is important, I readily acknowledge, to maintain exploration activity and exploration incentives.

The Government has been looking very carefully indeed at what incentives it might be possible to give. A paper published just a couple of weeks ago addressed all these issues in the context of the short term problems of the present producers and the present, in particular, on-shore exploration scene. We very carefully weighed the possibility of providing tax incentives or tax breaks of one kind or another and various other ways of giving a boost to the industry, with results that I have announced and given reasoned justification for. I do not think much more is to be gained by swapping rhetorical barrages on this occasion. I simply make it clear that I acknowledge the force of the point that has been made and indicate that the Government has the policy issues involved well and truly in hand.

A couple of other specific matters deserve some mention. As to conservation measures in particular, I do not think the Government's continued commitment to the national energy management program or the national energy awards under the national industry energy management scheme and so on should be dismissed quite as lightly as Senator Sir John Carrick did. We have maintained spending in real terms on those programs, notwithstanding quite a lot of pressure to reduce the spending on those programs by others in the Government who have taken a more short-sighted view as to the need to maintain them in a lower cost energy environment. New conservation initiatives have been taken in the past few months, with the five star building rating program, to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has actively and visibly lent his name and reputation. There has been the gas appliance fuel efficiency labelling exercise, in which I was involved very publicly a few months ago. There is a continued emphasis on appliance labelling, which is a matter of State reaction now being discussed and implemented through the Australian Minerals and Energy Council. There is continued emphasis on vehicle fuel consumption efficiency and the continued publication of the fuel guides by my Department, notwithstanding some very unfortunately sceptical and cynical responses by some motoring journalists earlier this year to that publication. There has been a continued willingness to devote research resources to energy conservation issues and a continued attempt, not always completely successful, to urge energy efficiency and economy measures upon those departments within the Government's jurisdiction.

I readily acknowledge Senator Sir John Carrick's complaint about lights being on in the evenings in buildings around Canberra. It is a complaint regularly made by me. I am told that it is largely a fault of the switchings and installations that were put in in an era of much less energy consciousness than we have now. Slowly we are hoping to convert some of those buildings. The difficulty is always to find the seed money up front to produce savings down the back. Senator Sir John Carrick would be well aware from his occupancy of this portfolio how difficult some of these things can be. I make the point that we are not ignorant or indifferent to these considerations; we are simply governed by practical constraints which afflict any government.
