Finally, on the subject of oil exports, it is the case that the Government is happy to see oil being exported at the moment from Bass Strait, in particular as a method of alleviating our very difficult continuing balance of payments situation. With that in mind, to offer some incentive for such exports to take place, we announced a couple of weeks ago an increase in the excise rebate for such exports with results that, notwithstanding the initial reaction from the industry, I think will bear fruit in the months ahead. The arithmetic does add up and offers some incentive for exports to take place; whether at the rate achieved last year remains to be seen.

It is the case that any export of indigenous oil involves a depletion of our resources at a faster rate than would be the case if we were not exporting it. That is perfectly true, but two factors need to be borne in mind. The first factor is the question of relative volumes to which Senator Sir John Carrick adverted. It is the case that even exporting at the very high rate that was accomplished all through calendar year 1985, at the end of the day that amounted to less than six months call on our reserves. I think that point ought to be frankly acknowledged and the decision made, as it has been by the Government, as to whether it is better on the whole to save up those six months worth of reserves for some uncertain future when the balance of payments situation confronting the country might be worse than it is today, but then again might well be substantially better, or whether it is appropriate and sensible to take advantage of the market opportunities that exist and put that oil out into the market.

The Government came down on the side of the latter approach because of the second consideration which is always relevant here; that is, the question of encouraging exploration activity as a result both of giving to the producers an increased cash flow and a great capacity, accordingly, to pour money back into exploration and also encouraging an environment in which those minded to explore will know that they will not be constrained by government policy from taking market advantage of that. This is particularly important in the context of the North West Shelf. It was important to the development by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd of the Jabiru field that it was given undertakings by the Government that it would be able to export the oil in question.

Complicated questions of national interest balancing are involved in judgments of this kind. It is not simply a crude matter of saying that we have just this particular bucket of oil in existence which is absolutely finite and will not be added to, and that any taking of a cup out of that bucket for other than domestic use is, for that reason, a wrong thing to do. A much more dynamic situation than that operates in this particular exploration and production area and governments have to make judgments about what combination of policies offer the best return to the nation as a whole, given its overall economic situation at the time and which offer the best package of incentives to oil industry people to get out and find the liquid fuel resources that the country so obviously needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). I point out that I am well aware of the publication `Energy 2000'; indeed some of the figures I quoted were from that publication. I do not argue that the diagnosis is not on paper; the diagnosis has been put on paper by both the Fraser and Hawke governments. My point in rising is to say that, knowing the diagnosis, there is no vigorous attempt to cure. Indeed, no voice is being heard. I know of no message in terms of clarion calls to the people of Australia to tell them what is happening and to seek their help in conservation and conversion.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to examine what the Minister has said. He has said that it is a difficult situation to decide whether to export oil to help the balance of payments now or to keep it in the ground for the future. Two things need to be said about that. Exporting oil at a time when Australia is getting a relatively low return because of low oil prices in this world is unfair to the Australian people by not giving them value for one of their most precious and non-renewable resources. If Senator Walsh were here and he had a monetary lapse of good humour, he would be talking of replacement costs, resource rentals and the inherent value that ought to be given to the people. That is not happening at the moment.

The Minister has said, I acknowledge, that the prediction is that unless we get very substantial new finds, our oil sufficiency now, which in terms of the lighter grades-not the heavier, not the bitumen or fuel oil grades in the petroleums-in one sense is of total sufficiency, but in an ordinary measurement is 75 per cent or maybe a little higher, will fall to 41 per cent by 1991 or 1992. Then the Minister said that the Bureau of Mineral Resources has said that there is a 50 per cent chance that it might not be as bad as that. Nobody can lead this country into the next five years on the basis that we have a 50 per cent chance that it might not be as bad as 41 per cent.

Let me tell the Committee what 41 per cent is. The other day the erstwhile world's best Treasurer, now of a Third World country, said that the balance of trade was a perilous thing and would lead us into all sorts of dire circumstances. If we fall to a 41 per cent level in 1991 and we need to import 30-odd per cent even to reach our present self-sufficiency level, we will have to find $3 billion to $4 billion, depending on the price of oil at the time-$3 billion to $4 billion at a time when we are arguing about a deficit increase of $1.4 billion which has put us into an ulcerous state. What a nonsense situation it is that we can be feeling happy, complacent, about the fact that we have a 50-50 chance of dropping to a level of 41 per cent in 1991. Nobody believes it will be 50 per cent or 60 per cent. The BMR itself would indicate that we will have a disastrous fall in our capacity to supply the light end of the barrel. Therefore, by 1991 we will have either to import oil at a very high price and so completely distort the balance of payments again or we will have to go without oil.

There are a dozen different ways to overcome this problem. The Minister-with great respect to his laryngitis; I am sorry for that-did not address himself to any. For example, nothing has been done about using liquefied petroleum gas-a logical solution which is in the Minister's own hands. In fact, the reverse is the case. The Government could convert substantially the Commonwealth fleet, including post office vehicles and all those vehicles that do long miles. After all, his Department is full of documentation about the good sense of doing that. Instead, the Minister has that policy in reverse gear. But have I heard another important thing? Have I heard any statement by the Government or the Minister about the quite exciting New Zealand development in which Australia was something of an informal partner, peeping over the shoulder of the Maui Mobil gas development? Have I heard at all what has been happening? If that project does have some disabilities, we ought to be told, because although it looks as though Australia will run short of oil, it does not look as though we will run short of natural gas for at least some decades. At the very worst, we can run automotive vehicles on natural gas. We can convert natural gas into methanol and run vehicles on that, or mix it with petrol, or we can convert natural gas to petroleum and run vehicles on that. Whatever the cost may be-we have had no statement on this-the public of Australia is entitled to know where such proposals stand in regard to this 41 per cent self-sufficiency level in 1991.

We are in an incredible situation. Australia is one of a handful of countries on earth-I said this yesterday-that have massive physical resources of minerals and a massive capacity to generate electricity in an unlimited way and to combine those capacities. We need to be sure we can turn the wheels, that we have the automotive power to do so. Nothing is appearing in print or in public statements to suggest any kind of urgency on this at all.

Fundamentally, I rose today to expouse a point to which the Minister did not direct himself. The real crisis in Australia is the cost of production. We have been talking about the symptoms, such as the balance of trade and government overspending. The real problem is that our costs are too high. What is the Department of Resources and Energy doing to get costs down? What is being done by way of a crash course in conservation, a crash course in conversion? These kinds of things are fundamental to getting jobs for people. Australia is able to produce virtually all the electrical power it needs. We know that the whole of the crisis of the 1970s occurred in other countries because they could not do that, because they had to import the means of generating electric power. Yet we cannot, with the cheapest coal we can get from our open cut mines, with power stations on site at the coal mines and with none of the pollution problems of the rest of the world or the need to cart coal across the world, use that electric power economically to compete with the rest of the world.

There is something drastically wrong with a country, and something drastically wrong with the elements of government, if here in Australia, with an abundance of electric power stations-as I have said, an oversupply of installed capacity-we cannot hook manufacturing on to the end of it. There is something wrong when we cannot take the minerals and process them, or struggle to do so. Yesterday I referred to the fact that Australia ships iron ore-50 per cent of it just common dirt-to Japan in one lot of ships and coal in another lot of ships, and Japan puts it through its steel mills, rolls it out in flat plate and sends it back to Australia for us to make motor cars out of it. The steel is cheaper than we can make it in Australia. There is something terribly wrong with Australia in that regard. We have the physical resources but we do not have the direction, the drive and the will to do it.

I have pointed out that we export more than 50 per cent of the world's exported alumina. We are in fact God-given in our supply of bauxite, which we turn into alumina, and yet we struggled hard for years to get the Portland alumina plant going. With all the brown coal capacity in the world, we struggled hard to turn alumina into the base metal when at whatever price it is today-say $1,000 or $1,300 a tonne-it could be out there, up front, in a normal projection, altering the balance of trade completely. The capacity for Australia to increase its production of the smelted metal, aluminium, and export that metal could in itself do as much as almost anything to overcome our balance of trade problem.

The whole purpose of saying what I am saying is to indicate that there appears to be no urgency about this; there is no directionalism, no telling the Australian people that the costs of production are the killers. In every way the Government is saying it will fix it with consumer price indexes, M3s and balances of payments or by trimming something off here or there. The fact of the matter is that we cannot do that at all. The only way that Australia will be able to employ people and maintain living standards is to get productivity up and costs down. We can do that without savaging the worker; we can do it by the worker and the employer co-operating.

The Minister pointed out that he had put out a paper entitled `Energy 2000'. I quoted from it. In fact, that paper foresees the possibility that oil consumption in Australia could skyrocket from the present 613,000 barrels a day to as high as 980,000 barrels a day by the turn of the century, although it estimates a little more conservatively that it will be nearer 800,000 barrels a day. It was that paper that said that Bass Strait production, which now provides more than 80 per cent of our present domestic output, will halve by 1991. But what did the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association have to say a few days ago on this whole matter? I quote from the speech of its Executive Director, Mr Orchison:
Oil demand in Australia from now to 2000 is likely to be 3.7 billion barrels.
Despite record exploration activity since 1981, crude oil and condensate reserves fell over the past five years from two billion barrels to little more than 1.7 billion barrels.
More than 4,000 wildcat exploration wells and many hundreds of appraisal wells will need to be drilled over the next 15 years, but our oil search is collapsing in the wake of the fall in prices.
He goes on, far more importantly, to talk about the fact that we are facing the reverse face of the oil crisis of the 1970s. He said this:
A re-run of the OPEC-dominated events of 1973 and 1979 is a factual possibility-with almost 60 percent of the free world's oil reserves in four countries: Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq and Iran.

I wonder whether the Minister and his Government saw an article in yesterday's papers where Sheik Yamani was reported as saying that he thought that in a decade or so those countries would be providing something like 75 per cent of the free world's demand for oil. I think we have excellent relationships with Sheik Yamani and Saudi Arabia. I think he is a very civilised man but I do not think any country in the free world should put itself into a bind. I simply rise to point out the dangers we are moving into, both for Australia and for the world, if we are complacent and think that because there is an oil glut today and we have no crisis we can waste the oil, and do not need to convert. We cannot just go ahead and think: `She'll be right, mate; a string of promises in a Budget will fix it'. That is not what will fix it. Only by co-operation between management workers and the Government in terms of increased productivity will we solve our problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a point that came up in the Estimates Committee which dealt with the Department of the Special Minister of State for the provision of office word processors in the electorate offices of senators and members. Some while ago a decision was taken by the Department of the Senate to provide personal computers in the offices we have here in Parliament House. A Digital decmate 3 is in the process of being provided to all honourable senators and, I believe, to honourable members as well. Through the Estimates Committee I made an inquiry of a witness as to when the same sort of word processing capability would be provided in our electorate offices. I was told that the equipment was out for tender and that the aim of the Department was to maximise Australian industry participation in this program.

SPEECH.PARA: I am all in favour of supporting Australian industry. I think that is common sense, particularly when we have the acute trading account difficulties that we have. The facts of the matter are that a decision was made to put a certain word processor into our Parliament offices. I do not know what the capital investment would be but it would be well in excess of $1,500,000. Not only have we bought those computers and installed them in this Parliament House but also we have made a very big investment in staff training. We all have three staff members and the training program for that computer course, in its various stages, would probably extend over eight to 10 days per person. In man hours involved we have a very big capital investment in training our staff to use the equipment. On further questioning, as reported on page 129 of the Hansard of the Senate Estimates Committee E on 10 April 1986, the witness said that in the tender specifications that had gone on to industry:
. . . industry will be asked to respond on three levels of compatibility to ensure that we can optimise the support and training between the two systems.

It is quite clear that the Department is considering providing a system other than the system we have. I think that is just economic and managerial madness. We have to have the same system in our electorate offices as we already have in Parliament House. We cannot have incompatibility. We cannot have records on floppy disks or files that cannot be brought down from our electorate offices and put on a machine in our Canberra offices. In the fullness of time, we cannot have machines in our electorate offices that will not talk and link up electronically with the systems we have here. Above all, we cannot have two different training schedules for our staffs. It is just a nonsense to go down that path. I bring this to the attention of the Committee because most people are not aware that the Department of Administrative Services is looking at an entirely different system from the system we have in place at present. I think the system we have is a good system. It is probably the best system that is available at present. It is a modern generation word processing system and I think we have no alternative but to put the same system into the electorate offices of senators and members and if we want to go to a different system we should do so in the next generation-in 10 or 15 years time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — As was said by the departmental witness in the Estimates hearing, the Department of the Special Minister of State is aware of the need for systems being installed in electorate offices to be compatible with those in Parliament House. In the tenders that are now out and about, the Department is seeking to ensure a level of compatibility that may be not total but certainly is commensurate with the user requirement on the one hand and on the other hand the Government's objective of Australian industry participation. The levels of compatibility that are perceived as being necessary are first of all information interchange-that is to say, the transfer of data by diskettes-and, secondly, systems appearance to users, which is the functional interface of the keyboard, its layout, its features and so on such as the word processing software which enables migration to and from systems in electorate offices and in Parliament House. Again, the word processing system installed in the electorate office system must have a high level of compatibility with the most frequently used features of the Parliament House word processing software.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an intention in the way in which the tender documents are framed and the way in which the exercise has been progressed to ensure the maximum possible degree of compatibility. To ensure absolute identity of systems in the way that Senator MacGibbon is insisting would be to ignore the requirement that I think most of us in this place would agree with, that is, to absolutely maximise Australian industry participation in this exercise.

There has been consultation with parliamentary officers about this. I am advised that the Secretary of the Department and the President of the Senate (Senator Douglas McClelland) have had discussions concerning information systems and the President has expressed on all our behalfs his satisfaction with the way things are going and the level of consultation. Officers of both the Department of the Senate and the Department of the House of Representatives reviewed the specifications of the tender prior to its release as to its coverage of the compatibility issues in the way I just mentioned. The Department of the Senate advised verbally that it was satisfied with the contents of the document and had no problems with its release.

TALK.START.PARA: —Orally.

—The Department of the House of Representatives advised-I acknowledge the interjection `orally'; pedants of the world unite-in a letter of 30 April that the document gave `appropriate consideration to the overriding compatibility requirement'. I think those various considerations do answer the points that Senator MacGibbon has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a matter in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs. In division 315, subdivision 4, item 04, there is an increased expenditure of $2m for the administration of the United Nations-the parent body and not one of its agencies. I would like to raise a matter of caution here for the Australian Government. I refer to the evidence given at page 137 of the Hansard of Estimates Committee E of 10 April 1986-that since 1974 the United States of America has paid 25 per cent of the budget of the United Nations and its specialised agencies, but the Kassebaum Amendment laid down that a ceiling of 20 per cent should be placed on the budget contribution from the United States. Given the size of the United Nations budget that 5 per cent is a very significant reduction. The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act, which commits the United States legislature to balancing its budget by 1991, starts to operate this financial year. That will effectively reduce the 20 per cent figure to an even lower figure as all expenditures of the United States Government are cut back. From the discussion the Committee had with the witness I was not convinced that the Government was aware of the risk that exists in Australia being asked, along with all the other contributors, to make up the shortfall of the contribution by the United States to the budget of the United Nations.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a supporter of the United Nations. I have grave reservations about some of its agencies, particularly the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation which clearly can only be disciplined by not being funded for some years to bring it back to the path on which it was founded. It has strayed very far from that and it is not overstating the case to say that there is good evidence of corruption in the way that some of its funds have been administered under its present Director. But since from now on the United States of America and some European powers will not fund UNESCO, it will be funded out of the United Nations central budget. Demands on the central budget will rise and the United States contribution will fall significantly. I believe that the Australian Government is not fully aware of the liability we have in this direction and I do not believe that liability should be met. Although I am a supporter of the United Nations and had the privilege of serving as parliamentary adviser there three years ago for three months, the organisation has a great deal of inefficiency and kidney fat within it and need some financial discipline imposed on it. I ask the Australian Government not to consider requests for increased funding for the United Nations in the foreseeable future until it puts it affairs in order.

TALK.START.PARA: — The only response I can make is that the United Nations is still debating its budget at the moment. The situation has not changed from that which was outlined by Mr Mott, from the Department of Foreign Affairs, in the Estimates Committee hearing on 10 April. As for Senator MacGibbon's policy prescriptions for the Government, we will take them on board and give them such weight as we think they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return briefly to the subject of oil energy. One of the fundamental ingredients in the costs of production today-and costs of production are the evil that is keeping us out of world markets and keeping our unemployed in that state-is the cost of freight flowing from the cost of fuel. What has been happening in the cost of fuel has been that the Government, which first was utterly abusive of import parity pricing and said that it was simply a tax office at every bowser, has not only embraced it but learnt to add more tricks to it. The Government has gone further than that. It has done something which I do not think ordinary people in the community understand. It has taken the excise factor of the price of a litre of petrol and indexed it to inflation. It is not necessary in any Budget for the Government to indicate to the public that it is putting up the excise, increasing the price of petrol. This happens automatically.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Keating), the most vituperchative opponent of import parity pricing and of what he called the unduly high price of petrol, has done better than that. He has raised the price more and more. He is the man who is alleged to be right, but has never yet got one of his policies through. He has failed at tax summits and failed at everything he has done. He now should be put in perspective as the man who has completely reversed, done a double somersault, and we now have not just the tax commissioner but a tax investigator at every bowser.

Let us have a little look at what is happening. The Australian Automobile Association in Victoria did an analysis of what happens at the petrol pump and who gets what share. It is interesting to see that for every litre of petrol bought at the petrol pump in Victoria the Government takes 53.11 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is more than half.

—Yes, more than half. Let us look not only at that 53 per cent but also at what is happening and what is likely to happen. If one takes a litre of petrol in Victoria, at 52.5c, which includes a Victorian Government franchise fee which may vary, it is indicated that out of that sum the retailer gets 4.2c-not a very big amount. The oil company, with its storage and distribution, gets 11.2c. Incredibly, the oil producer, whom one would think would get a large amount, gets 5.1c-or 10 per cent. But what about the Federal Government? The Federal Government gets excise duty of 15.8c, crude oil levy 11.4c, royalties 0.7c. It gets 27.9c out of 52.5c, and the Victorian Government comes along and takes 4.1c in royalties. The important thing to look at in percentage terms is that of the Federal Government's 53 per cent, excise duty is now 30.1 per cent. I predict, sadly, that it will go up and up, as indeed the crude oil levy goes down, unless the Government can find some other means.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that the Treasurer, having failed once again at the tax summit to get his option C involving a broad based indirect tax, is getting a broad based indirect tax by stealth and creep through the excise duty at the petrol pump, and so that is rising. The Government says: `We have got to have revenue'. The Minister says, `We cannot give you all the advantages of the overseas fall in oil', although, in Opposition, every day the voices of the Australian Labor Party here were raised saying, `Give us every cent of the drop in price'. But now the Labor Government says: `No we cannot do that because we need the money'. Why does it need the money? It forgot to tell us that in its first Budget it increased expenditure by a couple of billion dollars so, to pay for its expenditure, the people have to suffer by not getting this amount. We are seeing here a built-in cash register for the Government-steadily, steadily, by indexing of inflation which is running at 9.2 per cent at present. Up it will go and the Government will shift the burden so that government revenue is steadily increased. We will get that kind of broad based indirect tax there.

That in itself would be just a breach of faith, one of the Government's broken promises by the dozen, if it were not more serious. What is more serious is that we are facing a crisis in costs of production. Above everything, the farm community is facing an enormous crisis with falling overseas prices and rising costs in Australia. The big costs to the farming community are freight. The Government has made some petty gesture of on-farm discounting of fuel-a fiddling thing in itself. The real cost of freight is in every kind of commodity that moves to and from the farm.

The Government had the chance in Australia to reduce the consumer price index by at least another one per cent if it had given the full fall of overseas prices. In fact it elected not to do that. It elected to put on an excise and therefore to increase costs of production-to do the very reverse of what should be done. This should be understood by the Australian people. It is no good a government saying `We need the money'. A government which is a big spender, which year by year has increased its expenditure by more than the average 2 per cent of the Fraser Government-which was the lowest spending government for many years-has to look to the waste of its expenditure before it starts to put costs on people. It is crazy to punish people by indirect taxation for the Government's own inadequacies and mismanagement. That is what is happening at present, bit by bit.

In the area of fringe benefits the Government is seeking to pretend that it will force the wicked employers who incur its class hatred-they are set up as an Aunt Sally which the left wing has to knock down all the time because it needs confrontation as its role-to pay for a benefit of the employee. In the long run it will be passed on through the cost of production to everybody in the community. So we hear all the rhetoric to the effect that a handful of 10 to 20 per cent are getting fringe benefits and 90 per cent are not and that we should weep about that. What is happening now is a skilful arrangement between the Australian Democrats and the Government-a complete piece of trickery in itself-which will, in the end, cause the tax to be passed on to the ordinary people, the pensioners, to everybody else. It is a very comforting device for the Government; a device which means that by a deferral of taxation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Indebted as we are to Senator Sir John Carrick for ranging at large over a number of issues, I suggest that he be drawn back to the topic of this debate.

—Mr Chairman, I would like to speak to the point of order. My point was that the price of fuel and the price of freight was such a heavy ingredient in taxation that it is exacerbating the cost of production today, and that the Government was not focusing on the real error-the cost of production. I am delighted that the point of order was raised because it gives me a chance to repeat my point that an indirect tax on the petrol pump was doing exactly this. I pointed out that this was in parallel to what is happening in the proposal for fringe benefits. Rather than wandering at large we are at the petrol pump, we are at the indirect tax, we are at the insidious means of transferring to the ordinary person a cost. I put it to you, Mr Chairman, that there is no point of order.

—There is no point of order. These debates traditionally have been wide-ranging. The Department under review is the Department of Resources and Energy and Senator Sir John Carrick's remarks are relevant in regard to resources and energy. He may link them, if he wishes, to the fringe benefits tax but not too much.

—I will endeavour to observe your ruling, Mr Chairman. The fact is that the whole of my remarks is aimed at the increased costs of production. The whole of my remarks is aimed at the fact that the more burdens the Government puts on the taxpayer, the more costs go up. If the Government defers taxation for two months, in the short term it will help the Government to get its deficit in place for August this year, but it plays a dirty trick because it puts up taxes to the ordinary person, and in the end all this becomes an extra burden. So what looks like a nice little arrangement is, in fact, an attack once again on ordinary people.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the failure of the Government to observe import parity pricing-which was its stated policy-and the action of the Government to involve an excise which is now indexed, and which is creeping up and up, are contributing very significantly to the unemployment we have in Australia today and to the very grave disability of farmers and miners. It is dishonest because it is a series of broken promises. The Government promised to pass on these prices. I simply say that every time someone goes to the tax bowser-Mr Keating may join me in this because he was a most ardent proponent of this before-he will observe that this Government has learnt more tricks about how to put the Tax Commissioner at the tax bowser than any previous Government, and that the excise duty itself, ticking away, will rise and rise and will exacerbate costs and will exacerbate unemployment. It is within the capacity of this Government to have reduced the consumer price index by one per cent which would be in itself an enormously important thing and it would have overcome quite a few of the difficulties. It failed to do so. It went on its way simply because a socialist government wants to grab money. It does not understand that its job is to get off the backs of people and let them have a fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Sir John Carrick for raising the whole question of indirect taxation of fuel because it enables me to put on the record some facts about Australia's performance in this respect, comparatively speaking, which are not well understood, not well appreciated, and not often acknowledged. The reality is that not only are overall petrol prices in Australia lower than all but two other comparable countries, namely the United States and Canada, but also the Australian level of indirect taxation-that is to say product excise tax on petrol-as a proportion of total price compares very favourably indeed with other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. The taxation component in the Australian retail price of petrol is currently 43 per cent. This compares with an OECD average of around 52 per cent on the basis of the latest information available to my department.
—What is it in the United States?

—I am happy to say that in the United States it is a little lower than Australia. It is true that in the United States product tax is only 22 per cent. In New Zealand it is less than ours. In Canada it is less than ours. In Japan it is a little less at 40 per cent, but that is against a background of a petrol price of $A1.10 per litre. But every other country in the OECD has a higher rate than Australia's 43 per cent. The average, as I said, is 52 per cent. For example in France, the taxation component is 87 per cent; in Italy it is 78 per cent; in the United Kingdom it is 66 per cent. To complete the list, in the Netherlands it is 65 per cent; in Germany it is 63 per cent; in Greece it is 60 per cent; in Austria it is 55 per cent, and in Spain it is 44 per cent. Comparatively speaking, Australia is a middle to light ranging taxing nation so far as petroleum prices are concerned. The percentage is one thing and the total price of the product at the end of the day is the other consideration. As I indicated, in terms of total price, the Australian product is right down there at the bottom of the scale, jogging along with Canada and the United States. The prices on which these figures are calculated are 49 cents per litre in Australia; at the moment 46 cents in Canada; and 40 cents per litre in the United States. So Australian petrol prices have been kept much lower than could have been the case had we not chosen to keep product excise levels at a moderate level.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the case, as Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out that, since the decline in world oil prices which as a consequence of our import parity pricing policy led to a substantial reduction in the price of indigenous Australian crude oil which in turn led to a massive drop in crude oil excise revenue, in response to that and to that revenue decline we have imposed in recent months compensating product excise increases-not as to the whole amount in each case of the lost crude revenue; back in March it was only a partial recoupment-which cost the Government out of the Budget in the coming financial year something over $400m. That was a deliberate attempt by the Government to inject some competitive advantage into the economy, to reduce the consumer price index below that which would otherwise be the case, and to give the consumer and the economy as a whole some fillip from that. But the reality is, as was explained at the time, it is simply impossible, with a price effect such as this coming pretty much out of the blue certainly as to its scale and as to the time frame within which it occurred, for any government to cope with revenue losses of that order of magnitude. As a result we have imposed significant compensating excise increases. But we have not been alone in doing that, and that point also needs to be acknowledged. The United Kingdom Government, the ideological shrine at which the Opposition worships, has in fact increased petroleum product excise by a quite substantial amount in its recent Budget. So too has Italy, Denmark, Spain and Switzerland. Each of those countries have imposed recent product excise increases to compensate their Treasuries for the lower returns they were getting as a result of the lower overall prices.

The final point I make is that there is no question of stealth in the way in which the Government has applied this particular tax, nor will there be any question of the Government taking windfall gains as a result of it. I am announcing today-if the Press release has not already gone out-an increase in the import parity price for June to reflect some recovery in the market over the last four weeks. There will be a compensating reduction in the product excise to counter the increase in crude excise that will flow from that particular IPP.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will be the net result?

—It is revenue neutral. The price increase will be around 0.3c per litre, which will have a CPI effect of 0.4, I think, which is pretty small. However, that will give something like a 20 per cent price increase to producers-in particular, on-shore producers. The Government has been quick to respond to the needs of producers and to offer the exploration incentives that we spoke of earlier. The particular point I make here is that we are honouring the promise that we made earlier this year that there would be no attempt to hang on to product excise increases in the event of an upward movement in the import parity price and, as a result, an upward movement in our crude excise receipts. That is exactly what we have done, and the move will be fully revenue neutral.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not in any way suggest that in the longer term it may not be necessary to have greater reliance on product excise as a result of declining indigenous production and the sort of Bass Strait phenomenon we spoke of earlier. That is a revenue problem with which this Government, as would any government, will have to wrestle in due course. It may be that in due course there will have to be a greater shift to product taxation. However, I think it is important to acknowledge the Government has not sought to wring the petrol consumer dry, despite the temptation to do so when one looks at comparative taxation regimes in other countries. There may be some opportunity to increase product taxes over time but it is not an opportunity that this Government has sought to grasp at the moment because it acknowledges the desirability of keeping these fuel input costs as low as is compatible with reasonable revenue returns to the country as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must state that every argument that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) advanced just now to support his case was rejected by him and the Australian Labor Party when in Opposition. The Fraser Government pointed out that Australia was the third lowest petroleum producing country in the world and that the tax intake was as the Minister stated. The Labor Party, including the Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, and the Minister, said then that that is no argument at all; nor is it. The argument is about whether the Government will pass on totally import parity price adjustments. Let us not now turn to an argument that the Minister rejected out of hand. The fact of the matter is that what the Government has done today is a breach of its election policies and a breach of its import parity policies. The Government is now trying to scramble for any kind of argument, all of which it rejected in the past, to justify its actions. I can only say that the Government does not have legs on which to run. Lawyers are paid to take a brief from both sides but this really takes all the gall there is.

— Might I just correct one error of fact in what Senator Sir John Carrick had to say. I do not think the present Minister for Resources and Energy ever went on record then as saying anything about petrol prices in any context whatsoever. The first interest I took in this subject was when I assumed the portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let the very long presentation of Senator Sir John Carrick go by without stating that the saving of energy and the need for specific measures to introduce and handle new forms of energy must be a very important part of any energy policy for a country. The Australian Democrats support the conservation view. I do not know whether we would agree much further in the area of hitting the Government on the petrol excise, which I believe introduces, to some extent, a conservation attitude towards this type of scarce resource. However, we agree on not exporting a scarce resource, a non-renewable resource, such as petrol.

SPEECH.PARA: I am worried that a number of specific questions which Senator Sir John Carrick raised in that area are being completely bypassed by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). In deference to his sore throat, I will cut down the amount of my questioning in this area. However, I cannot let the opportunity go by without asking him to say specifically what the Government is doing about cutting down the wastage of energy within the Public Service. What specifically is the Government doing about transferring its very large fleets of cars and trucks and those of the statutory bodies which come under its control to liquefied petroleum gas, which is available to a much greater extent within Australia? What is the Government doing to introduce, say, alcohol as an additive to fuel to cut down the use of the non-renewable component of fuel?

It is important that the Minister tell the country what the Government's plans are in this area. In Queensland sugar producers are currently screaming that they are going out of business. We could be using the `mountains of sugar' in a very effective way to produce alcohol. It may be more expensive but it would keep some people in business and would improve our employment prospects. Fuel will not be at the same price indefinitely. The current situation seems to have been induced basically by the Iran-Iraq war and the fact that people in those areas need to get more revenue. We also seem to be in the business of trying to get revenue by selling cheap oil to the world. I believe that we should be conserving oil.

The next specific matter which I think we should be looking at is the area of low impact technology. What is the Government doing about encouraging solar ponds and the use of the sterling cycle in getting energy out of very small temperature differences? Is the Government supporting any projects on this in Australia? We used to be way ahead on solar energy use because we have a lot of that resource. Currently we are dropping back because we are relying more and more on just ripping out of the ground those mineral and energy resources about which Senator Sir John Carrick talked and on using electricity to subsidise the aluminium industry to a very large extent at the expense of the Australian taxpayer. What is the Government doing about low impact energy? What is it doing about using some of our arid land where oil bearing weeds are growing and extracting oil of the higher fractionating types which are not available in our underground gases? I do not wish to continue very long. I would like to hear the Minister's response to these matters.

What is the Government doing about cogeneration? Cogeneration is a technique which allows people to produce electricity on their own property from wind and local resources and feed it back into the network for the benefit of the community. It is producing lots of power in California and Portugal. What are we doing about developing these new sources of energy so that when the price of oil goes up, as it inevitably will because resources are running out, we will have to have an indigenous energy producing industry that we can export to the world? It is the lack of vision in this area of both the major parties which has resulted in our balance of payments going down the gurgler. We are not exporting dynamically. It is not so much a matter of cost. We can probably afford to pay for the labour if we just use our imagination and the resources and intelligence of the people of Australia, which are enormous, to develop facilities and new and exciting ways of saving energy and producing energy. I ask the Minister to respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Whenever I am backed into a corner at a social function, as I often am, by someone talking about getting methane from pig poo or ethanol from beetroot, I always know that the person is an Australian Democrat. Senator Vigor's contribution today was in the finest spirit of his Party's tradition in that respect. It is important that we have regard to renewable sources of energy, solar energy and all the other forms with which Australia is potentially very well endowed. But one has to maintain a healthy sense of realism and proportion about what likely contribution those energy sources will ever be capable of making to the national economy as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The sorts of figures that have emerged from our studies are retailed in the `Energy 2000' series of booklets, with which I would be very happy to supply Senator Vigor, and indicate that even on the most optimistic assumptions of the contribution of these energy sources, we are still talking of the order of only one per cent or at most two per cent of our national energy needs. As a result it is just the case that these things will not be the answers to the nation's prayers, although they can make a very useful, indeed, marginal contribution. As to some of the other matters raised, there is quite a detailed description in the Department's annual report of the national energy management program and what we are doing with Commonwealth buildings and vehicles and so on. I will ensure that a copy of that and any other material that is available is sent to Senator Vigor.

On the particular issue of the Queensland sugar industry and fuel alcohol, Senator Vigor ought to be aware, if he is not already aware, of a recent publication of my Department which addresses in very considerable detail both the technology and the economics of that issue and comes down, regrettably, against the viability, from any rational economic perspective, of that particular fuel source option. I will make sure that Senator Vigor gets a copy of that so that he can belabour me with some alternative version of it in the future.

The issues raised by Senator Vigor of solar ponds and everything else are not things that the Government is ignoring. We continue to support research into these things through the national energy research, development and demonstration program. There are still incentives for research, apart from that program with the 150 per cent research and development write-off provisions that the Government has introduced. It is important that activity in these areas continues but do not let any of us be under some romantic illusion, as regrettably all too many people are in this area, that somehow these alternative energy sources will constitute the basic answer to the country's energy problems, and in particular to the fundamental problem of liquid fuel which has been the subject of Senator Sir John Carrick's earlier contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the estimates for the Department of Defence and to make a general observation about the witnesses from that Department who appeared before Estimates Committee E. I base those observations on eight years continuous experience on Estimates committees in the Senate, both for the annual Budget and for Additional Estimates. It is with regret that I have to say that from my experience in my time in the Senate the Department of Defence provides the worst witnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose I have dealt with the majority of departments over the years and the best witnesses have been those from the Department of Resources and Energy. While I am criticising people, I would like to give an accolade to a department whose behaviour before the Senate has been exemplary, in my experience.

My criticism of the Department of Defence is not something that has come to my notice or consciousness in the last couple of months. It was apparent quite a few years ago. The other point I would like to emphasise is that it is certainly not one of the faults of the Labor Government. The attitude has been in existence in the Department for quite a few years. I have been told by senior people in the Department that the staff of the Department get together weeks before an Estimates committee and actually rehearse what the Department's line shall be in reply to questions. That is unconscionable. Certainly we expect witnesses to support a departmental position that has been agreed after consultation, but we do not want rehearsals and we do not want 100 per cent departmentally correct answers. The effect has been that far too many witnesses who have appeared before us have given us answers that are obstructive, evasive and at times misleading-in an intentional way-and some of the witnesses have been inaccurate.

I will not embarrass the senior person involved by naming him but in the Hansard of the last hearing at least one head of a division made a statement, in good faith-my recollection is that the Hansard does not report him inaccurately-that is wrong in detail. It probably does not matter much at the end of the day but I am surprised that witnesses should make mistakes before such a committee and not correct themselves.

It is wrong that witnesses can appear before a committee of the Senate with these attitudes. The attitude of the Department of Defence is an adversarial, almost gladiatorial, one. Witnesses try to see what they can hang on to and conceal when they appear before the Senate Committee. Surely the attitude ought to be one of frank openness and readiness to answer the questions of the Senate. I do not want to deal with the civilian component of the Department of Defence. In my judgment it is too large and, quite frankly, beyond redemption. Until we get a Minister who will get in there, kick a few tails and set a few priorities, we will not improve the civilian component. When staff of the Department of Defence appear before Estimates committees they come in like a thundering herd. About 50 or 60 civilian and senior service witnesses come in and just about fill the Senate chamber.

My greatest concern is about the service personnel. As I made the point that only some of the answers that are obstructive and evasive, so it is only a percentage-very definitely a minority-of the service personnel appearing before the Senate who do not have a helpful attitude. Quite bluntly, we are looking at people who are more politically oriented than they are soldiers; I use that word in a broad sense to cover all three Services. I am not saying for one moment that these service witnesses with a political bent are operating in a party political sense. They are not doing that in any way; they are not openly Labor, Liberal or anything like that. They are political in the sense that they are defending the positions, as they see them, of the Department of Defence and they adopt an adversarial role.

Such people are in the minority but, regrettably, that minority is increasing year by year. They are as evasive as their civilian counterparts. They should be frank, open and direct with the Senate. When they are not open, frank and direct in their answers, inevitably the Senate has to doubt their integrity and professional competence. It is a tragedy. They are not the sorts of service personnel I want to see rise to the senior levels of the Australian Services. They are a discredit to the very fine men we have as Chiefs of Staff of the three Services in Australia. General Sir Phillip Bennett, the Chief of the Defence Force, Admiral Hudson, the Chief of Naval Staff, General Gration, the Chief of the General Staff and Air Marshal Newham, the Chief of the Air Staff, are all people of great integrity. In all the dealings that I have had with them on various committees in the Parliament, they have given frank, honest and open answers. I believe they would be horrified if they came in here and saw the way that some of their one-star, half-colonels and officers of similar rank behaved before the Senate at a Senate hearing. It is part of the Australian parliamentary tradition that Parliament controls the Services. There is no argument about that. But we seem to have reached the stage where the Department of Defence believes that it can control everything and give no information to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Department of Defence representatives to give me their perceptions of the quality of the performance of the honourable senators before whom they appeared. They felt constrained by a sense of discretion, not to mention the traditions of the Westminster system, from doing so. I do not doubt that Senator MacGibbon has felt some frustration from time to time about the absence of quick or what he perceived to be responsive answers to questions but it is unfortunate that he should have tarred with such a comprehensive brush all the witnesses who have come from that Department over recent times. It may be that some individuals are less forthcoming than others. Some institutional reasons and part of the culture of that Department-if I may put it that way-may make it less responsive perhaps than are some others to questions of this kind. As the Minister responsible for answering questions on defence I acknowledge that often I have some difficulty in obtaining quick answers through the office of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) from the Department to the sorts of issues of the day that are likely to arise.

SPEECH.PARA: This problem is simply a function of the sprawling size and complexity of the Department and the provisions and lines of responsibility within it which make some people feel constrained from perhaps being as forthcoming as they are able. It ought to be appreciated that despite the large numbers of witnesses who come to Estimates hearings from the Department of Defence, both from the civilian and military sides, they represent only a very small proportion of the total senior bureaucracy in the Department. It is difficult to combine the general policy and operational oversight responsibilities that people have with the requisite degree of detailed knowledge of matters that might arise during the hearings. I am told that the difficulty that the Department has faced is in avoiding having unmanageable numbers of officers present.

To have an appropriate range of officers able to deal with any conceivable question that might come up, we would probably need three or four times the number that we have. That sometimes contributes to answers not being as available as one might think appropriate. Beyond that I can say nothing. I am sure that the Department and the Minister will take on notice what Senator MacGibbon has said. It is a little unfortunate that he chose to be quite as scathing in such a comprehensive fashion because many individuals who have been witnesses over the years from that Department have not justified any of the criticisms levelled so comprehensively against them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of comments on the Department of Defence. First, I will specifically comment on the program that was announced last year and the several million dollars allotted, as I recollect, to increase the number of Australians in the Reserve. Reserve numbers had fallen very substantially from about 32,000 to the lower 20,000. It was presented in the last Budget and in the previous Estimates Committee that a very specific and carefully nurtured program was being developed to raise the level to about 28,000 in the short term. We queried at the time the very nature of the glossy program. I do not want to be invidious but some would doubt whether a benign Prime Minister hopping out of a helicopter, whatever his politics, may have an attraction to urge young people to join the Reserve. Both sides of the Parliament directed questions on the nature of the program but it was staunchly defended, as one would expect. What has happened? Rather than any increase in the Reserve, numbers have fallen over the months by about 500 or 600. That is drawing from memory. That ought to be a matter of very serious self-criticism by government and a matter of statement and of public debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that in two world wars what was then called the militia was the basis from which an army could expand, particularly to get its noncommissioned officers and junior officers very quickly. That was very important when there was time during perhaps the first year of a war to put together an army. How much more important is this now when everybody agrees that there will not be any time if an emergency occurs? The forces one has at the point of an emergency are what one will have to deal with the emergency. It is much more important now that our reserve forces in size, equipment and morale be at a maximum state of readiness. There is talk of some integration between the permanent army and the Reserve. For my sins and to my great pleasure I spent a fair part of my life in the militia. I would welcome that decision very much. The sooner that Russell Hill recognises the imperative need to depend in the end very largely upon part time soldiers, sailors and airmen for the community's assistance at a point of crisis, the better off we will be.

I do not make that point in a subjective way. A program set out with great expenditure and glossy television advertisements has failed miserably. One must ask: How does this happen? For example, how does it happen at a time when many fine young men are unemployed and have time to do jobs. It is not good enough simply to say: `But the reserves are selective and put a test on those who will come in'. Unhappily, in the unemployment pool there are many fine people who would have the qualities to be amongst our reservists. They are not joining. When the Government in a mean and miserable way put a tax upon Reserve earnings it said that this would not hurt and that everything would be all right. What a silly thing to have done, and what a silly thing not to have repaired. Whether it was important in terms of money is not the thing. It is a psychological situation. I stress that it is vital that the Government look at what has happened in the past six months and at the reasons why people are not coming forward to join the reserves. Let us look at this against the background that there is leaked to us time and time again a series of ideas which suggest either some kind of `fortress Australia' or that the only threat is that somebody will land on our shores and we will have to act with immediacy.

I took no comfort when as a member of a Senate committee quite a long time ago I asked about the Operational Deployment Force at Lavarack Barracks in Townsville. I asked what was the state of immediacy of readiness. I was told what has to be a vital piece of information: That if there were an emergency along our coastline within seven days we could put a company group into action. I tell honourable senators, as one who is not bad at sums, that a company group probably comprises between 120 and 150 people. I am not talking about 150,000 people or thousands of people. We were told calmly that within seven days we could get a company group into action. That is a very interesting situation, provided the enemy is compliant, provided one can say to one's opponent: `Would you mind waiting please because we have a logistic difficulty?' What a piece of nonsense! Why have an Operational Deployment Force unless it has a sense of immediacy? I think officers told us that within a fortnight or so they could get together a battalion-probably 700 or 800 people. Yet there is a brigade in Lavarack Barracks.

The defence forces are always organised for peacetime, sadly enough, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. In saying that I make no reflection on the defence forces. I have a very great affection for the defence forces and understanding of the importance of the Department of Defence, although I must say that I share some of the reservations Senator MacGibbon put forward. The fact is that if, at the most, we have to deal with terrorism, with all sorts of incursions, in an immediate way we have to have a well equipped Reserve and an Army that is ready to move. It has to be capable of rapid movement by air and land. On land it must have the protection of modern, up to date armoured personnel carriers-not the obsolescent carriers we have now. Our soldiers, our troops, deserve protection.

The trouble is that we are being told a series of things by way of brainwashing. No doctrine I have heard regularly in the Parliament and in the community is more erroneous than the doctrine of perceived threat. Every time we have a defence debate the doctrine of perceived threat is trotted out by the Defence Department, the Army or other bodies. We have been told-we are being told now-that Australia faces no threat for 10 years, that we will have 10 years warning. The other day I looked up a statement made in the other place some eight months or so before World War II by Prime Minister Curtin, a good man. To paraphrase him, he said that anybody who argued then for an increase in armaments was as wrong as could be. Of course, eight months later the world was involved in a slaughter which cost 40 million lives. I do not quote Mr Curtin in an invidious way. I quote him to highlight the error of those who think that the telescope is sufficiently good to perceive the threat. That misunderstands the opponent. Why would an opponent present a threat which was so perceivable that he started with a disadvantage? That is a nonsense. What is most important to remember is that the lead time to get together trained troops and hardware is longer in terms of years than the optical power of any telescope. It takes some four years to train an army sergeant and, probably, eight years to get a naval destroyer from the time of ordering. If there is an emergency we will be able to deal with that emergency only with what we have at the moment. In the immediate years ahead our capacity to deal with emergencies will be the capacity we have now because the lead time is so enormous.

We are constantly brainwashed with the idea of perceived threat. Nobody has been right in the past. Honourable senators should read William Pitt to see his mistakes, or Lloyd George or Curtin. The whole of history supports the truth that the theory of the perceived threat is as wrong as hell and has cost literally hundreds of millions of lives throughout the world. Nobody is going to present the threat to us on a plate. Nobody is going to give us a lead time. Yet we are being told that now. We are being told that the only threat to us will involve some kind of stray incursions up north and that what we need are small bodies of troops. If that is so, we had better smarten up. What we will need more than anything will be a first class Reserve-up to date, and immediately ready to take part. We do not have that Reserve now. I ask the Government to consider the calamity that has befallen us.

I conclude with a couple of remarks that no doubt will be embroidered later in the Senate. During the Estimates debate last year a number of questions were asked about the nature and cost of the intention of the Army and the Department of Defence to transfer an Initial Training School to Bathurst-Orange. I do not comment on the matter because a Senate committee will do so at another time. However, I note that the Government has decided not to proceed with the proposal. I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to let this Committee know the total cost of the whole of the investigation of the Bathurst-Orange proposal-it will not be at hand now-including the cost of the impact statement by Dames and Moore. I also ask the Minister to take on board, when the land acquisition is being considered, the damage done to the people of Bathurst over them and denying them freedom of movement. I do not trespass on the Senate inquiry which is another matter. I ask only for information on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take on notice the question about Bathurst-Orange and refer the honourable senator's remarks in that respect to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). As to the question of the Reserve, it has to be said that recruitment and retention in the Army Reserve are matters of continuing concern to the Government. The most recent figures available, to the end of April this year, show a continuation of the increased recruitment and lower wastage this year compared with 1984-85. Recruitment is running over the comparable period, 1985-86 to 1984-85, at an increase of 2,875 or 105 per cent. Wastage is down by 1,720 or 22 per cent. The overall strength as at 30 April was 23,246, which is an increase of 71 over the number at the end of the previous month. The target is not 28,000 or 32,000 but 26,500.
—In the short term.
—In the short term. It is acknowledged that there is a shortfall in relation to that target but the trends, as I say, of recruitment and wastage are encouraging.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the larger issues raised by Senator Sir John Carrick, I have to say that there is no particular perceived problem about the Defence Force's capacity at the moment. There has been a very substantial increase in that capacity as far as capital equipment is concerned over recent years, with a greater increase, it has to be said, under the Government than under its predecessor. It is important that that program continue, and it will. The question of capacity is distinct from the question of readiness, which Senator Sir John Carrick also referred to in a number of his remarks. The readiness of a force is conditioned by current perceptions as to the requirements to be made of that force. That question is being squarely addressed by Mr Dibb in his report shortly to be released which will, in turn, be considered in very great detail by the Government. Beyond that, I do not think it is necessary or appropriate for me to reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have Senator MacGibbon's long experience of Estimates committees, but I have been to a number of Estimates committees in my short time in the Senate, to the discomfort of the Government, as I have been investigating reasonably thoroughly the figures and claims which have been made by the Public Service. Indeed, I think the Government should be very happy about that if it took its job seriously. I felt particularly unsatisfied about the Department of Defence. That was not helped by the attitude of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who insisted, after I had asked my first question, that everything else be put on notice. Although the questions were put on notice and despite the fact that the Department has had much time to consult as many people as it wanted, I have received a number of non-answers in this area. This is very serious because the Department of Defence has put in a bid for an amount of $290m in the Supplementary Estimates. I have looked back over the history and it is by far one of the largest amounts that have appeared in Supplementary Estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: I was quite innocent when I started this process, but since examining the figures and the information that have been given to me, I have been appalled at what is happening. Part of the reason for seeking this large amount of money is a heavy reliance on the purchase of materiels from overseas. In a defence environment this is a serious problem. In a war, the lines of communication are the things which are attacked and we are becoming more and more dependent upon extremely long lines of communication. That is just one aspect of it.

I believe it is important that the Senate and the Parliament as a whole should examine what we are getting for our money. I have not been able to get any reasonably sensible answers on this. I give notice to the Department of Defence that at the next Estimates Committee hearing I will be expecting answers to these questions. At this stage it is not the case, but if we go about things sensibly we can develop high technology industries and achieve a real measure of self-reliance, rather than just being a little piece of a jigsaw in a large world alliance. As a parliamentarian I owe it to the people of Australia to make certain that their money which is being spent on defence-it is a large proportion of the Budget-is being spent sensibly. If we look only to purchases from overseas, we will create major unemployment and balance of trade problems. These are all avoidable things. If we intend to have a strong and independent Australia which can stand on its own against any threat-I agree with Senator Sir John Carrick in terms of the pernicious doctrine of perceived threat-we must be prepared to develop an indigenous industry which is able to service the surveillance technology and small arms support technology within Australia.

The evidence that was given to me at the Estimates Committee-what little I managed to glean-suggests that we will have to put a lot more effort into the area of purchasing of defence equipment. There seems to be an enormous reluctance to choose Australian products. I ask the Minister what is the Government's policy in this area of choosing Australian products when Australian products can be chosen. It is the policy of the Australian Democrats to have affirmative action for Australian industry. That policy should be espoused also by the Government, unless it is working for overseas multinational companies, which is one possible theory.

I refer to the various reports of the Auditor-General and their follow-up by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its 243rd report, entitled `Review of Defence Project Management'. The report refers to the fact that time after time there have been mentions of major cost overruns, major delays in getting programs ironed out and major problems with management information systems. I know that it is a very demanding business to defend this country. I wonder, considering the answers I have had and the administrative bungles, whether we are in good hands in this area, but I have no alternative but to trust it. I believe that the information on our requirements should be available in a timely fashion. For us to be totally in control of our purchasing policy local industry must be told very early what is expected by the Department of Defence. We should not have to depend completely on going overseas, looking at what is available and writing a tender that corresponds exactly with the goodies that we have been shown by some foreign arms dealers. Costly decisions should not be made at the last minute. We are probably overspecifying a number of the weapons systems that we are getting, according to the Auditor-General's report. How is a parliamentary layman such as I able to judge that? What types of procedures does the Government have for looking independently into the morass of defence purchasing to be able to give some understandable report to us? I interviewed officials of the Auditor-General at a briefing the other day and they said that a lot of the auditing in Defence is done internally. When I have tried to ask questions about it, I have found that basically the auditing on each of the systems is done overall. How much time is that system up and available and what are we getting for the money?

I have asked questions, to which I have not had answers, on the physical stocks of spare parts. Something over $1 billion for the year was spent on sundry equipment and spares over the whole of the armed forces. Admittedly that was broken down into a few individual projects, but it was not broken down in terms of the levels of spares and the efficiency and effectiveness of these areas.

I turn to the offsets program, which is supposedly a means by which we buy foreign equipment and get those companies to produce things here in return. The offsets have to be arranged and monitored properly. I asked questions about that and the answer I was given was that no records were kept before 1980. There seems to have been a peak of offsets arrangements in 1982 at $572m. We are still holding unfulfilled offsets of approximately that amount, despite the fact that only very small offset commitments have been put in the meantime. Our record in this area is pathetic. There is a major adverse report from the Auditor-General on offsets generally. The Government had to tighten its administration of offsets by setting up a central offsets recording section. That was set up last year, and I applaud the Government for doing that, but we have not seen any results from it. Can the Minister tell me how effective that has been? The information that was provided to me by the Minister yesterday shows that there is a current outstanding offsets obligation of approximately $600m.
Consideration interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I inform the Senate that Senator Gietzelt will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Gietzelt in relation to his portfolio or to those he represents in this chamber should be directed to Senator Grimes.
—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the Government be making any changes to its fringe benefits tax proposals as they apply to cars, or in any other way?

—I think it is common knowledge amongst those literate senators who read the newspapers that there have been discussions about the fringe benefits tax on motor cars, and certain propositions, if I can put it in that terminology, have been advanced. The Government has not yet considered those propositions as a Government, but will do so very shortly. I personally assure the Senate that if such propositions are put, I will oppose them, because that seems to be the best way of getting them accepted.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education. What is the Commonwealth's view on Press reports which indicate that the Western Australian Government intends to legislate to change the Western Australian Institute of Technology into a third university in Western Australia and rename it the Curtin University of Technology? In particular, would the proposed change of status entitle WAIT to a higher level of Commonwealth funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed Press reports and indeed have received other information from Western Australia that the Western Australian Government intends to change the name of WAIT, by legislation, to the Curtin University of Technology. Its motives for taking this sort of unilateral action can only be guessed at. However, as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, there has been no agreement to this course of action. The Commonwealth has a responsibility for funding higher education institutions, and it has the responsibility to take a national perspective in relation to the balance between the two higher education sectors and in the provision of higher education through all States and Territories. There has been no formal submission by the Western Australian Government seeking the Commonwealth's agreement to this course of action, and even if such a formal submission were to be forthcoming I very much doubt that the Commonwealth, as far as the national perspective is concerned, would afford such a proposal a very high priority.

ANSWER.PARA: The funding of WAIT under any name will be at the college of advanced education level. It is simply not possible for a State government unilaterally to decide to change the funding of an institution from the CAE level to the higher level afforded to universities because of their research functions. I do not think that the course of action that the Western Australian Government has decided upon is sensible. I note Press reports that other institutions in Western Australia have also expressed their concern about it, and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee equally has expressed concern about unilateral action of this kind. I hope that the Western Australian Government will reconsider its course of action. I should say, for the benefit of those honourable senators who are not familiar with the Western Australian Institute of Technology, that the remarks I am making in no way detract from my recognition that it is an outstanding institution. It is an institute of technology of first class standing; its reputation is very high, its teaching standards are very high and it has engaged in some interesting initiatives, including the establishing of an external studies course, for a Bachelor of Business Administration, in Singapore. All of these things are to its credit, and it is a very creditable institution. But the question of the relationship between the sectors is an important one. A balance must be maintained and it is not acceptable to the Commonwealth that any State should unilaterally seek to change that balance without the agreement of the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I am sorry to hear he is so discouraged about his cars. I refer the Minister to his comment on the Sunday program on 18 May when he said the prices and incomes accord would be on the agenda of the economic conference involving Federal and State governments, the unions and employer organisations. Following yesterday's Government-Australian Council of Trade Unions meeting at which Mr Willis talked about the possibility of some adjustment to wages policy, will the Government be putting any submission to the meeting aimed at achieving a more flexible accord?
