Is it still the Government's intention, as stated by Mr Willis last Wednesday, to seek a reopening of the national wage case if anything substantive comes out of the meeting? Finally, will the Minister advise what other matters the Cabinet has decided should be on the agenda for the meeting?

—Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle is right; I did say on the Sunday program that the prices and incomes accord would inevitably be on the agenda for that meeting, and aspects of the prices and incomes accord will be. It goes without saying that if we are participating in a committee which is an advisory committee on prices and incomes, it is likely that prices and incomes will be discussed, and they are the substance of the accord so inevitably that is the case. I think, if I got the honourable senator's question right, that she then asked whether the Government will be seeking more flexibility in the accord. I remind the honourable senator that there is a degree of flexibility about macroeconomic effects on the accord already in that there is a provision for those matters to be discussed in the event of a significant change in the macroeconomic environment, and whether or not a more flexible accord for the longer term will be on the agenda has not been determined at this stage. Insofar as seeking a reopening of the national wage case is concerned, all I can say is I think that is unlikely because any policy responses to the current trade situation will, of necessity, be over a period. The agenda has not been finalised yet so I cannot answer these questions with great specificity, as the Prime Minister sometimes says. If Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle wants to recycle the question later in the week, I might be in a better position to answer in more detail.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a set of researched figures drawn from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and other reliable sources which show that at the beginning of this month in 18 key areas of the economy Queensland had the worst results of any State in six, the second worst results in six and was below the Australian average in 14? To what extent is this appalling economic performance of the Queensland Government, and in particular the Premier and Treasurer Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, holding back the rest of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—Why don't you talk about your own deficit?

—About what? I am aware of the facts to which Senator Jones has drawn attention because a newsletter circulated in Queensland by Senator Jones fell on my desk the other day. It contains some very interesting information about the Queensland economy and expresses his distress that a State with the great potential that Queensland has is, because of the way in which it is being misgoverned, dragging the rest of the country down. It shows, among other things, that the unemployment rate in Queensland for the most recent available month was 9.2 per cent, which is equal to the highest of any State and a great deal above the national average of 8 per cent. Queensland also has the lowest average weekly male earnings figure of $384, which is 7 per cent below the Australian average of $413.

ANSWER.PARA: In spite of that advantage in the employment market situation-the employment potential that the Opposition is always talking about, that if wages were lower employment opportunities would be much higher-Queensland still has equal to the highest unemployment rate of any State and an unemployment rate significantly higher than the national average. It also has the highest rate of industrial disputes, which is a comment on the success of the confrontationist tactics pursued stubbornly by the Queensland Government, and the number of working days lost per thousand employees was almost double the national average. It also has the highest growth rate in the number of bankruptcies for 1984-85, the most recent year for which figures are available. There were 15.7 per cent more bankruptcies in Queensland in the last financial year, while the Australia-wide figure fell by almost 4 per cent. The figures for fixed capital expenditure are also very poor compared to the national figures most recently available for a 12 months period, and the number of new residential buildings commenced in the December quarter of 1985 dropped by 9 per cent in Queensland.

Finally, Senator Jones asked me whether it is possible to state the degree to which the dismal economic performance in Queensland is holding the rest of Australia back. I think it is an impossible exercise to do that in any precise way but the figures speak for themselves. There can be absolutely no doubt that the dismal performance of the Queensland economy has retarded quite significantly the economic progress which the country as a whole would otherwise have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services aware of the increasing number of homeless young people in all States in Australia who are forced to sleep each night in abandoned cars, bus shelters and other less than salubrious quarters? Is the Minister aware that there are a number of migrant hostels maintained by the Government in various States in Australia which are left unused for much of the year? Has the Government considered using these vacant premises to house homeless young people? If it has not, will it now consider the matter or, alternatively, will the Minister say why such accommodation could not be put to what appears to be a very good use of providing destitute young people with a roof over their heads?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, as is anyone in the Senate who served on the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare which looked at this problem, that there are too many homeless young people in Australia who live in cars and other unsatisfactory accommodation of that type. I do not know that Senator Haines can back up her statement-I do not know that anyone can back up the statement that she makes-that there are increasing numbers of homeless youth. It is an assertion that is often made and it is an assertion that I cannot deny or affirm.

ANSWER.PARA: The use of migrant hostels and other buildings of this type has been considered by government authorities and, in fact, was considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. In general there are buildings owned by particularly State governments which may frequently be appropriate for this purpose. In fact, in New South Wales the State government I believe at one stage made houses available, particularly houses that it was holding for future highway or freeway development, for homeless young people. Buildings also were used that had previously been used for young people in charge. The problem with migrant hostels by and large is that they are in inappropriate places for young people. They are frequently out in the suburbs where young people by choice simply do not want to be. In making them satisfactory for accommodation by this group of young people there is a great danger of their ending up institutional forms of accommodation. Of necessity there would have to be much more discipline and control than these young people are frequently willing to accept, but I certainly will take the matter up with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who I think is still in charge of those hostel buildings that are still around.

The important thing is that we provide two types of accommodation. The first type is the refuge or shelter-type short term accommodation. I think it is the judgment of most people that there is probably enough of that type of accommodation around. What is really needed is medium-term and long term accommodation which is affordable and accessible and which in the first place provides young people with assistance to develop their living skills so that they can cope with this sort of independent type accommodation. Some of the State authorities, particularly those in South Australia and Victoria, are assisting in this regard. I think all State authorities should assist in this regard so that we can get these people into more permanent and more normal type accommodation than would be provided in migrant hostels or other institutional type accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance seen an article in the West Australian newspaper on 16 May 1986 headlined `Policeman: MP incited group'? If he has, is it true that the article reports the conviction of a bankrupt farmer, Mr James Butterfield, for remaining on the premises of the Merlin Hotel after being warned to leave, and for resisting arrest during the course of a demonstration? Will the Minister consider an act of grace payment to Mr Butterfield to cover the fine and court costs, given that he was apparently incited to break the law by a Federal member of parliament? Should the fate of Mr Butterfield give pause for thought to people who might consider taking the advice of Mr Hassell and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen to also break the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deplorable though the recent incitement by Mr Hassell and the Premier of Queensland to law breaking may be, I do not think one could put a retrospective application to it, but it is certainly correct, as Senator Cook's question indicated, that the police evidence given at the hearing of the charges against Mr Butterfield, as reported in the West Australian, was that the Federal Opposition spokesman on small business, Mr Wilson Tuckey, had been inciting farmers during a demonstration at the Merlin Hotel. That evidence was apparently given by Sergeant Glen Miller, who was reported as saying that Tuckey was the loudest and most vocal of the group. Having been present for some of that incident, I can confirm that Tuckey was the loudest and most vocal. The second loudest and most vocal was a Mr McNee, who at that time was the Liberal Party of Australia Member of the Legislative Assembly for the seat of Mount Marshall, who promptly lost his seat about two weeks after that event. I think it is regrettable that the ratbag right example set by Mr Tuckey on that occasion has subsequently been endorsed by his State leader, Mr Hassell, and also by the Premier of Queensland.

—Mr President, a point of order: I have seen a report since yesterday's Question Time in which Mr Hassell made it quite clear that he is not advocating breaches of the law. Since the Standing Orders protect members of State parliaments from allegations which are unparliamentary, I think it is appropriate that I should take a point of order at this stage because it is not apparently accurate that Mr Hassell has advocated any breach of the law; rather, he has made it quite clear that whilst he strongly opposes the tax, he is not in favour of the law being broken should the tax be put in place. Therefore, I think that the Minister should be cautioned on this point and should not make allegations of that nature against a member of the Western Australian Parliament.

—On the point of order, Mr President: Senator Chaney is correct in saying that that was reported in yesterday's West Australian; but at the end of last week, and specifically last Friday, Mr Hassell was advocating defiance of the law. He has subsequently changed his mind. I am glad to see that, although whether it is because of moral conviction or persuasion or political expediency is another matter.

—I will rule on the point of order. Standing order 418 refers to offensive remarks rather than inaccurate remarks. Bearing in mind what the Minister has said, I rule against the point of order, but I ask the Minister in answering to bear in mind what I have said on standing order 418.

—Certainly, Mr President. Senator Cook asked me whether I would consider making an act of grace payment to Mr Butterfield because his offensive behaviour was incited by the member for O'Connor. There are no rigid rules governing the granting of act of grace payments. There are, however, guidelines, and in my judgment to use the act of grace provisions for that purpose would fall well outside the guidelines which I have followed since I have been in this office, and which I think both my predecessors followed in a similar way. I think that the decent thing to do in the circumstances, given that Mr Tuckey incited the behaviour which cost this unfortunate Mr Butterfield a $180 fine, would be for Mr Tuckey to pay the $180 out of his own pocket.

ANSWER.PARA: I also hope that the West Australian Liberal Party might note this incident and its implications. I believe that if the Liberal Party re-endorses Mr Tuckey it will lose the seat of O'Connor because Labor preferences will ensure that he is so removed, even though in following that course of action long-standing Labor Party precedents in directing preferences towards Liberals in Federal elections would be broken. That is a custom which I have supported vehemently over many years. The long-standing policy of the West Australian Labor Party, a policy of which I have been a firm supporter, I would support changing for this particular reason. I hope that that sort of warning might assist those in the Liberal Party who are currently engaged in the power struggle to oust the present leadership-the Hassells, the Tuckeys and all the rest of them-and put someone decent like Senator Chaney in their place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the seven Ministers-Senator Gietzelt, Mr Howe, Dr Blewett, Mr Kerin, Mr Uren, Mr West and Senator Grimes-who, according to a leaked document reported in the Australian, wrote to Mr Hawke refusing to co-operate with the Prime Minister's demand to identify areas in their departments that could have cuts. We then have the Minister himself, Senator Button, distancing himself from the fringe benefits tax--
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask her question?
—I am just coming to it.
—I hope that she will do so at a point early in time, or I will have to ask her to sit down.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I cannot hear the question because of the noise on the other side of the chamber. I ask you also to give Senator Walters a chance to ask her question by calling Government senators to order.
—Order! I ask all honourable senators to remain silent while they await Senator Walters's question.
—As I say, Senator Button has distanced himself from the fringe benefits tax--
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask her question?
—Seeing that the Cabinet is so divided over Government policy and, indeed, there is such a barney going on--
—Order! I ask Senator Walters to ask her question, or I will call the next question.
—Will the Minister please inform the Australian public which side in Cabinet is likely to win, and what form of taxes the Australian public can expect in just four weeks' time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Walters has been overseas for a lengthy trip and has come back and culled through her old newspaper clippings in dredging up this question, which was asked by other senators in different forms some months ago. The so-called letter from the seven Ministers might have roused a flutter in Senator Walters's breast, but it did not rouse one in many other breasts. It is the habit or custom, whoever is in power, at Budget time for Ministers to seek to protect the various interests they seek to represent in the Budget process. I wrote a letter to the Prime Minister about similar matters, and I am sure that other Ministers did. As usual, my letter did not get as much publicity as some of the others. I do not think anybody took any notice of my letter, and I am very aggrieved. I am sure that a lot of Ministers wrote letters of that kind, and I would not attach any great significance to that.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Walters asks which side is winning in some mythical confrontation she sees taking place in the Cabinet room. There is no confrontation, either mythical or real, taking place in the Cabinet room. There are a number of difficult issues which have to be grappled with. They will be grappled with. When the Cabinet has determined its position on these matters, we will make an appropriate announcement, and Senator Walters will be able to ask a question about it, if she can. But she may well be speechless.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Government aware of a proposal by my good friend and colleague Mr Ralph Jacobi, the member for Hawker in another place, regarding the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee on business regulation, whereby the Parliament could put under scrutiny the relationship between government regulation and the health of the trading and commercial ventures and enterprises that are so essential to the well-being of Australia? Does the Government see merit in such a committee being established and, if so, will it take such steps as are necessary to ensure that this long term project by the honourable member for Hawker comes to fruition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that he is Senator Tate's good friend. I have never been sure about that. Let me say that Mr Jacobi has been persisting for a long time with the importance of establishing a joint parliamentary committee on business regulation. The Government welcomes that approach. About a year ago the Government, in response to representations, specifically from the Business Council of Australia but from other organisations as well, set up in my Department what is known as the Business Regulation Review Unit, which is dedicated and devoted to trying to reduce the level of business regulation and more importantly--
—It is not making much progress.

—Let me finish the answer and then Senator Hill can have a go. More particularly, the Unit is dedicated and devoted to trying to reduce the lack of uniformity between State and Federal regulations, which is probably the greatest burden the Commonwealth has in respect of regulations generally. That Business Regulation Review Unit, which is a small group, is not only monitoring existing regulations or regulations coming up in the current context but also seeking the removal of unnecessary regulations which have been put in place in the past. It has been supplemented in its work by a voluntary arrangement with a number of business organisations. There are already business representatives on secondment working in the Business Regulation Review Unit and that will, I believe, in time produce very satisfactory results. Senator Hill interjected that it has not done much so far. I think he ought to ask me a question about that when I can give him an answer which is a long list of successes or partial successes. It is a slow process in a federal system.

ANSWER.PARA: The initiative sponsored by Mr Jacobi for the setting up of a joint parliamentary committee on business regulation is one that we regard as totally complementary to the action which the Government has already taken. The important thing is to establish an environment for change in relation to regulation and over-regulation. For example, if the Business Regulation Review Unit were successful in creating an environment for change within the Public Service and within the community and if there were a joint parliamentary committee which seriously got down to establishing an environment for change amongst some of the thickheads who have been interjecting on the other side of the chamber, that would be an immense improvement in attitude and would be very beneficial to this country. We welcome that initiative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce will recall that on 18 February I asked him:

QUESTION.PARA: When may the Senate expect to see the legislation to give formal authorisation to the Government's decision to allow the 150 per cent tax deduction for private sector investment in research and development . . .
He will also recall that he replied:
. . . the answer to the first part of the question is 8 May.

Why was the legislation not presented on 8 May as the Minister indicated? Was his answer simply in error or is there some other reason? When will the legislation be presented? Will it be before 30 May or will it be later, in which case it will not be possible for it to be passed until the Budget session? If the legislation has to wait until August, or later, what is the position for tax deductions in the current financial year for people who have taken the Government at its word and are expecting a tax concession which was, after all, announced by this Government on 29 May last year? Who is specifically responsible for this incompetence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall saying that on 18 February, for which I say thank God after listening to the rest of the honourable senator's question. I do not recall actually saying that, but I am confident that I did say something like that at about that time. The honourable senator asked whether my answer was misleading or in error. The answer is clearly that it was in error. I am hopeful that the legislation will be introduced in the House of Representatives this week. A number of delays have occurred and they have mainly been in drafting and because of the enormous task which the parliamentary draftsmen have had in relation to tax legislation generally. There were also a number of technically difficult things in relation to definitional problems and so on in this particular piece of legislation. I am hopeful, as I said, that it will be introduced this week in the House of Representatives.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Puplick asked what contingency arrangements are in place in the event of the legislation not being passed by both Houses of the Parliament by 30 May or whenever-the important point is before 1 July. I have been conscious of this problem. We are quite satisfied that appropriate arrangements can be made in respect of those companies to which Senator Puplick referred and which acted in good faith on the basis of the introduction of the tax concession from 1 July 1985. Those mechanisms will be implemented if that becomes necessary. I am very conscious of the delay, but I assure the honourable senator that the legislation is going ahead and that it will apply from 1 July 1985 in respect of all its effects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to recent Department of Social Security information on the number of unemployment beneficiaries in the various States of Australia? Has the Minister also noted the release of a report by the Queensland Liberal leader, Sir William Knox, which indicates that the Queensland economy is in a very bad way? Does this confirm that there is now a bipartisan Liberal and Labor position on the parlous economic condition of the Queensland economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the latter part of the question, I do not think one could say that there is a bipartisan view of the condition of the Queensland economy in the sense that that term is normally used, because it is normally used-at least as I understand it-to describe the attitude of the Labor side of politics and the non-Labor side of politics. Although there is clearly agreement between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party in Queensland on the appalling state of the Queensland economy, so far as I know the National Party has not yet acknowledged that and lives in a fool's paradise and deludes itself into believing that reality is something other than what it really is. That can be ascribed to the particular, peculiar and unique state of Queensland politics in that the Liberal Party and the National Party are not in government or in opposition together-the National Party Government is alone, I suspect to the greater disadvantage of Queensland than if there were a National-Liberal Party coalition. That report on the Queensland economy from the Liberal Party which was published by Sir William Knox, its parliamentary leader, confirms the other report from the Department of Social Security to which Senator Maguire's question refers and also the economic statistics which have been the subject of a number of questions in the Senate from, in particular, Senator Jones and Senator Maguire.

ANSWER.PARA: I will give some of the details of those statistics. In Queensland in March 110,000 people were receiving unemployment benefit, a figure slightly higher than the figure in Victoria, yet Victoria's labour force is two-thirds larger than that of Queensland. So Victoria has two-thirds as many people in the labour force but has a slightly lower number of people on unemployment benefit. Queensland, the third largest State in terms of population, is the second largest in terms of unemployment. It is also interesting to note that Australian Bureau of Statistics data reveals that in only three months out of the 31 months for which data has been published since the last Queensland election, Queensland has had an unemployment rate above the national average. For example, when Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen announced the 1983 State election only slightly under 15 per cent of Australia's jobless were in Queensland; now, more than 18 per cent of Australia's jobless are in that State. It has just under 16 per cent of the labour force.

It was customary for the Queensland Government to blame southern dole bludgers, to use its term, for Queensland's unemployment problem, but, like most of the claims that come from that State Government and from the Premier in particular, it is incompatible with the facts. The latest published information indicates that Queensland has recorded a net interstate population loss in the 20 to 34 age group, which is the most active of all labour market age groups. The unpalatable fact is that more than 5,000 people in that age group left Queensland for other States during 1984-85 because they realised, far from being dole bludgers, that the opportunities for getting a job were better almost anywhere else in Australia than they were in Queensland, and that the opportunities for getting jobs were certainly better in any of the other mainland States. They are voting with their feet and are showing what they think of the Queensland Government's economic management.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Education concerning the answers to questions I have been asking about the Chis- holm Institute of Technology in Melbourne and its $2m expenditure on the purchasing of a shopping centre. In answer to my question on 11 April the Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government encourages institutions to undertake activities which will enhance their flexibility in meeting the needs of their students. Activities such as that undertaken by the Chisholm Institute deserve the support of the Government and I have no intention of reducing Commonwealth funding to the institution.
In her news release on 1 May 1985, the Minister stated:

The new approach recognises that all schools have capital needs and makes an appropriate allowance for capital spending which ensures a reasonable balance between capital and recurrent spending and reduces the possibility of schools directing income to capital projects in ways which affect their entitlement to recurrent funding.

I ask the Minister: If she reclassifies schools to reduce their current grants because of their spending in capital projects on the one hand, why is she maintaining total funding for the Chisholm Institute on the other hand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to give a very long answer indeed to explain to Senator Sheil that the system and basis for Commonwealth support for higher education institutions is quite different from the system and basis for Commonwealth support that flows into government and non-government schools. I think Senator Sheil is under some misunderstanding with regard to the way in which the recurrent needs of non-government schools are worked out. Certainly an allowance is make in the formula for capital expenditure, which is expenditure on essential educational facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: No school is disadvantaged in any way by raising funds, either from fees or any other form of fund raising, to provide for essential capital facilities. So really no comparison can be drawn between a school raising funds, through fees or some other means, for essential capital facilities which does not affect its recurrent funding category and the situation where an autonomous higher education institution, which by the way operates under State legislation, takes steps to ensure that it will have income available to it in addition to the recurrent and capital funding it has available to it from the Federal Government. Recurrent funding for higher education institutions is in terms of places. Institutions are funded for a certain number of places and at a certain rate depending on whether the places are in less expensive courses, such as legal studies and business studies, or more expensive courses such as engineering and high technology courses. I do not think there is any point to be made by drawing any comparison with or contrast between the way in which higher education institutions are funded by the Commonwealth and the freedom that those institutions have to pursue other sources of income and schools funding, which is on a very comprehensive formula and certainly takes into account the capital needs of schools. It does not penalise schools in any way for raising funds to provide those capital facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry seen the Opposition's rural policy document which was released last week? If so, will he give the Senate an indication of the likely cost of the proposals contained therein?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not actually seen the document, but I have a summary of it, which was leaked last week by either the Liberal Party mole or one of the Liberal Party moles.
—The same one who leaked the education policy.
—I am not sure whether it was the same mole who leaked the education policy because he has not been leaking--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is attempting to answer a hypothetical question insofar as the document has not been released.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As always, Mr President, your ruling is correct although Senator MacGibbon is equally correct in drawing attention to the fact that the document has not been officially released. However, it has been unofficially released by one of the Liberal Party front bench back stabbers who, seething with discontent as are a number of other members of the front bench, wants to get rid of the present Leader of the Opposition. I am not sure whether they want to resurrect the former leader but they certainly want to get rid of the present one. That is the reason they have been leaking documents one by one as they come out. This has created a situation so serious that the Liberal Party felt obliged to dump six of the documents in one hit last week.
—Order! Will the Minister come back to Senator Black's question?

—Certainly. I apologise, Mr President; I was distracted by the spurious point of order raised by Senator MacGibbon. It is quite clear that the document is extravagant and of course absolutely incompatible with the repeated calls from various members of the Opposition, particularly Senator Baume and Senator Messner, to reduce government spending. The document promises to increase expenditure in the agricultural area alone by in excess of $500m per annum.
—How much?

—It promises an increase in expenditure of $500m just in the agricultural sector. For example, the document comprises a promise to rebate all the fuel excise paid by farmers. No doubt that would solve any income problem which a farmer living close to a major town would have because he would be able to buy petrol for $14 a drum less than the market price for drum fuel and about $20 a drum less than the market price for fuel out of the bowser and then flog it off to everybody in the nearby town and split the $20. It would certainly solve those particular farmers' income problems but it would, of course, exacerbate the revenue problems of whatever government happened to be in power by something a good deal more than the direct and assessable cost of rebating that excise to farmers. That means rebating to farmers excise on petrol. Anybody who knows anything about agriculture-I had more than 20 years direct experience in it-knows that the amount of petrol used on farms in agricultural production is negligible. So this is a straight out proposition to squander about $137m by giving a rebate for which there can be no logical or economic justification; it would also set up a huge black market to boot. Even in the heyday of McEwenism in the 1960s-when McEwenism was running rampant-the coalition governments of that period would not cop that rort. But it is being promised by this most irrespon- sible leader that the Liberal Party has ever had.

ANSWER.PARA: Among other promises were full fuel freight equalisation, extension of the rural adjustment scheme, removal of the sales tax on wine, removal of the excise on brandy, the abolition of export inspection charges, tax benefits on income equalisation deposits, first year write-off for expenditure on water conservation and the removal of sales tax on oils and lubricants. I think I could do no better than to summarise this as a wish list of political promises which was the sort of term that the Leader of the Opposition used a couple of weeks ago in his speech at the National Press Club. He said that he was not there to deliver a wish list of political promises. That is precisely what he is doing in this policy area as in so many other areas. It would blow out the deficit--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have not sought to have this question declared out of order because the Minister is making a public comment on matters which relate to public policy for which he is responsible. He is continually misrepresenting the status of the paper which it is known-it has been published-has not been approved as a policy document. It has been drafted as a policy draft for discussion. I think that the Minister is continually misrepresenting the status of the document when he is answering the question.
—There is no point of order. I ask the Minister, in completing his answer, to bear in mind that he was asked to comment on the cost of the items.

—The total cost of the items is above $500m. If one were to throw in the promise to abolish the assets test that amount becomes almost $700m. Incidentally, let me correct a slight error I made a while ago: `a shopping list of political goodies' was the phrase that Mr Howard used. He said that that is exactly what he would not deliver but that is what he has done. In view of Senator Chaney's repudiation of that document as a policy document, I invite Senator Chaney, Mr Sinclair, Mr Hunt, Mr Howard or any other Opposition person in a senior position, who cares to clarify this point for us, to state which of the specific promises I have read out the Opposition will repudiate and which it will stick by.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the refusal of mine workers at Broken Hill to comply with an interim award handed down by Justice Fisher. Is the Government aware of the effect this industrial dispute will have not only on Broken Hill but also on Broken Hill Associated Smelters which employs some 1,480 workers in Port Pirie and which, of course, is reliant on ore from Broken Hill? What action will the Government take to ensure compliance with the award noting that it has condemned businessmen for advocating breaches of the law in recent days and that the Government subscribes to our highly centralised industrial relations system and the strict application of our rigid award system?

—As I understand it, the earlier part of Senator Hill's question is quite correct, that is, that if the mines at Broken Hill were to close there would be serious employment ramifications in South Australia as well as in Broken Hill. But I am not sure that the unions are actually breaking the law. I do not claim to be an expert in this area but, as I understand it, they may be behaving recklessly or foolishly but are not actually breaking the law. So that part of the question, if I am correct, is not applicable. As to the more general question, I have no briefing on this so I can do nothing better than refer it to Mr Willis to see what comments he has to make.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to South Africa's raids on three of its neighbours, Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe, all members of the Commonwealth. What is the Government's view of the Eminent Persons Group process? What action will the Government take to indicate to South Africa Australia's attitude towards these raids?

—The Government has condemned the raids in the strongest possible terms. The Cabinet will consider the implications of the raids and of other developments in South Africa at an early date. Mr Fraser has been in touch with the Prime Minister to discuss the work of the Eminent Persons Group. The two of them have agreed that the South African Government's action has seriously damaged the prospects of the EPG but that it would be premature for the group to abandon its work at this stage. The only way that any hope for negotiations can be sustained is for the South African Government to take decisive, credible action in indicating to South African blacks and to world opinion that it is sincerely prepared to dismantle the apartheid system. There is very little time left to take such action. In the event that the EPG mission fails, tougher concerted international action will be necessary against South Africa. As it has to date, the Government will play an active role in pursuing that objective.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PATENT, TRADE MARKS AND DESIGNS OFFICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Science. Can the Minister confirm that there has been no response to the report of the industrial property advisory committee inquiry into the Australian Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office, despite its having been with the Government for almost two years? Can the Minister confirm that the present delay in the processing of patent applications is 33 months, and two years for trade-marks? Can the Minister confirm that the cost of registering a patent in Australia is now almost the highest in the world? Does the Minister agree that the Government is pursuing a contradictory approach to industry policy when on the one hand it provides incentives for research and development and then places on industry the dual burden of high costs and enormous delays when it comes to register new products and processes?

—I was not specifically aware of the delay to which Senator Archer refers. I will refer his question to the Minister for Science and ask for some explanation for the delay. If what the honourable senator says is correct, I agree with him if the implication in his question is that there seems to be an inconsistency between the practice in the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office and the Government's general initiatives in this area. I recollect a conversation quite recently with an officer of the Patent Office in which, as I recall it, he told me that delays were of that order but that that was not abnormal in the history of the Patent Office. But that may be wrong. If I may say so, the question warrants a detailed answer from the Minister and I will seek that and give it to Senator Archer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: POSTING OF MEDICINES TO THE UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of allegations that the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has a policy of not accepting medicines posted from the West, and that attempts by Australian-Ukrainians to mail medicines to their Soviet counterparts in the wake of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster have proven unsuccessful? Can the Minister indicate whether the Australian Government knows the reason for any such policy and whether any action can be taken by our Government to assist those suffering in the affected areas?

—The Government is aware of difficulties that have been experienced by members of the Australian-Ukrainian community in attempting to send medicines to friends and relatives in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. It is our understanding that, as a result of regulations introduced some years ago by the Soviet authorities, all imports by mail of medical supplies into the USSR are banned. The Australian Government is investigating the implications that this ban may have for those affected by the Chernobyl accident and will certainly keep in touch with Ukrainian community organisations that have expressed concern.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows his light-hearted suggestion that he would oppose changes to the fringe benefits tax to try to achieve a better success rate. I ask: Is it a fact that the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd, General Motors-Holden's Ltd and Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd have all made representations on the basis that, if the tax proceeds, there will be a significant downturn in vehicle sales for the remainder of 1986 which will lead to a shedding of a significant number of employees. Is it also a fact that the automobile component manufacturers, the retail motor traders and affected unions have made similar representations concerning their industries? Can the Minister tell the Senate what number of jobs he believes could be lost if the tax on the motor vehicle industry is implemented in the way proposed?

—I have answered this question, wheeled forward in different guises, about 25 times this year, and I will have another go at it. I have no doubt that all of those people have made representations to Government, to the Opposition, to the Australian Democrats and to everybody else that they can bump into in the pub or anywhere else, about the effects of the fringe benefits tax. But, as I have said on numerous occasions, some of the prognoses and predictions by sections of the automotive industry about the effects of the fringe benefits tax are quite bizarre. I refer particularly to the sorts of predictions that have been made from time to time by the Australian Automotive Dealers Association and which were made prior to the South Australian election, I recall. I have said on a number of occasions in this place that there will be a downturn in vehicle industry production in 1986. That is not surprising because 1985 was a record year and 1984 was another record year-basically a response to good economic management. There were record years for the automotive industry in 1984 and 1985 and there will inevitably be a downturn in 1986. That will be exacerbated by a number of things-a pull forward of orders of vehicles into the last quarter of 1985 as a result of the introduction of unleaded petrol from 1 January 1986.
—We all know this. I asked you specifically what is the effect of the tax.

—High interest rates in the first quarter of 1986 will also have a detrimental effect on the motor vehicle market, as will in some ways the effect of the devaluation. Senator Chaney interjects and says that he knows all this and that what he wants to know is what the effect of the tax will be. As I have said on a number of occasions, I cannot quantify the effects of the tax. I have said on many occasions here-I do not change what I say-that I believe the tax, in the context of 1986 and the other factors that I have mentioned, will have a detrimental effect on the vehicle industry if the tax is not changed and on employment in the vehicle industry, but nothing like to the extent that has been suggested in some of the utterances from the various bodies to which Senator Chaney referred.

—I ask a supplementary question. The answer really illustrates why the matter has been raised with the Minister more than once. I did not ask him whether he accepted the predictions of the various bodies that he mentioned. I did not ask him about the effects of other factors on the car market. I specifically asked the Minister to tell the Senate what number of jobs he believes could be lost if the tax is implemented, that is, what number of jobs could be lost because of the tax and the tax alone?

—No, I cannot and I will not because I am not as stupid as some honourable senators opposite. I have seen some of them wander into this place and say: `If the entertainment deduction is taken away, there will be 11,000 or 14,000 jobs lost in the restaurant industry'. I have seen the stupidity of all that. I sit opposite Senator Messner, who told us last year that if there were a wine tax there would be an enormous loss of jobs in the wine industry. I have sat opposite him for two years during these ludicrous predictions from him as the Opposition's spokesman on finance. I will not go down that silly track with those opposite. I do not know the answer. I will not be in the business of speculating.
—Does Mr Bannon know?
—If those opposite are very impressed with Mr Bannon's figures they can rely on them, but they should not rely on mine because I will not give any.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether he saw the report in the Australian newspaper on 26 May 1986 entitled `Kennett calls for study of luxurious dole system'? In that report the Victorian Liberal State Opposition leader, Mr Kennett, stated that Australian taxpayers were asked to support the nation's unemployed, who were the beneficiaries of the world's most luxurious benefit scheme. Mr Kennett went on further to advocate the creation of a task force that would `be empowered to recommend a system that would require those on the dole to contribute constructively to the community through community work'. I ask the Minister: Is this unwarranted attack another attempt to blame the unemployed for their unfortunate plight and is it further evidence that the Liberal Party has nothing but abuse to offer the unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two voluntary schemes-one has been in existence for some time and the other has either commenced or is about to commence-under which the unemployed are given the opportunity to do community work. As I understand it, that is not what Mr Kennett was proposing. He was proposing some sort of compulsory requirement as a precondition for receiving the unemployment benefit for people to do community work for some time. That was a bit nebulous. Mr Kennett was recycling old Liberal Party obsessions and snake oil remedies. His proposition ignores the fact that in order to implement that sort of scheme on a compulsory basis an enormous number of resources have to be put into organisation, supervision and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: It also raises the question that if the work concerned is of real community value and not of the shifting sand from one heap to another and then back in a wheelbarrow type of work for work's sake, why has it not been done already in the public works area? Mr Kennett's suggestion is a variant of the one floated four or six months ago by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, who came out with a magnificent idea of forcing the unemployed to go to educational classes for three days a week. This was presented, although that is hard to believe, as a cost saving measure. If all the recipients of unemployment benefit were forced to spend three days a week in educational institutions, and taking the lowest per capita cost education institutions for people in that age group-the technical and further education colleges-that idea would add $600m a year in outlays on TAFE education. That is how much Mr Howard has considered the question. I suspect that Mr Kennett has given it about as much consideration. Mr Kennett's suggestion ought to be treated in much the same way by the Government as has been Mr Howard's.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time on 8 May, Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question about her passion-fruit people, as I think she called them. I provided an answer but I undertook to get further information. Specifically, the honourable senator asked whether passion-fruit pulp was being dumped or being allowed into the country under some preferential agreement. Examination of recent import trends for passion-fruit products indicates that there was a surge of imports of passion-fruit juice from Brazil in late 1985. These imports were entered at the general rate of duty and to date there has been no complaint of dumping lodged with the Australian Customs Service. Concessional arrangements apply to imports of passion-fruit products through schedule 2 of the South Pacific and Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement, which provides for the duty free entry into Australia of 100,000 litres of passion-fruit pulp per annum.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there has been no increase in imports under the concessional duty from the South Pacific. The surge in imports has come from Brazil. No dumping complaint has been made against imports from Brazil. I remind the honourable senator that if an industry feels that it is adversely affected by imports it can seek a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission for variation of the level of assistance. In conjunction with the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is looking at the possibility of having a reference on the fruit and fruit products industry which would take into account the needs of the passion-fruit processing industry. Mr McKechnie, the Queensland Minister for Tourism, National Parks, Sport and the Arts, wrote to me about this matter and I have replied today in similar terms to the answer which I have given the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that a number of questions today have been quite lengthy and a lot of detailed information has been given in them thus, in many instances, requiring in return long answers by Ministers. I ask honourable senators to look at the length of their questions and the amount of information given in them so that a greater distribution of questions will be able to be allotted at Question Time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, contingent upon clauses 5 to 9 inclusive, 19 to 26 inclusive and 44 to 47 inclusive of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986, or any of those clauses, being negatived in Committee of the Whole, and the Bill being read a third time, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Messner moving a motion to refer the proposed provisions contained in those clauses to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a disaster for Australia's future balance of trade as repayments, interest payments and dividends paid abroad will continue to rise. Australia's high interest rates domestically exacerbate the problem. This continued high inflow of foreign money artificially supports the Australian dollar at a level which makes our exports more and more uncompetitive on world markets. Approximately 71 per cent of the total expected foreign investment approved in 1984-85 will be spent on the acquisition of existing businesses. Less than 30 per cent will be invested in new business. In real terms, foreign takeovers of existing businesses have continued to rise, from less than $1000m in 1977-78 to about $2,200m in 1984-85. Most of these take- overs are in the service industry-hotels and accommodation-and in the finance and insurance industries where we have introduced 16 new banks.

SPEECH.PARA: The major reason given by local businesses selling out to foreign interests was liquidity problems, a demonstration of the bankruptcy of the Liberal-Labor monetary policies of the last 10 years. In fact, the major reason is the failure of the policies of successive governments. As these takeovers were associated with only a small proposed expansion of business output, it is obvious that high local interest rates and poor management were mainly responsible for the loss of Australian equity in its businesses. We will need to face the problem of buying back the farm. Foreign investment in the manufacturing and mining industries is declining. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard table 3.3 of the report to illustrate my point.
