TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This table reflects the fact that the industrial production boost to the economy in 1982-84 is fast waning under the continued mismanagement of various governments. Of the total $1,050m spent in taking over Australian manufacturing businesses, only a further $50m will be spent on additional development. We must ask ourselves whether these takeovers are really in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Investment in mining is also declining. Peak investment was in 1982-83 and was 17 times higher than that of seven years earlier, and in two years averaged only 1.3 times the figure of 10 years ago. On the other hand, finance, property and service businesses are being bought out holus bolus. The funds involved in buying out were 22 times more in the last year than was the case 10 years ago. A large part of this increase is due to the entry into Australia of foreign banks.

Our balance of trade deficit is growing exponentially. Our overseas markets are being eroded by our closest allies who are flagrantly breaching the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreement on trade practices and protectionism. The Government is fiddling about with fringe taxes and fringe issues while the whole of our trade is going down the drain because the investment that is coming into Australia is buying up our businesses and not creating new productive capacity. All of this is obvious from the report. I commend a very close reading of the report to Government members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1984-85 report of the Foreign Investment Review Board is a report of the body, established in 1976, which is charged with the responsibility of screening foreign investment proposals for Australia. It not only examines proposals put forward by investors but also advises the Government on courses of action that should be taken in respect of those proposals and makes recommendations in the ultimate case as to whether foreign investment proposals for Australia should be allowed or disallowed. One of the Board's important guidelines is to work for high levels of Australian equity and participation in new investment projects in this country. One of the perspectives taken by conservative politicians in Australia is that foreign investment is vital to our economy. On a number of occasions in recent years conservative politicians throughout Australia have indicated that the ability of our country to attract foreign investment was a sign of economic health, economic confidence and economic well being. We have seen scaremongering campaigns in recent Australian elections when allegations have been made by conservative politicians that the election of a Labor government would scare off investors in our country and that all kinds of proposals would be scrapped as a result of the election of a Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984-85 the Board considered some 1,286 proposals for investment in Australia. Of those proposals, some 1,252 were approved and, of those approved, 482 were subject to some sort of qualification. Total expected investment foreshadowed in those proposals was around $4,600m-a very substantial sum. The services sector was the leading area of foreign investment activity, both in terms of the number of proposals approved and total investment expenditure. There was also increased foreign investor activity in Australian manufacturing industry.

As I have pointed out, conservative politicians make great play of foreign investment in our country. I want to highlight some figures which appear on page 54 of the latest annual report of the Foreign Investment Review Board and which relate to new investment, which is the most important economic element of foreign investment in our country and which has the potential to add to wealth and productive power, as distinct from investment known as `consideration' which involves simply the buying and selling of existing assets, whether they be shares, real estate or whatever. New investment is much more important. It is very interesting to look at the table which appears on page 54 of the report and which indicates that in Queensland there has been a massive slump in new investment by foreign investors. For example, according to the 1983-84 annual report, there was $499m of new foreign investment in Queensland. In the current year under review, 1984-85, there was a mere $207m of new investment. So the foreign investment proposals for that State have been more than halved in a 12-month period. Queensland now receives some 13 per cent of new investment proposals from overseas, which compares with its 16 per cent share of Australia's population. So, on the criteria used by conservative politicians, certainly a lack of confidence in the Queensland economy is being shown by foreign investors. They are staying away in droves. Foreign investment in Queensland has been more than halved in a 12-month period. This reflects the very poor economic climate in Queensland, which is exemplified by a whole range of economic indicators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to congratulate the Foreign Investment Review Board on its 1984-85 report. The report is very detailed and sets out clearly the degree of foreign ownership of our industries in this country. The question of whether we are going to allow our industries to be taken over by foreign interests has been an issue since 1970. In fact, it was on that issue that I first became involved in politics. The establishment of the Foreign Investment Review Board undoubtedly was a milestone in slowing down the degree of penetration by foreign interests in Australian wealth-producing industries. The Board is doing a valuable job. One would hope that the present Government is giving the Board the degree of support and encouragement its important task requires. One wonders about this from time to time because the Government has brought down guidelines which, to some degree, lessen the effect and authority of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no room for complacency about this issue whatsoever. If we turn to the report we find that over the last decade, for instance, Australian ownership of our mining industries has dropped from 50.5 per cent to 49.6 per cent. One may say that that is not a big reduction in Australian ownership over a decade. I say that there has been no turnaround. We are not yet buying back the farm. That seems to me to be the important issue. Why should more than 50 per cent of our mining enterprises be owned by foreign interests? Australians defend the country. One would think that the minerals in our soil should belong to Australians; yet 50 per cent of those minerals belong to foreign interests. Is that a good situation, with our balance of payments the way it is? Thirty per cent of our exports are going to pay the interest bill on money we have borrowed and a lot of that money is being used to take over our wealth producing industries. One would have thought that the overwhelming percentage of our manufacturing industries should be owned by Australian capital. Who should own the means of producing in this country? This report says that there has been a slow-down in the penetration by foreign ownership of manufacturing, but still only 67 per cent of our manufacturing industries are owned by Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Superannuation will help that.

—Thank you, Senator Ray. I was about to come to that. The Australian Democrats are supporting an initiative of superannuation for all. This will release enormous amounts of money in the form of savings of Australians, which, if we are far seeing enough, could be invested in buying back the farm. I hope that that will be done. If it is not, we can be sure that Australians will be colonised just as surely as they were in the beginning. Why defend the country if all that has to happen is that foreign money comes into this country and buys out our ownership of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When one examines the high level of approvals compared with the total number of applications, one could well ask why we have the Foreign Investment Review Board today, because it is departing very much from the original charter under which it was set up. Given the Australian Labor Party Government's attitude of lack of interest and concern for small business and for the ownership and control of Australian resources and businesses, it is not surprising that we find another instrumentality being manipulated by the Government. I refer to the Foreign Investment Review Board, which is losing its independence and is becoming quite impotent as far as the discharge of its responsibilities is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Given Australia's chronic balance of payments situation, we are becoming increasingly dependent upon an inflow of debt capital and equity capital, which means that the ownership and control of Australian resources is moving increasingly overseas, outside the control of ordinary Australians. The great disappointment is the very low ownership by individuals of shares on the Australian stock exchanges. We should well ask: Where is the fulfilment of the Labor Party's pledge of buying back the farm? Its policies of deregulation and everything else are certainly encouraging overseas capital and enterprises to buy into the most profitable of Australian resources.

One alarming feature at present is the take- over battles that are taking place in Australia. The extent to which foreign funds are flowing into Australia, albeit at times to finance some of the millionaires of Australia in their battles to take over Australian major companies, is frightening. The consequence of their action in borrowing abroad is to raise the debt repayment problems even further, to put us further into hock. I believe that the time is not far off before some of these giants in their takeover battles will bite off more than they can chew. We will find in a very short while that they will have to sell off large chunks of big Australian enterprises simply to meet their debt obligations. I think this will be a major tragedy.

There is a view, however, that the presence of the Foreign Investment Review Board actually discourages equity investment in favour of debt capital. When one examines the track record of the FIRB, it seems to be letting in all enterprises, except one or two which do not seem to be politically desirable. In relation to its past track history, that record does not apply. It concerns me that some enterprises have been allowed into this country for the purpose of exporting their partly produced products to their overseas subsidiaries. What is happening now is that a lot of these enterprises which were allowed in on a restricted basis are expanding their tentacles at the expense of small, privately owned companies in Australia. We are seeing an increase in the debt repayments because companies are investing in Australia and creating a debt repayment situation, regardless of the profitability of the enterprise. I believe that this is detrimental to Australia. I am one who would favour increasing the ownership and control of resources by Australians for the benefit of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to make some comments on the report of the Foreign Investment Review Board in relation to investment in the mining and minerals exploration industry. The report reveals the deterioration that has occurred in that industry and its attractiveness to foreign investment, bearing in mind that we are talking about investment in the ownership of Australian resources in the minerals and exploration sectors. The number of proposals for investment fell from 173 in 1983-84 to 132 in 1984-85; a decline of nearly 25 per cent. Investment in those projects fell from over $1 billion in 1983-84 to $450m in 1984-85. Investment in new projects fell from $250m to $150m; a decline of 40 per cent. Those figures show an alarming decline in the attractiveness of investment in the Australian mining industry. A combination of factors is involved there, but largely it is due to Australia's high and still increasing costs, particularly labour costs, increasing regulation and increasing taxation. A further example is the fringe benefits tax proposals of the Government which will further add to the costs and will act as a further disincentive to investment in the mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that stands out like a beacon in this report is that virtually the only major investments-even though investments are declining-in new projects have been in the gold mining industry in the period under review. It is further to be noted that the Government is proposing, and I think hoping, to introduce a tax on the gold mining industry before very long. It set up an inquiry into the industry last year when the Western Australian election was coming up, obviously for political purposes. It is to be hoped that that report will indicate reasons why the industry should not be taxed, but I fear that whatever the report may reveal the Government is hell bent on taxing that industry. It would be consistent with this Government's attitude to the mining industry. The Government sees it as simply a never ending source of revenue. So for those reasons, amongst others, there has been a decline in the attractiveness of the industry. As soon as the Government sees a profitable mining industry, such as the gold mining industry, it is hell bent on recovering further revenue from it. I do hope that the Government will ponder this matter in the light of the startling statistics that appear in the report and completely reject any notion of taxing that industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the 1984-85 report of the Foreign Investment Review Board. I want to say just a few words before adjourning the debate. I point out first that the Board is not involved in an examination of investments being made by Australians when they are borrowing overseas to finance Australian takeovers. I refer in particular to the current proposals by Mr Holmes a Court and the Bell organisation. The Foreign Investment Review Board, as I understand it, is not involved in any examination of where he is obtaining the funds for the proposed takeover. The Board's first function is:

SPEECH.PARA: to examine proposals by foreign interests for investment in Australia and make recommendations to the Government on these proposals;

The rapidly changing outlook for industry and investment in Australia generally requires a revision of our attitudes toward foreign investment. Clearly a policy appropriate for the 1970s with its climate of companies virtually queuing up to invest in Australia is not necessarily right for the late 1980s. Moreover, it is becoming increasingly apparent that existing foreign investment policy discourages direct investment and encourages overseas borrowing, thus adding to the level of our overseas debt. A strong case therefore exists for either scrapping or significantly scaling down our existing foreign investment restrictions. This issue is receiving close attention in the Opposition's policy review.

The now thoroughly discredited Treasurer, Mr Keating, has actually got around to admitting what economists have being saying for a long time, that is that the Australian economy is now in crisis. That admission provides a strong argument for the Foreign Investment Review Board adopting a more flexible and relaxed policy. Let me give the Senate an example. If I have a business which I think is worth about $4m in assets but is in fact on its way to going broke and some foreign company likes to come in and offer me $6m, of course it is to my advantage and to Australia's advantage for me to sell the business to this company, as it may be able to use its expertise to make the business profitable, and I have $6m firstly to pay off my liabilities and secondly to go on and invest in some other project in the nation. It is not that the foreign company comes in and closes down the Australian organisation, sacks Australian workers or does anything like that. In fact, the foreign investment in Australia encourages this economy to grow, not to stagnate as has been suggested by some previous speakers in this debate. I put it to the Senate that the immediate relaxation of foreign investment restrictions would help to stimulate direct investment from abroad and the capital inflow would help to reduce our overseas debt. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON AN AUSTRALIA CARD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Aulich:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card for the work it has done in compiling its report. Some of these joint committees are valuable exercises because of the data they accumulate, and the access they give to the public on some of these issues does much to develop views on these subjects. However, I have to say that when it comes to the actual analysis of the data and the coming up with the recommendations the results tend to be predetermined. Any time we set up a select committee members of such a committee take in their existing prejudices; they look for evidence to support their views, and that is what comes out at the other end. That is why I am not particularly fazed that this Committee has brought down a majority report opposing the Government's proposed Australia Card. I think quite often those pre-existing views come through.
—They did in the minority report, too.

—Looking at the personnel on the Committee, I could have told Senator Puplick months ago that he would oppose the Australia Card. Such a dilettante, fairy floss civil libertarian is impelled to oppose the Australia Card. There is no doubt of that. I also had no doubt that even one of my colleagues, who was very voluble on the issues before he was put on the Committee, would continue to oppose the introduction of an Australia Card.
—And vice versa.

—I have no doubt that vice versa applies. At least I give credit to a couple of the members, who may have had pre-existing views, for turning up to all meetings. It is unforgivable for members not to turn up to meetings. I refer particularly to one member, who shares committee membership with me on another committee and never turns up there and barely turned up to this Committee yet he has come out with conclusions that are supposed to have some credibility. I am not a blunt enough person to mention the person's name. One regrettable aspect was that this Committee leaked like a sieve. Committee members shot their mouths off on the issues well before the report came down. It is obvious that the report was leaked substantially to the newspapers.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a period in which a lot of civil liberties are under attack. We must acknowledge that. With the sorts of views currently being expressed on telephone tapping and other things, one would not normally embrace a proposal that some people might argue has a potential to inhibit people's civil liberties. But I stress that identity cards like the Australia Card exist in many other free and democratic societies around the world. They also exist in totalitarian societies. I just make the point that a national identification system is not necessarily totalitarian, and is compatible with a free and democratic society. I also warn that unless the Government takes some action to set up a national identification system, a ramshackle de facto identification system will emerge in this community. With the increasing use of computers, with the use of all sorts of credit cards and card identification, a ram- shackle de facto system is already evolving, with no protection for the individuals concerned.

The key word in this debate is protection-not just protection of civil liberties but protection of the average citizen in this country. Australia's citizens have to be protected against things like tax evasion, against cheating of the social security system. Every time the social security system is cheated it falls into more and more public disrepute and the victims, those who are in need of social security, are then open to ridicule as being some sort of bludgers or cheats. No government can stand by and watch that continue. I believe also, on the question of illegal immigration, that a proper national identification system would reduce the number of illegal immigrants in this country. Everyone in this chamber has had people ask why they cannot get a relative or an employee into the country. One of the reasons is that there are 60,000 queue jumpers in Australia already.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could put a one in front of that, at least.

—We do not really know how many are here, do we? They are all queue jumpers. They all come here unscreened and they do not meet any of the criteria. The people we are penalising are those poor people who go through the system, apply properly and maybe miss out by one or two points. That has to be stopped.

SPEECH.PARA: I was rather impressed by some of the evidence which went to the issue of having a smart card which contained certain central data information and which could have optional information put on it by the holder of the card. That has great ramifications in the medical area. People such as me who are allergic to penicillin could have that information put on their Australia Card so that at any particular time that medical information could be released if a particular key code was used. I think that would be a marvellous thing and I note the support from some of the medical profession for this proposal.

Let us come to the guts of the argument. Why have a photo? It all goes to the question of how much integrity the card would have. I have noted that at least the majority report argued for a tax file card number but, having read some of the evidence which the Committee looked at, I am not convinced that that card would have enough integrity. It would run the danger of being forged or misused.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think the Australia Card is going to have?

—An Australia Card with a photo would tend to have far more integrity than a card with a tax file number. We are facing a situation where it is possible, as argued in the minority report, that the Government would receive something like an extra $8 billion over 10 years. That is a fairly revealing figure. I also think it reveals why some parts, but not exclusively all parts, of the Opposition would be very keen to stop an Australia Card. The civil libertarian argument tends to be a smokescreen. What the Opposition really wants to do is to put as much pressure as possible on this Government, deprive it of as much revenue as possible and then see what the gas cooker comes up with. By cutting us off at both ends, by arguing continually for increased expenditure across a whole range of areas and then trying to cut off all avenues of raising money, the Opposition thinks something has to give somewhere, which will give it the opportunity to sneak back into government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to move on to two or three other points. No national identification system could be tenable if the bureaucrats were just allowed to go out and organise it without the Government putting some key protections in place. I am a very strong supporter of the concept of a national data protection authority that would oversee the Australia Card and similar cards and protect the privacy of individuals. If the Government does go on with the proposal for an Australia Card and in fact gets it through both chambers, it is essential that certain restrictions be placed on its use; that is, that it will not be compulsory to carry it at all times, that it has no direct police function at all--

TALK.START.PARA: —So far.

—Not so far. There is always the thin end of the wedge argument, is there not? It is always the good little scary thing to bring up. If Senator Haines is really going to argue that this is going to have a police state function, she is arguing that fundamentally society in this country has changed, and I do not believe it has. I am critical of the report in one area. That area relates to the restricted use of the card. I urge very strongly for one more extended use of the card over and above the recommendations of the minority report, and that is its use by the Australian Electoral Commission. We already have an agency in this country which collects names, nine million of them, gives them a number, not a unique number, records people's addresses and publishes those details. It seems to me that if we had an Australia Card we could well have more integrity in the electoral rolls in this country by giving the Electoral Commission access to the system.
—It specifically rejected it.

—It may have specifically rejected it, but it is not infallible. That is why we determine the electoral laws and that is why Senator Puplick has to put submissions to joint committees, as he once did, on how to reform the electoral laws. I should have thought that he would understand that. We determine what the laws are and what is best. The Commission may have rejected it. It may not have given it proper consideration. But I would say that it is very logical that a group that collects nine million names should also have access to this system.

SPEECH.PARA: In winding up my remarks, I congratulate all members of the Committee on the work they did, especially my colleague Senator Aulich, who I do not think missed a meeting. I know that he undertook a very heavy workload. If this Committee had been a royal commission the report would have been another two years down the track and it would have cost $5m. Instead, we sent eight parliamentarians away to investigate this matter. They got this massive report done in record time and they came up with a very poor majority report and a brilliant minority report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I detect not only certain vested interests in the comments of Senator Robert Ray but also a sort of defensive cynicism as well.
—Factional loyalty is a lovely thing.

—As Senator Puplick says, factional loyalty is a wonderful thing but it does not always mean that the views of Senator Robert Ray are necessarily those of the majority of members of his Party. There was, of course, an indication of that when the majority report came down because it was not a majority report that consisted of the views simply of members of Opposition parties; it consisted of the views of members of all parties, including the Government party which were represented on the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference were set up late last year on consultation with all political parties and they covered a wide range of things, including the costs of introducing and operating the system which the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) was then advocating and which, despite all the evidence that should have sent him down a contrary track, he is still advocating. The terms of reference covered the likely effectiveness of the proposed system as far as combating things such as evasion of and fraud against the tax and welfare systems, the method of obtaining positive identification of the individuals who were applying for the card, abuses of civil liberties and invasions of privacy and, more importantly, the comparative cost effectiveness of alternative proposals that would just as well combat the evasion of and fraud against the tax and welfare systems that I think everybody in this place, in the other place and in the community generally is so opposed to.

The Committee went on to look at other things, such as whether the card or an alternative should be universal and/or compulsory, what sort of facilitation of data linkages would be allowed and what protections there would be in that area. As Senator Robert Ray said-it is probably the only valid comment he made in his entire 10 minutes-the Committee put in quite an heroic effort, as did those people who made submissions to it and appeared before it. The evidence before the Committee was overwhelmingly that not only was an Australia Card of the sort proposed by the Government and by the Minister for Health not necessary but also that there were other ways of achieving an end or at least a mitigation of fraud against the various systems we have in this country that would be more cost effective, less invasive and less open to abuse than the system that the Government was talking about.

The Government believes, probably rightly, that it has the general public on its side, mostly because the public was not party to the sort of information the Committee was and because the public, even more than the Australian Labor Party, is more subject to the prejudices that are spread around this place. Social security fraud and overpayment and tax fraud, as all the evidence before the Committee indicated, come mainly from the understatement of incomes-for example, from not declaring income in the cash economy and from the non-declaration of interest. Aside from that, the only major component was outright criminal defrauding and that, practically everybody said, was not going to be touched by something like an Australia Card since the confirmed criminal, whether he is a dedicated professional or just an enthusiastic amateur, is going to have the resources and the inclination to get around the system.

As far as the main losses are concerned-that is, losses from the cash economy and from the non-declaration of bank interest-most witnesses pointed out what I would have thought was patently obvious, that is, that the cash economy is not going to be picked up simply by having everybody processed and given a card with or without a photograph, thumbprint or computer chip in the top left hand corner. There are a great many people in this chamber as well as in the community who hire people and pay them cash to do a variety of things, such as cleaning houses, mowing lawns and putting up pergolas out the back. In most cases they pay them in cash. It is known who they are, where they live and what their telephone numbers are. The mere provision of a card is not going to make the person who receives the cash necessarily declare it, and the Government knows that as well as the rest of us.

In regard to the non-declaration of interest on bank accounts, the majority report recommended a high integrity tax file number which had to be appended to bank accounts and used for other financial transactions, applications for jobs, social security payments and so on. It would settle, as the Australian Taxation Office admitted, a large amount of this simply by adding the incentive to declare interest earned by insisting that those bank accounts which did not have a tax file number appended to them would suffer a fairly hefty withholding tax. There are indeed other measures which do not have the sorts of invasion of privacy problems through data linkages that the Government proposal has.

People in the community argue that those who have nothing to hide have nothing to fear. One sometimes wonders whether they know how much information is on file in government departments that they would prefer other people not to know. There is information on everybody's health problems going back into the past. There is information on the sort of education we have had, where we have travelled overseas, our ethnic background, how much money we have and where we have it, what social security payments we are on or have been on in the past. All that information is stored already in various government departments. At the moment it is accessible only by accredited officers within those departments and under very rare circumstances some exchange of information is permitted, but it is fairly heavily overseen with protections.

Once one moves into the sort of system that the Government is proposing, it would be much easier to exchange that information not only with other departments but with the State governments which want to get involved. I am sure that there are large numbers of people in the community who have had health problems of one sort or another but who do not need to have that spread around the community or given to a State Public Service Board when applying for a job.

The logistical problems of the proposal which the Government is planning to go ahead with willy-nilly, notwithstanding the evidence contrary to its statements and the likely problems it will hit when the proposal reaches the Senate, are enormous. For a start, it is useless having an Australia Card or any other form of national identification system which is based on identifying data which, to begin with, is of low integrity. We all know the problems that arise with the ease of access people have to birth certificate information which is not their own, to which they are not entitled and which they can use to have passports, drivers licences and other items supplied. We have recently in this place had to tighten up the passport legislation simply because of the problems in the births, deaths and marriages registries in this country. Until those are fixed up, there is no point whatsoever in moving to a national identity system in this country which of necessity will be low integrity.

The logistics involved even in getting the births, deaths and marriages up to scratch are quite horrendous. It will take months simply to get the hardware and the appropriate software organised and in place. That is assuming that the Minister for Health is right and that States are infinitely bribable and will go on with this proposal anyway. It then takes another minute per entry. I presume that we are not starting from 1986, and that if we want to get these up to scratch, we will have to go back at least 70 years. If we are looking at social security and tax fraud, heaven only knows how long that will take. It will then be necessary to process 10 to 12 million Australians, at 10 to 15 minutes an interview and photograph and that little exercise will take between 18 months and two years. Therefore, the logistics and costs are enormous. It would be far simpler, more sensible and just as effective to take the majority report in hand, to make the integrity of the tax file number higher and to rationalise, nationalise and computerise the births, deaths and marriages system.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the Taxation Office say about that?

—The Australian Taxation Office recognises that a high integrity tax file number under its suggestions would raise as much money as would an Australia Card without a photograph. Its objections were minimal at best. I understand that my time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Robert Ray.
—Surprise, surprise!

—I support his remarks often within and without the Parliament, and I do so again today with pleasure. I have read with interest the speech made by Senator Puplick in this place on this issue, and I have just listened with even more interest to Senator Haines. Although I congratulate both honour- able senators on their capacity to dress up the impossible in the nicest way, I must say that both speeches add up, as have previous speeches by them in this place, to yet another defence of the tax avoidance of Australia. Once again, we see another opportunity ready to be thrown aside and cast away because they cannot let anybody get near their friends in the industry.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I believe that the Standing Orders afford to both Senator Haines and me some degree of protection from the comment of being friends with or having friends in the tax avoidance industry. The remark is improper and I think that it should be withdrawn.

—Further to the point of order: I would be the first in normal circumstances to support Senator Puplick in this regard, except that on numerous occasions in this place remarks of that type from the opposite side have been accepted, and I dare say will continue to be accepted until we change the Standing Orders. That being the case, I submit that the Chair is bound to ignore the point of order.
—Order! It would be improper for a member of parliament to be a friend of tax avoiders. Therefore, the imputation is out of order and Senator Richardson should withdraw it.

—If that be your ruling, Mr Deputy President, I withdraw. I would hate to give offence. However, If I may continue my remarks, when the crunch comes there is no doubt that some people in the Australian Democrats and all members of the Liberal Party and National Party have shown a propensity over time to defeat legislation introduced by the Government that attempts to get at the heart of the problems of tax avoidance and tax evasion. Once again when the crunch comes we are seeing yet another example of this. Senator Haines said that the mere provision of a card would not affect the cash economy; it will not necessarily make people declare income. That of course avoids the obvious. The obvious thing is that right across our economy people have been lining up for jobs in clubs, shops and all sorts of places under false names and a huge amount of revenue is thereby avoided; thousands and thousands of Australian have managed to avoid their responsibilities. That is one area where an Australia Card would have an immediate and sure effect. Straight away the Government would get the revenue to which it is entitled, and ordinary wage and salary earners across the country would start to shoulder only a fair burden and not the burden of the bludgers who infest this community.

SPEECH.PARA: Having used the word `bludgers', as somebody else did earlier in the debate, I turn to the politics of the dole bludger syndrome. If one goes back over the last six years, one sees that it was started with somewhat of a flurry and fanfare by Malcolm Fraser, that eminent person. It was continued by Mr Peacock and Mr Howard. Mr Ian Cameron, a member of the National Party, in an extraordinary and fascinating speech in another place, took it to new and even greater depths. Having heard all that one can only come to the conclusion that the syndrome of talking up to the Australian electorate the fact that people who are unfortunate enough to be on the dole are in some way an improper encumbrance upon us has become an article of faith among the Liberal and National parties.

The problem is that no one really knows how true this is. One can only ever get estimates as to how much money is being earned improperly from people on false names getting the dole. There is plenty of anecdotal evidence. We have all heard stories of young men going to the beach who manage to get on a surf board every day while collecting seven or eight dole cheques a week, but the reality is that we have no proof. The only way we will ever find that proof is to ensure that there is a proper identity card, with a photograph. People will have to produce that card before they get the dole. If and when we get that, we can find out the truth of all the accusations that the Liberal and National parties have made over the years. I suspect, at the end of the day, while we will certainly find that there has been social security fraud, it will turn out to be nothing like the volume those parties have been suggesting.

I agree with what Senator Robert Ray said. It was pretty obvious from the evidence and from reading the transcript that most of those committee members who went into this Committee did so with preconceived views. I do not necessarily object to that. Senator Puplick is one who holds strong views and he is entitled to them-so am I. Before that Committee started there was only one member of that Committee, Senator Haines, about whom I was unsure. So I had to look through the evidence and the progress of the inquiry to determine the thought processes which would bring Senator Haines to her conclusions. I have to say that Senator Haines did manage to fool me. I missed it again. I have been one of those who have accused the Australian Democrats over the years of jumping from one popular issue to another in that tawdry exercise of chasing votes. Having watched Senator Haines and her colleagues do this for so long, I assumed that because of the overwhelming popularity of the Australia Card she would be with it. I was tempted to go through the will-we or won't-we exercise, that the Democrats often do, to try to work out whether Senator Haines would support it. But in the end, I thought no, it will be the popularity of this issue that will get Senator Haines's hand in the air.

At the end, when we looked at the result, Senator Haines chose to ignore what two-thirds of the Australian people have been saying for two years, and that is that any honest citizen has nothing to fear from an Australia Card with a photograph on it, particularly the card recommended by the minority report. Two-thirds of Australians believe in it. It is because two-thirds of Australians believe in it that this Government has absolutely no fear of bringing the legislation into this Parliament. If Senator Haines is really going to call herself a member of the Democrats, she should pay some respect to the democratic process. If ever the democratic process cried out in this country, it is now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government by opinion poll; is that what you are after?

—We do not have to go to opinion polls; it does not matter whether we go to board luncheons or to trade union groups-in Senator Haines's case I suppose it is whether she goes to a meeting of Friends of the Earth, but in my case I try to travel wider. In travelling wider I discovered that the one thing that unites and concerns Australians at the moment, from the highest to the lowest, from those who dig ditches to those who chair boards, is those people in this country who are bludging and not paying their fair share. They all agree that the card is the only way in which we can begin to tackle the problem. I do not, and nor do the members who signed the minority report, pretend that this is the only answer. The only way we will start to address the problem is to bring in this card. It is for that reason that I commend the minority report to the Senate and hope that more and more honourable senators will come to realise that that is the only way to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise, having waited a few seconds for honourable senators on the other side to speak on this debate. It is very significant that so far we have had Senator Haines from the Australian Democrats, and Senator Puplick on the other side, and that has been it. No one else on the other side of the chamber has been prepared to debate this issue, despite the obvious chances they have had and despite the fact that some in the other House have been prepared to have their say. Those opposite have come to this chamber but have not been prepared to debate. One wonders why that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I look at the role of select committees first. It is important that we have a resume of what the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card was about. We were asked to examine in brief a proposition that was designed to combat illegal immigration, social security fraud and tax cheating; basically the proposition was to give us a fairer system in those particular areas. As everyone knows, select committees always encourage articulate and often powerful and public spirited groups and individuals to come forward. That happened on this occasion with most of the major groups in the community being prepared to come forward and give evidence. Some of it was very good and some was superficial, but all in all the Committee had a pretty fair coverage of most of the major issues.

It is a pity that a number of members of the Committee were prepared to close their eyes before the Committee was set up and during the conduct of the Committee inquiry itself. There was evidence right down the line that these people were not prepared to be moved by the evidence in front of them. That was disappointing to me personally because at no stage am I on record publicly as either supporting or opposing the Australia Card concept. I assiduously avoided giving that impression during the conduct of the inquiry simply because the public is entitled to know that people who are chosen to be on select committees are prepared to keep their eyes open, to at least open their minds to the evidence that comes before them. But on a number of occasions we had a number of committee members prepared to put themselves on public record, in the newspapers and in the electronic media. I guess in the long run that affected the credibility of the Committee as a whole. As I said, I am personally disappointed about that particular process.

There is another group which did not have a say and that is a group which often does not get a say on select committees and in this Parliament as a whole. I refer to the ordinary Australians, the people who struggle to bring up their kids decently, who want to provide their families with a satisfactory style of life and who do not want to be ground down by the system-those who expect a fair go. Those people are the ones who are not heard here. They are the ones who are ignored almost as a matter of principle by the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and some of the Australian Democrats which say, in effect, and I have said it before-that what ordinary Australians think does not matter. I say to those parties that they do count. They do have strong opinions about a fair go and they overwhelmingly support, as all the polls indicate, the concept of an Australia Card with a photograph. Why? They support the proposition because they are not fools. They see the evidence of enormous tax cheating that has been occurring in this country for the last decade. They know that significant groups of people are evading tax through artificially contrived schemes. They know that enormous amounts of money are being made from illegal activities, such as drug importation and insurance and banking frauds. They would have read about the Costigan reports, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group, the McCabe-Lafranchi report, the reports of Special Prosecutor Gyles and other reports that have gone into these particular problems and indicated the massiveness of these illegal activities and the sort of money that is being evaded and hidden away in this community. The ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers or small business people know that they are shouldering the tax burden while others evade their proper responsibilities. They elected this Labor Government to do something about it. They elected us to provide them with a series of proposals to change that.

One of those proposals which has come forward as part of the package of tax reform is the Australia Card proposal. Senator Puplick, to look at a couple of specifics, asked us to examine our consciences, and to examine the figures that were before the Committee. He indicated that the minority report had included, in its assessment of the revenue of $8 billion over 10 years, a figure of $1.2 billion saved by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The honourable senator has seen this as an example of unwillingness on our part to include rubbery figures in our final estimates about the revenue from that Card. In response to that viewpoint, our view, as a minority group on the Committee, was clear and unequivocal. It is this: First, we have assumed that Immigration and Ethnic Affairs figures may well have been generous, but counterbalancing that there is a very good reason to believe that social security fraud may have been much higher than that indicated by the Department of Social Security in its submission. I doubt whether there is one honourable senator in this place who will stand up and guarantee that the current figures for social security fraud are accurate. Is there anyone who believes that the fraud so far discovered is in fact the end of all that; that there is no more to discover. I suggest that there is a counterbalancing of the underestimation in the Department of Social Security versus the over-estimation in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Secondly, we have also assumed that the real value of an Australia Card, in relation to the combating of illegal immigration, is its preventative value, its deterrent value. If an illegal immigrant cannot get a job, cannot claim health care, cannot claim unemployment benefits, the attractiveness of Australia as a country to provide a haven for illegal immigrants will diminish. So it is this deterrent role that we regard as its key value, not its revenue. Ask the workers in the field and the trade unionists what they think of illegal immigration, of people who are prepared to come into this country and work at below award wages, and who are prepared to work in conditions that are not acceptable by the vast majority of Australian working people, let alone the trade union movement. I believe that they will then understand why there is such support for an Australia Card in the community at large.

I return to my original thesis that the Australian community does know about the tax evasion that is going on in this country; it does know about social security fraud and it wants us to do something about it. This Government is doing something about it. We are in the process of altering the tax laws to ensure that fairness and equity are the principles that underpin our tax and social security systems. The Australia Card is an essential part of that reform, a fact which is conveniently forgotten by those on the other side of the chamber who seek to excise the Australia Card from the package of total tax reform. At this stage it is important to finish on this note. There are people who have indicated that they have had enough of tax evasion, of social security fraud and of struggling on the limited incomes that many of them have. They are now saying to this Parliament: `Do something about it. We support the Australia Card concept. We support what the Government is doing in its tax reform measures'. I believe it is about time that those on the other side of the chamber, who so cynically and hypocritically oppose the Australia Card for purposes of their own, ought for once to find themselves in line with what the Australian community wants and let this Senate as a whole reflect what that community wants.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
