SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter relating to the Parliament House Construction Authority although the aspect of the issue to which I wish to refer is not a problem of the Authority specifically. I refer to the construction of the flag-pole which I understand has now been deferred for about 12 months. To go back a little, the problem with the flag-pole relates to the increase in the size of the Parliament House because it is from 1984 that the site has run into particular difficulties and it was then that the Government reached an agreement with the Trades and Labour Council of the Australian Capital Territory to provide accommodation for workers on the Parliament House site. The Government says that it has done this; the Trades and Labour Council says that it has not done it adequately. As a consequence the erection of the flag-pole has been banned. That has gone on from about November until now and to date has cost the Authority approximately $400,000, as I understand it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me point out again that the Parliament House Construction Authority is virtually an innocent bystander on this issue. The dispute is between the Government and the Trades and Labour Council. With the costs escalating as a consequence of the ban on the flag-pole, the Authority had to make a decision and it has now done that. The fact is that, while the large crane remains in its present site, other work on the building cannot proceed. The big crane has to remain on its present site to erect the flag-pole. As a consequence, a considerable amount of the construction and finishing work is being held up. If a decision is made, as it has been, to remove that crane and proceed with the completion of the building, that will enable other things to be done. It will also mean that the Authority will have to make other arrangements for the erection of the flag-pole at a later date.

I understand that to hire a crane large enough to erect the flag-pole once the building is virtually completed will itself cost approximately $200,000. What is possibly the largest crane in Australia will have to be dismantled screw by screw, brought from Victoria to the Australian Capital Territory and reassembled on the site. This will mean that a considerable amount of the landscaping will not be able to go ahead and other external finishing on the building will not be able to be completed. That landscaping and finishing work will have to be done at a later stage, again at considerably increased cost. I suggest that the total cost of this dispute between the Government and the Trades and Labour Council will probably amount to $1m. What I would like to know from the Minister is what the Government is doing to end this dispute with the Trades and Labour Council which is causing this escalation in the price of the Parliament House building. We all know that it is a costly building. Most of us understand the present cost set-up and know why it is so. Only the Australian Democrats cannot work that out and follow the reasoning behind what has occurred.

This specific issue of the dispute between the Government and the Trades and Labour Council, which has gone on now for such a long time, will clearly be responsible for about $1m worth of increased cost on that building. In fact, it may even be more by the time it is all completed. As I have indicated, the Authority has decided to proceed and to put off the erection of the flag-pole for what may be another 12 months. Apparently that is the only way it can avoid the escalating costs at present. But I want to know when the dispute will end, when the Authority will be able to get on with the work that has to be done and when these absurd wastages of cost will come to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to contribute much by way of an answer to Senator Reid's remarks on this subject. The position taken by the Parliament House Construction Authority has been made public. On the face of it, it is a fairly extreme course and one that obviously will be very costly in the long run. But it has been born of frustration with the inability to solve this dispute and the mounting costs from not being able to get access to the central interior part of the building while the crane is sitting there unutilised. Obviously the matter has reached a point of absolute lunacy. I fully accept what Senator Reid has said in this respect. I do not know how the matter will finally be resolved. I gather the dispute is about workers' housing. It ought to be capable of resolution. I will seek further advice from the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) and try to contribute something further to the debate at another time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise matters relating to the lease of certain land on Bowen Island in the Federal territory of Jervis Bay. On 15 April 1985 the Minister for Territories, Mr Scholes, agreed to a recommendation by Mr B. H. Pratt, Assistant Secretary, Land Management, Australian Capital Territory Parks and Conservation Service, that the Minister note the observations made by that officer, recognise the unacceptable record of tenancy by the lessee and approve that, in the interests of expediency and to minimise the anticipated lengthy and unproductive representation which was likely to ensue, further discussion with the lessee be confined to formal notice of lease termination approximately six months prior to the expiry date of 31 December 1985. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the Minute Paper signed by Mr Pratt and Mr Scholes-I have shown this to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is in the chamber-on which has been typed a rebuttal by Mr Pratt of each of the points made by the tenant of this area of land.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Subject:
BOWEN ISLAND-JERVIS BAY TERRITORY
MINISTER
PURPOSES

To advise you on the implications of termination of the lease on Bowen Island in Jervis Bay on 31.12.85 and to recommend that a letter be sent to the lessee giving formal notice of lease termination approximately 6 months prior to that date.
BACKGROUND

2. Bowen Island in Jervis Bay is 51 ha in area and is in a largely unspoilt natural condition with the exception of a holiday development on its western side which includes the only safe landing point. It has significant scientific, conservation and educational values and is entered in the Register of the National Estate. Features include:
coastal vegetation which has developed in isolation from many influences present on the mainland;
a number of archaeologically significant prehistory sites in the form of kitchen middens and rock shelters;
highly fragile penguin and shearwater rookeries;
interesting relics of the Second World War in the form of gun emplacements and bunkers;
intrinsic scenic features of cliffs, rock shelves and isolated beaches.
Rebuttal of Point 2

Apart from penguin rookeries which exist equally within and outside the lease, all other features mentioned occur outside the lease area. The penguins are generally hardy birds which we know easily co-exist with us, which is supported by their continued increase in population from 300 breeding pairs to over 1500 breeding pairs. This is a result of our providing protection from cats, dogs, tuna and lobster fishermen. Hence, most of the major features attributed to Bowen Island already fall under the Department's ability to manage this area. This has not been made clear in this report.
3. Fullers Agencies (Aust) P/L (principal Mr Malcolm Fuller), obtained a lease over the island in 1953.

4. In 1967 the Commonwealth-owned improvements on the island, including the jetty, were sold to the lessee and a new lease for ten years giving tenant rights in the improvements was granted. They are presently valued at $86,000. There are seven residences within the lease area, four of which were constructed for defence purposes during the Second World War. One of these is used to house a caretaker who resides permanently on the island. The remainder are used as holiday venues by Mr Fuller and a consortium of associates.
Rebuttal of Point 4

Valuation was not made in accordance with our tenant rights, so is not correct and substantially under value the real cost to the taxpayer. A professional valuer, McCann Valuations of Canberra, has put the figure at $400,000.

5. The adjacent Jervis Bay Nature Reserve was declared in 1971 and it was intended to include Bowen Island in the reserve on termination of the lease in 1977. This action was recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in 1975 and the Department's intention to do so was reiterated in the Jervis Bay Draft Development and Management Plan published in 1979 (Appendix A), which formed the basis for departmental management policies at Jervis Bay. The Committee also supported the intention of the Department to not grant renewal of the lease when it expired in 1977. As a preliminary to lease termination, the unoccupied portion of the island was withdrawn from lease in 1974. The lease now covers 4.65ha on the western side of the island.

6. Mr Fuller however, pressed for renewal of the lease and made extravagant compensation claims for the area withdrawn. As part of the terms of settlement of this claim, tenant rights on the island, and a new lease, to expire in 1985, was granted in 1979. The new lease incorporated stringent environmental conditions designed to ensure that the lessee met his responsibilities for occupancy of an environmentally significant and sensitive area. A copy of the lease is attached (Appendix B).
Rebuttal of Point 6
By what measure does this officer state our claims to be extravagant. This seems to be a statement by an officer to give the Minister a biased opinion against our current claims.
Stringent conditions within the lease have been met. The Department itself has failed to remove exotic flora despite our requests and which, under the lease, we are banned from removing.

7. Notwithstanding this agreement and Mr Fuller's claims of environmental awareness and appreciation of departmental management objectives for the area, he has failed to achieve acceptable standards of tenancy. The more significant incidents on the Island during the period 1974-1984, some of which are continuing, include:
the improper use of firearms;
improper disposal of garbage and sewage and accumulation of refuse;
removal of and damage of native vegetation;
damage to penguin and shearwater rookeries;
irresponsible fire lighting requiring departmental attendance;
cultivation of undesirable introduced plant species;
inadequate maintenance of grounds;
keeping of dogs on the island.
Rebuttal of Point 7

This officer's accusations are strongly denied by ourselves as having no basis, and we have been refused any opportunity to defend these accusations. This officer's intention is clearly to damage our good record of management. The lessee has not since 1980 received any advice from the Department to alter any management of the Island, which shows clearly this officer's intention to deceive.

8. The only provision within the lease for control of these activities is termination, which is considered to be an extreme measure for any one incident. The lessee was advised in writing on 1.12.80 of deficiencies in his management of the lease area and this had led to a slight improvement in recent years. However, a recent inspection indicates that the situation is still far from satisfactory and unacceptable to the Department.
Rebuttal of Point 8

The officer is quite incorrect to mislead the Minister that the only recourse the Department has available is lease termination. Under the lease document the following sections provide options the Department has at it's disposal to correct any matter.
Section 4 (R), 4 (T) and 4 (V) provide for collection of money as a result of the lessee's failure to maintain the leasehold to the Department's satisfaction.

The problems noted by the Department during the inspection reports of November 1983 and 4th April 1984 were not conveyed to the lessee for his attention. This failure by the Department to perform was not indicated as it should have been to the Minister.

Since 1980, the Department has not, at any time, expressed ``it's dissatisfaction'' of our management, however, if the Department had made any suggestions for improvement we would have been happy to discuss them.

9. The lessee was advised in writing in 1980 that before consideration of lease renewal after 1985 could be entertained, satisfactory observance of the present lease conditions must be undertaken (Appendix C). He was advised also that should the lease be renewed its size would be reduced further.
Rebuttal of Point 9
The advice received in 1980 from the Department was in our opinion completely rectified to the Department's satisfaction at the time. The advice included:
Removal of rubbish: now completed as reported in the Departmental report on 20 June 1985, ``substantially eliminated'' ``a distinct improvement in grounds maintenance''.

Exotic plants were to be removed only under the guidance of the Department as they were suitably experienced, however, the Department has neglected this. It should also be noted that we made a further representation to the Department in 1981 to give guidance at our cost to remove the bamboo, this was not answered.

10. Following the introduction of the Nature Conservation Ordinance in 1982 it became possible to incorporate leases within reserved areas. Consequently action is being taken to declare the whole of Bowen Island, the lease area included, as part of the Jervis Bay Nature Reserve.
Rebuttal of Point 10
The officer failed to make clear that under the nature conservation ordinance in 1982, the Department was able to achieve many of its aims for Bowen Island whilst the leasehold could be continued.

11. The ACT House of Assembly recommended in May 1981 that the lease section of island in question remain under lease unless a resident ranger could be placed on the Island. The Department agrees with this approach and has indicated that on termination of the lease it will station an appropriate officer on the island to supervise public use. A subsequent Report of the Assembly in 1984 again indicated support for the termination of the lease.
Rebuttal of Point 11

Simply, this paragraph makes it clear in the Minister's mind that the Department is to station a full-time ranger upon Bowen Island. This is untrue as there is no plan by the Department to place any full-time ranger on Bowen Island. It does not make it clear that the ACT House of Assembly recommended that our lease be renewed if a full-time ranger was not to be appointed to the Island. This misinformation would certainly lead to the Minister making an unsatisfactory decision.
12. Also attached are:
Attachment D-Lease inspection reports of 24.4.84 and 21.11.80
Attachment E-History of lease administration
Attachment F-Relevant ministerial and departmental correspondence
Attachment G-Map of Bowen Island
Attachment H-Photographic Report
RECOMMENDATIONS
13. It is recommended that you:
(i) note the above information
(ii) recognise the unacceptable record of tenancy by the lessee;

(iii) approve that in the interests of expediency and to minimise the anticipated lengthy and unproductive representation which is likely to ensure, further discussion with the lessee be confined to formal notice of lease termination approximately 6 months prior to the expiry date of 31.12.85.
B. H. Pratt
Assistant Secretary
Land Management
ACT Parks and Conservation Service
Agreed
GORDON SCHOLES
REBUTTAL OF POINT 13
``Recommendations''

The Minister has been recommended to make a decision without giving the lessee any hearing in order to correct any misinformation provided in this report. Such a recommendation can only be viewed with suspicion of an intention to mislead the Minister to make an incorrect decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I want to be careful about any criticism of Mr Pratt. Mr Pratt made a number of recommendations and allegations of which we on the Estimates Committee had some difficulty in ascertaining the veracity. But, of course, we were not cross-examining Mr Pratt. I am not saying that his allegations are right or wrong. I make no criticism of Mr Pratt for performing what he saw as his duty in making the report to the Minister. However, perusal of the rebuttals set out on the paper that I have just incorporated will indicate that the tenant of this area of land has considerable criticism of what Mr Pratt reported to the Minister. At the Estimates Committee hearing doubt was cast on a number of the matters that Mr Pratt recommended or mentioned; in particular, for example, we could find no evidence that the tenant had an unacceptable record. But that is as may be within the duties and responsibilities of an officer of the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is with the Minister's ready acceptance of that report. What has been established is his failure to give the lessee any opportunity to answer the accusations made by Mr Pratt in this report. It is clear when one reads the report that nothing from the tenant is set out. Mr Pratt made a series of allegations; that is obvious in the report. I would have thought that anyone with any sort of an impartial mind who had read the report would wonder whether the tenant ought to be asked whether he wished to rebut those allegations.

I take, for example, Mr Pratt's report about the background of Bowen Island. He talks about Bowen Island in Jervis Bay as having 51 hectares, being a highly fragile penguin rookery and a number of other things. That implies that the lease is for the whole of Bowen Island. But the truth is that the lease relates to only 4 1/2 hectares of the 51 hectares. As far as reference to the highly fragile penguin rookery is concerned, that might appear to indicate that in some way or other the tenant damaged the highly fragile rookery. On a quick, busy Minister's reading of the report, the Minister may have thought that the rookery is being damaged. The truth is that the rookery has grown during the occupancy of these tenants from 300 breeding pairs of penguins to over 1,500. That is the sort of statement by Mr Pratt to which the Minister clearly has not really applied his mind. I criticise the Minister for his failure to give the lessees any opportunity to answer these accusations, either then or since. I claim that the Minister has denied them natural justice. It may well be that in some higher court of the land it will eventually be established that the Minister has denied the lessees natural justice.

As I understand it, the tenants deny the accusations contained in the report by Mr Pratt and present a very persuasive argument that if they had an unacceptable record of tenancy that that would have been documented and communicated to them. There is no evidence of this being the case, of their having been written to by the Department and being told that they ought to do some particular thing or correct some behaviour. The report talks about the growth of certain unacceptable plants, exotics, oleanders and other such plants on the island, but they are growing in the area which is not subject to lease-on land that the Department controls. There really seems to be some reason for the Minister to meet these lessees to give them an opportunity to present their case and to reassess the action which the Department has taken. The Minister will not do that.

I wrote to the Minister on 4 March and sought a report from an independent source in view of the disturbing allegations contained in the representations made to me. The Minister has not yet responded to my letter. It may very well be that the long term objectives for the island might require termination of the tenancy but to my mind the Department has failed to indicate what departmental objectives cannot be achieved while the tenants remain and whether these objectives could not be achieved by phasing out the lease over a much longer period. I indicated the other day to one of the occupiers that the appearance from the mainland of houses erected on the island was a bit higgledy-piggledy and suggested that they could be painted the same colour or have some work done along those lines. It was pointed out that there has been no such suggestion from the Department.

The tenants are completely under the control of the Minister and the Department in that the Minister fixes the terms and conditions of the lease. The area is only 4.5 hectares out of 51 hectares and that area could be reduced even further because the tenants are really interested only in occupying the houses and the immediate surrounds of the houses and in having access to the beach and the jetty. If the Minister or the Department had perhaps required them to effect repairs to either the houses or the jetty, or to repaint or otherwise improve the outlook, the tenants could have done that quite easily and the area of land being occupied may have been reduced.

I am informed that there is no penguin rookery under any of the houses, and that the houses have been there for upwards of 40 or 50 years. The penguins rook around the houses and in the kikuyu grass. It is interesting that the Department keeps talking about removing growth which is non-natural from the area. The most important growth which covers the entire island, in particular the area under the Government's control, is kikuyu grass. The cost of removing it would be enormous. The tenants do not have to leave the island for the Government to start that program if it wishes. The penguins rook in the kikuyu grass which protects their nests. If the Department intends to remove the kikuyu grass, the Department and the Government will be interfering with the penguin rookeries. I asked Mr Turner, the Assistant Secretary of the Department, whether there was any evidence that penguins had not flourished during the lease. He conceded that the penguins had flourished. The Opposition asks the Minister why it is intended to waste this money by ejecting these people. After all, they provide a full time caretaker for the island, making sure that people do not go there and have picnics and toss beer cans and rubbish around the place. The caretaker protects the island from that sort of public vandalism.

The Department can achieve its objects without ejecting the tenants. A much more sensible proposal would be to have negotiations with the tenants instead of taking them to court as the Government has done. The Minister is refusing to answer questions on the basis that the whole subject is sub judice because the Department has taken out ejectment proceedings against these people. The Minister says that he cannot talk or write about the matter. I would have thought that any sensible litigant-and as a former practising lawyer that is the sort of advice that I would have given to my client-ought to be trying to effect a compromise. As far as the responsibilities to the Australian people of a Minister of the Crown are concerned, I would have thought that a sensible Minister would seek a compromise because it is clear that the path that this Government has decided to take under the guidance of the Department clearly will end in the higher courts of the land: These tenants will not just vacate. They will defend the proceedings brought in the Magistrates Court in the Australian Capital Territory. If they fail there they will appeal to higher courts. As I said, eventually they have every chance of winning their case on the basis that they have been denied natural justice.

The sensible thing for the Minister would be to negotiate some compromise and achieve what the Department wants without having to put a permanent ranger on the island. He should allow the tenants some extra period of residence while making it perfectly clear that at the expiration of that period they would voluntarily relinquish their lease and resign. No doubt some compensation could be agreed upon during the negotiations. That would have been the sensible thing for the Minister to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ensure that the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) sees the text of the remarks made on this subject by Senator Lewis but I think his response would be along the lines of the material available to me which is that the lease on block 6 of Bowen Island in the Jervis Bay territory expired in December 1985 and has not been renewed. The decision not to renew the lease is in accordance with the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. The former lessee, Fullers Agencies (Australia) Pty Ltd is, as has been said, disputing the Minister's decision not to renew the lease and has not vacated the land. Action to recover possession has therefore commenced in the Australian Capital Territory Magistrates Court. It would not be appropriate to canvass matters relevant to the legal proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the Minister meeting Mr Fuller to discuss the request for the case to be reviewed, the Minister's position is that he gave very careful consideration to the future of Bowen Island when he made his decision not to renew the lease and when considering subsequent representations from Mr Fuller. His view is that the arguments for and against a private lease on Bowen Island have been more than adequately canvassed and no useful purpose would be served in pursuing the matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, I do not regard the answer given by the Minister as adequate. It is the sort of answer we were given at the Estimates Committee hearing. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has had considerable time since then to have a close look at the matter and be in a position to tell us a bit more about it. Any taxpayer in this country is entitled to know what is being achieved by this action of the Government and how much it will really cost, which will be considerably more than the amount contained in the estimates for this year and which will be an ongoing cost. We have not had an adequate explanation as to why this action is being taken and why the Fullers could not have been left in possession of the island and asked to do some of these things, which they probably would have done. We have not been told why the Minister would not talk to the Fullers and try to seek another solution.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to know what the likely legal costs will be which we, as taxpayers, will have to bear as a result of this stupidity and which, as I said, will be ongoing costs. We are told that there will be a full time ranger on the island, but that that will not really cost anything because there is a spare ranger there now who can do the work. That is also quite absurd. If one thinks about the financial implications of the whole Bowen Island exercise to get back about four acres, one will realise that it is an enormous expense at a time when such expense is not warranted.

No explanation has been given as to why the things that the Department of Territories thinks ought to be done could not have been done by the tenants who were on the island. Who benefits from this action? We are entitled to know. I am sick of being fobbed off with the sort of explanation that is being given. It almost sounds as if the legal action was embarked upon when it was, merely to provide the excuse to hide behind that the matter is now before the courts. Given the legal costs that will be involved-let us face it, there is little likelihood that the matter will not finish up in the Federal Court of Australia, anyhow-we are entitled to have answers to some of these questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Apart from the answers that were given at the Estimates Committee hearing, a series of further written answers to questions has been circulated to Estimates Committee members. They address some of these matters of cost and, in particular, the question of the stationing of a ranger on Bowen Island. It is advised that a ranger will be stationed on the island once vacant possession is available. I believe that a number of the other matters Senator Reid is concerned about are specifically there addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the larger question of budgetary allocations for this matter, the view that is taken by the Department of Territories is simply that a responsible approach will be taken within the budget that is available to the Department as a whole. It is a question of using resources in accordance with priorities. To that extent the Bowen Island matter will simply have to take its place in the queue. But there is a full understanding, as I am advised, of all the issues that have been raised. Nothing new has been put into the debate on this occasion. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has fully considered all the material that has been put before him and raised in this place. His response is as I have communicated it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some matters emerge from this issue, quite apart from those already raised about the extraordinary behaviour of the Department of Territories and the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) in their relationship with the lessees of Bowen Island. One matter emerges from the very question the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has just raised, that is, the matter of expenditure priorities. I must say that, as Chairman of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, I am intrigued to see that the Government has amongst its priorities the spending of $640,000 this financial year to get rid of the Fullers from Bowen Island-the people who have been doing an outstanding job in conserving and preserving this area. I correct myself: That $640,000 includes some other expenditures relating to the purchase of improvements on withdrawn leases. But the bulk of the money-as I understand it, the great majority of it-relates to this specific matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considers that Australians' money should be spent, at a time like this, on what is a totally unnecessary, wasteful and absurd proposition which cannot be defended adequately, which has not been defended properly to the Committee and regarding which questions are still being pursued by honourable senators, without a proper response being given. If the estimates are accurate-that there is to be an increase of $326,000 in the original estimate of $314,000 to go this year towards the purchase of improvements on withdrawn leases-it seems to indicate that the $400,000-odd claim that has been touted as the claim the present lessees will have is, perhaps, close to the truth. I note that during the Estimates Committee hearing the public servants involved said that $150,000 of the additional amount probably relates to Bowen Island on top of whatever was the initial amount allocated. But at this stage we are not sure what that amount will be because it is subject to litigation.

However, let us assume that around $400,000 is to be wasted this year on a procedure which is totally unnecessary if the stated objectives of the Department are really what the Department is all about. That is the essential issue. Are the stated objectives what the Government and the Department really seek? If the objectives are the great list of things officers gave to us of improvements and so on that had to be made, such as the cutting down of bamboo which has been proceeding anyway, nothing in the present lease arrangements prevents the Government from doing them without this kind of massive expenditure. The Department tells the Government that these things are absolutely essential, that they must be done and that they have such a priority that the kind of money involved is a minimum of $400,000 and the allocation, as I said, is up to $640,000.

What does this additional expenditure achieve that could not be achieved in terms of the Department's objectives? That is a question the Department has not answered. It will not discuss these matters with the people concerned and is behaving in a totally arrogant and unpleasant way, not only to the lessees but also to honourable senators. It may well be that this supplementary estimate of $640,000 is largely bunkum anyway and will not be spent because litigation is proceeding. In my mind there is no way this money will be spent by 30 June because these matters will not be resolved by then and may well not be resolved for a long time. I can assure the Department that, as Chairman of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, I will be looking very closely at the Department's expenditures to make certain that the money allocated for this purpose is not diverted to some other purpose. I must admit that I have very little confidence in the departmental advice, following what we have seen so far.

I am also very concerned about the discussion of whether, if the Government gets rid of the lessees-who, as I have said, have looked after this area so successfully that the penguin population has increased significantly-it will require the stationing of a full time ranger on the island at considerable cost. I am not certain of the running cost of maintaining a ranger on the island, because the Department ducked the question during the Estimates Committee hearing and said that a ranger would be provided out of the existing strength of the staff of rangers in Jervis Bay. That staff looks after an enormous area, public usage of which has been increasing enormously. The demands on that existing staff will continue to increase. Yet we have had this phoney response that someone can be diverted-someone who is already overworked and is already handling an enormous increase-without any additional cost to the taxpayer, into an additional task of being a full time ranger on Bowen Island. The answer given was that the priorities will just be rearranged. I would then expect the Department to start pressuring the Government, if it behaves as most departments seem to, for an additional staff member after this position has been established, because of the phoney response that as there are more and more tourists in the rest of the area, therefore there is a need to increase the staff in the rest of the area; having sought to fool the Senate by saying that there would not be any additional cost whatsoever and that the Department would simply divert one of the existing staff. I find the whole arrangement to be most unsatisfactory.

I have to declare an interest. I have been to Bowen Island; I know the lessees; and I have had the privilege of staying there and of watching the fairy penguins come ashore in the evening. I have seen what an outstanding job has been done by these people; a job being done for nothing as far as the Department is concerned. The Department now seeks to do that job at public expense, at a capital cost of between $400,000 and $640,000, basically to achieve nothing that could not be achieved without the expenditure of any of this amount. Until the Government tells us exactly what can be achieved or what cannot be achieved in the present situation, the Senate would have every right to be particularly concerned about this unnecessary expenditure, which will do nothing either for the penguins or for the island, at a time when the Government is preaching expenditure restraint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I can add very much more to what has been said earlier, but a couple of points should be made. The first is as to the suggestion that the Department of Territories somehow is having to justify a cost of $400,000 to buy out the tenants. It should be clear from the documentation that has been provided that the only sum that has been earmarked for this purpose is $150,000, $90,000 of which is to purchase existing improvements and the remainder is to demolish various buildings, repair the jetty, and so on. It is the case that a figure of $400,000 is in circulation, being the valuation provided to the lessees by a private valuer, but that is a contested valuation and it is not to be assumed that the payout will be anything like that order of magnitude. It is the case that the $90,000 that has been allocated for this purpose will not now be spent, as a result of litigation, in this financial year, but in other respects the situation is as I have described it.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of the rangers and the additional allegedly wasted cost involved in stationing a ranger permanently in this location, I am advised that rangers are now already involved in the Bowen Island administration in a limited way and the change is not as radical as is being suggested by those on the other side. Apart from this, the matter simply has to rest as I have indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pose some questions and make some comments on the Department of Aviation, essentially in relation to the Government's decision to build a new airport at Badgerys Creek. I do so against the background that I have sought information on the nature of the airport at Badgerys Creek and have received a quite ambiguous reply. Fundamentally, it is important to understand, against this background, that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), in a letter to me by way of written answer, made the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Decisions as to what role the second airport will initially fill have of course yet to be taken.

I ask the Minister: When has the Government decided that the construction of the airport will start? That must be a simple question to be answered, otherwise the Government would not have made the announcement and sought to acquire the land. Will it start in the next year? Secondly, when is it proposed that it will be finished? This is a fundamental question particularly in relation to the functioning of Kingsford-Smith Airport. The answers to all of these questions must be known, otherwise the decision would not have been made and it would not have proceeded. What is the estimated cost to the Commonwealth for this? What is the estimated cost to the New South Wales Government with regard to all the ancillary activities? Has there been any agreement by the State Government to undertake that cost? Has there been any financing arrangement between the Commonwealth Government and the State Government? Specifically I ask: Has any work been done in relation to the direction that shall be taken of freeways from the airport towards the city and, therefore, what areas will be acquired and what properties are in peril? Does the area include a buffer zone and what is the buffer zone? In other words, is the Government planning to protect the airfield from encroachment of development? Is the environmental impact statement, on which no doubt the committee made its decision, available for us to see?

I understand the difficulty, in that I have asked a lot of questions, but I am not seeking the answers now. I specifically invite the Minister to consider this situation: The Government has indicated that it proposes to amend the Commonwealth Lands Acquisition Act and was to have done so in this session, but I understand that it will do so in the Budget session. I have been advised in another Committee that a number of decisions have been taken-for example, a review from the decision will be provided to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal at least that has been advised by the Government to another committee. I understand that the primary delay in investigating this legislation relates to whether the amending legislation should include a provision for injurious affection. The Minister will understand the significance of injurious affection to an area which is to take a main airport; that is to those whose properties will not be acquired but who are on the fringe of acquisition. I hope that all these questions will be answered specifically, because the people of Badgerys Creek are suffering from this at the moment.

In drafting the legislation will the Government very seriously take into account injurious affection and solatium, which the Minister would understand can be specific in an area such as this? Above all, will the Government take into account the loss of value of a property from the moment a freeze is put on until the moment that it is sold? It is ludicrous to have an acquisition under which the value that the Government pays is the value that the user would get commercially at the point of payment. That is a nonsense because, for example, in the Cobar area at this moment properties have halved in value simply because of the freeze. Taking those questions on acquisition together, I ask specifically: Will the Government refrain from acts of acquisition, if it has it in mind at this moment, until the benefits, if any, accruing from the amended Act can apply to these people? Will it, in amending the Act, take in those details to which I have referred?

Specifically, I want some other answers. Airfields have four main purposes. Three commercial categories of aircraft use them. First of all, they are used by intrastate aircraft; that is, aircraft flying, for example, from Dubbo to Sydney, from Sydney to Narrandera, or between various other parts of the State. At least 50 per cent of the commuter aircraft carry passengers who go to an airport specifically to get onto either an interstate aircraft or an international aircraft. That is of great importance in planning any airport. So, for a start, we can identify intrastate commercial aircraft. We can identify interstate commercial aircraft. I remind the Minister and the Committee that many passengers on interstate aircraft are on those intrastate aircraft in order to go to, say, Dubbo from Melbourne or to get onto an international aircraft. That is very common. I now draw attention to international aircraft and the need for people to be able to get onto interstate and intrastate aircraft from the first point of entry into Australia. Of course, there is then general aviation, a term that takes in, generically, anything from crop dusting to recreational or private flying.

Let me rejoice in the Government's description of what is likely to happen. I find this to be an Alice in Wonderland situation. Here we are with a Government saying it will build this airfield, so it must know what it is going to do. Otherwise, why would it acquire property? Let me read to the Committee the two choices. I refer to two paragraphs from a letter of the Minister for Aviation, Mr Peter Morris, of 4 April. He says:

One of the findings of the SSA Site Selection Programme was that there seems no good reason why the principles which appear to direct traffic distributions between multi airport systems in metropolitan centres overseas would not equally apply to Sydney. If so, we can look forward to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA) essentially catering to commercial and business activities, and the second airport more characteristically accommodating leisure travel and other activities which cannot be accommodated at KSA.

I now ask the Minister what is meant by catering for leisure travel. Is not overseas travel, travel between States and intrastate travel leisure travel? The letter goes on with a lovely kind of blandishment:
If this occurred the split would then generally be leisure/business . . .

In other words, one airport has leisure and the other has business, rather than international, interstate or intrastate aircraft, et cetera. We must not worry about that; we have this leisure/business breakup. The letter continues:
This specialisation results in little need to travel between the two airports.

I have some news for the Government. Airports 30 to 40 miles apart with a major international city between them will be absolutely isolated from each other by three or four hours of travel and endless delays. For the Minister responsible for the Government's action to freeze land at Badgerys Creek to give this reply is a nonsense. But it becomes far more than that-and the questions I have asked so far have received no specific answer-because now the authorities are saying that Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport must be dealt with and dealt with quickly, with immediacy, because it is dangerously overloaded and there are risks of accidents if the pressures keep on. The Government need not have had any doubt about that because the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee has said that over many years and only the Wran Government has stood in the way of its sensible report being considered. But here we have an airport-Kingsford-Smith Airport-which cannot wait for another airport to be built. We must not forget that when the other airport is built, it will be going in for leisure traffic, not for any of the commercial business flights that most people use. At the very least, an airport of any major standard will take 10 years to construct, with all the freeways and everything else. The fact is that there was never a choice between either doing something at Kingsford-Smith or having another airport; there was always the necessity to look towards Kingsford-Smith as well as having another airport.

The real urgency is this: What specific action is the Government taking, in the light of this authoritative knowledge that it now has, to overcome the bottlenecks that are occurring day by day at Kingsford-Smith Airport and to overcome the dangers of accident as a result of too great a volume of air traffic, other than simply shifting international aircraft to other capital cities? That is in fact what has happened. They have been shooting off to Melbourne and Brisbane, despite the fact that most international travellers have Sydney as their central point.

I have risen on this matter simply to say that I believe that the people of Badgerys Creek have been done a grave disservice. Frankly, I do not believe for a moment that the Government intends to build this second airport. If it does, it can answer my five or ten specific questions. We will then know when it will start and finish and its cost and usage, and we will know that it has the agreement of the State Government. We will know all these things. Also, the Government will have adjusted the situation to deal with people decently, honestly and fairly under the Lands Acquisition Act. I emphatically ask that the questions I put in the consideration of these estimates be given answers in the immediate future so that the people of Badgerys Creek and surrounding areas can understand specifically their problems. They are suffering a hardship now by way of loss of property values and loss of manoeuvrability for themselves, and they deserve a better fate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Sir John Carrick asked five or ten specific questions, although I did not count them. I remind the Committee that we are debating the estimates of expenditure of several departments, and if specific questions like this are to be asked it might be best if the honourable senator asking them were to tie them in with the specific estimates that we are looking at.

—I specifically said to the Minister that I was not asking that he respond to them now but that he take them on notice. It is the custom in this place to be able to make a speech, under this heading, on the very framework of aviation. If Kingsford-Smith Airport-the focal point of aviation in Australia-is not part of these estimates, then, with great respect to you, I do not know what is.

—With great respect to Senator Sir John Carrick, the role of the Committee of the Whole has changed over the time that he and I have been here. We were not able to make speeches of a second reading nature in the past. I thought that the honourable senator wanted answers to those questions at this stage, but, if he does not, that is fine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to raise a couple of matters under the vote for the Department of Aviation. Firstly, it has been drawn to my attention, as I am sure it has been drawn to the attention of other honourable senators, that the aviation cost recovery program the Government is pursuing has got to the stage where it is likely now to have a severe effect upon the operation of general aviation in this country. Some colleagues of mine, such as Senator Townley and Senator MacGibbon, who are closely associated with the problems of the aviation industry will undoubtedly be aware of the extent to which the Government's pursuit of its policy in terms of aviation cost recovery is posing particular problems for general aviation.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that there is a view expressed by people in the general aviation sector of this country that the sorts of charges which are being imposed on things such as the way in which individual pilots have to comply with increased licencing and increased reporting arrangements and the costs attached to those may well lead to a situation in which fewer pilots will lodge flight plans if there is considerable penalty attached to doing so, and that that will have a substantial and detrimental effect upon the safety standards which have previously been so very much a feature of the Australian aviation industry. In order to illustrate the charges to which I referred under the cost recovery arrangements, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief document prepared for me by the General Aircraft Association which I had previously shown to Senator Gareth Evans when he was the Minister on duty. Rather than take the time of the Senate going through those charges, I believe it would be more convenient if permission was given to incorporate that document.
Leave granted.

Industry's acceptance of Bosch Report. The Department of Aviation is basing a lot of its assumptions on the industry's general acceptance of the Bosch report, much of which was critical of the Department of Aviation and favourable to General Aviation. However, the Department of Aviation has now seen fit to modify and selectively implement sections of the Bosch report in a manner detrimental to General Aviation without allowing for further negotiations. The changes made by the Department of Aviation effectively negate the industry's acceptance of this report.

SAFETY: I believe the Department of Aviation has overlooked the fundamental question of safety. Fewer pilots will lodge flight plans if there is a considerable penalty attached to doing this. The system will be deprived of the valuable traffic advisory service now provided to Instrument Flight Rules, Regular Public Transport aircraft, etc., with consequent reduction in protection for these aircraft. Also, Department of Aviation action will be less effective and considerably more costly.

The final result: Destruction of the Industry as we know it. General Aviation will become the province of the very rich. The valuable contribution played by General Aviation to the lives of tens of thousands of Australians will cease to exist. Don't forget the jobs of many thousands of workers in the industry, government employees included!

TALK.START.PARA: —The other point that I raise-Senator Ryan undoubtedly will roll her eyes in horror at this-is the question of inwards duty free shopping. On this occasion I draw attention to the fact that, the decision having now been made for inwards duty free shopping in Australia, the Department of Aviation has now produced a pamphlet entitled `Lighten your load-buy on arrival'. This pamphlet has been issued by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) and it encourages people to buy on arrival when they return to Australia. This has been sent out in several thousands to travel agents throughout Australia to distribute to people when tickets are issued, suggesting that they wait until they return to buy their alcohol, tobacco and perfume, which are the three products which are available at this stage on re-entry into Australia. I find it passing curious that the Commonwealth Department of Aviation spends money to urge Australians to shop at shops owned by non-Australians and ignores the idea of purchasing goods from Australian-owned and operated stores.

SPEECH.PARA: The only `buy on arrival' shops available at the moment are owned by foreign companies. They are owned by foreign companies which have an employment practice of not employing Australians at senior managerial levels but, in fact, of bringing to this country foreign nationals to manage and operate their particular activities. It is extraordinary to me that the Commonwealth should spend money to urge Australian travellers to effectively boycott Australian-owned premises in order to buy at foreign-owned premises. As I have said repeatedly in this place during numerous interventions on the question of inwards duty free shopping, I have no doubt that this is part of a long term and concerted campaign by the Department to squeeze out the independent off-airport duty free operators. The Department dislikes these people because they have stuck up for the traveller at the expense of the bureaucrats in the Department of Aviation. All of the history demonstrates that the Department of Aviation has put every possible impediment in the way of the independent off-airport duty free shop operator.

The off-airport duty free shops have had to go to the High Court of Australia, in the case of Sterling-Nicholas v the Commonwealth, in order to protect themselves. Their only support has been that support provided to them by legal means. The Department has attempted to kill them off at every possible turn. It has been extraordinarily successful. As a result, duty free purchases at Australian off-airport duty free shops are the cheapest in the world. For instance, information in the Sydney Morning Herald on 29 April this year, on 24 October 1984 and back in 11 April 1983 has consistently shown that Australian off-airport duty free shops are the cheapest and, indeed, the best in the world. Yet the Department, having now introduced this inwards duty free shopping arrangement against the recommendations of the Customs Service and against the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission, is now using Commonwealth revenue to try and drive the independent off-airport Australian-owned shops to the wall in favour of those shops which are on Commonwealth property-those shops which pay lease arrangements to the Commonwealth and which already have received favourable deals from the Commonwealth. They were granted their inwards duty free concessions without competitive tender. The Commonwealth is now attempting to drive Australian operators out of business by spending public money to the commercial benefit of non-Australian organisations.

I think that is a disgraceful situation. I think it is indicative of the level and standard of behaviour of officers in the Department of Aviation and in the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, who have been the main proponents of this idea. I believe there are many thousands of people employed in the duty free industry in Australia who will be disappointed, to put it mildly, to learn that the money they pay in tax is now to be used by the Commonwealth to conduct a propaganda campaign to the detriment of Australian industry and in favour of commercial operations which are owned by foreign companies whose profits are repatriated out of the country and which pursue an employment policy which ensures that Australians are not employed in top managerial positions within that organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to return briefly to the estimates of the Department of Territories and in particular to the matter of Bowen Island. I realise that Senator Lewis, Senator Reid and Senator Michael Baume adequately canvassed a number of matters, but some of them in very short form seem worth repeating because there did not seem to be an adequate answer offered, either today or on the many opportunities the Department has had in the past to supply satisfactory answers. The first question I raise is who benefits by what has happened at Bowen Island? No one has convinced me or other senators I have spoken to that the public benefits by this move at Bowen Island. Nobody has convinced me that the lessees benefit-the lessees are the last people to believe that they will benefit-by being kicked off the island. The second question I ask is what is being achieved by sending away the lessees, who occupy only a small portion of the island? What harm have they done that requires that they be sent away? In fact, photographs made available to members of the Estimates Committee seemed to show that, since the lessees have occupied the portion of the island they leased, there has been a substantial improvement in the environmental aspects of the island. In my view, there has not been an adequate explanation of the cost of removal of the kikuyu grass. Apart from the financial cost, there has been no explanation of what will happen to the penguin colony.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Estimates Committee, it was asked how the kikuyu grass would be removed, given that it is in that grass that the penguins nest. The answer given was `very carefully'. Everybody laughed at the time and I suppose at the time it was a bit of light relief in a long day, but it does not seem to me to be an adequate answer to say that the kikuyu grass will be removed very carefully so as not to disturb the penguin colony. After all, if this move is genuinely being made to conserve and preserve the natural environment, and the penguin colony is a part of that, I would have thought that satisfactory estimates would have been made about what will happen to the penguin colony if the Government or the Department goes ahead with their plans.

I am led to believe that tests have already been undertaken to determine the effectiveness of various poisons to deal with the kikuyu grass. I am further led to believe that a passing remark from an officer involved in these tests put an estimate up in the millions of dollars over an extensive period to rid the island of kikuyu grass. I say `a passing remark' because I understand that is all it was. It was not a well thought out and researched estimate. We have been given no indication from the Department of the full cost of returning the island to the state it wants it to return to, and in particular the dollar cost of removing the kikuyu grass and the environmental cost to the penguin colony. Will the Minister undertake to make available all advice received by the Department with respect to the Government's plans and what effect it will have on the penguin colony, and in particular to make available whatever advice the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment offered to the Department of Territories? When that advice is made available, Opposition senators may be able to alter their view. Their view at the moment is that the priority given to this project, in tough economic times, must be queried because there is a cost outlay with a limited benefit, if any, in removing the lessees from a small portion of this island. I concur in the views of my fellow senators that the answers thus far have simply not been adequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to question the estimates of the Department of the Territories. A statement was presented to the Estimates Committee and incorporated in its proceedings as to why the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) was not prepared to answer questions on Bowen Island and on the Ouvea issue. At the outset I want to reject the claim by the Minister for Territories that the question relating to the stay of the crew of the yacht Ouvea at Norfolk Island in July was somehow outside the Additional Estimates. The New Zealand police had facilities made available to them by the Administrator and, for all we knew, overtime bills might well have gone up markedly, just as they did for the Australian police who were stationed on that island.

SPEECH.PARA: However, of more moment to me is the inability of the Press and other media to get any comment from the Administrator. If such material had been available on the public record one would not have to spend time in the Senate trying to get it. In this case an act of international terrorism took place in New Zealand and there was an involvement by our Government days later on Norfolk Island. I believe that members of parliament, such as I, have a responsibility to ferret out exactly what involvement we had. I would like to hear some comment on that matter by the Minister.

The same problem, however, seems to have existed in other areas of the answers from the Department of Territories. One such noticeable area is that of Australian Capital Territory housing. For a time the media were highly and irrationally excited by the community housing expansion program, CHEP, in the Australian Capital Territory. In August the Minister for Territories announced his intention to appoint a consultant to examine alternative forms of public housing in the Australian Capital Territory. That idea has been undermined, I believe, by the Department and in fact bombed by Cabinet. However, we have no information on this and I seek some guidance on the subject from the Minister.

We are now apparently to have a consultancy, under the auspices of the Department, to look into the whole matter. We do not know what terms of reference are involved, what degree of public input there will be into the process, or what steps the Government has taken to get the Department of Territories to align its practices with the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. All these matters need to be answered in the interests of public knowledge and of the people of Canberra.

Even more serious in this area, it seems that some of the information provided to the Committee by the Department of Territories indicated that there are real administrative problems in the Department. We have heard at length of the Bowen Island litigation, which was commented upon also in the formal report to the Senate by the Estimates Committee. We also have the case of the Belconnen Mall in which information was withheld. In the Estimates Committee hearing we had to ask a vast number of questions. A briefing I was due to have was cancelled at an hour's notice by the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Subsequently it was reinstated, but a number of written questions had to be put to the Department, hence, in the process, wasting resources and energy.

We have also clear indications before the Committee that the Department did not properly read the Nuclear Activities (Prohibition) Ordinance passed by the House of Assembly in 1984. It claimed that the ordinance would have prohibited the use of uranium in medical research. I can see no way in which the Department could come to such a strange conclusion. I saw nothing dealing with this in the copy of the ordinance that I had. It seems to me that this shows up a severe problem in the legal section of the Department of Territories. I believe that, as long as this is not cured and sorted out properly, the Australian Capital Territory will continue to have major problems.

It seems also that the answer given about legal action in relation to enforcing a Supreme Court order in Torrens Street omitted a number of facts that local residents believe to be highly relevant. This type of slipshod answer is not what we expect from a department. I believe that the matter has been taken to the Ombudsman for the second time in over a decade. I understand that local residents collected evidence because the Department was showing no inclination to do so. The Department did not answer that part of my question in the Estimates Committee. I believe that it should, on notice from here, be asked to answer by the Minister, or some undertaking should be made that the question will be answered.

I understand that the Australian Government Solicitor said that a prosecution for contempt could be undertaken. I hope that the Minister will not hide behind the problem of sub judice in avoiding the question yet another time today. I know that the local residents have collected all the excuses given in the past, and this has systematically shown that there was a change in pattern as each excuse came to the end of its available lifetime. It is no wonder that the Government is acting to try to improve the land administration section of the Department of Territories. It is extremely important, if we are to continue to pay out large amounts of money and the Territories Department is to grow by adding a whole lot more sections, that the problem of administration should be solved.

The National Capital Development Commission indicated in an answer that it would be reviewing the current lease ordinances relating to the Australian Capital Territory. Will that be an internal process only, or will the Government ensure that there is scope for submissions from the public and public hearings so that a work- able system can emerge-one whose principles will actually be adhered to? Actually getting contact is a real problem for the people in Canberra. We are now going through a process of getting self-government. The same Department will be running it. If the Government does not accept the electoral system that is being proposed by the Senate, we may not have self-government and the Department will be running it on its own. This would be a real problem.

Information supplied to the Committee indicated that as at 31 March 1986 the aggregate arrears for land rent and rates on commercial leases amounted to $1.37m. Recovery action on over half that amount has been suspended or has not actually commenced. In fact, I was interested to read in last weekend's newspapers an advertisement about legal action being taken in relation to rates. Does this mean that there will be concerted recovery action in the case of the commercial leases, or are we just going to hit the individual citizens whose rates are behind the times?

Is the Government moving to regularise the involvement of the National Capital Development Commission in areas of the Australian Capital Territory outside those set aside for it in its legislation? What is happening? We do not know. No such information is available. What progress has been made on determining the parts of the Australian Capital Territory that will continue to have national standing and funding to match the status of a national capital? When will that information be put to a local governing body for discussion and possible amendment? When will we get a local body?

I also note the Australian Capital Territory self-government proposals exclude Jervis Bay. We have no indications, currently, as to how Jervis Bay will be handled. Will it be handed over to the Department of Defence or will it still be managed by the Department of Territories? I think that is an easy enough question to answer. What will happen to any current leases?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the answer?
—I wish I knew.
—You said it was easy. You can't even get the easy ones tonight.

—That is what I am trying to say about the Department. Will current leases be terminated like the leases on Bowen Island? Will the Government be making a detailed statement on its intentions for Jervis Bay, particularly its use as a nuclear port or as a defence facility? When will we hear about this? All of these questions are essential to an understanding of what is happening within the Department of Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told by the Minister, particularly in relation to the self-government legislation, that there are great difficulties in getting the legislation drafted. In fact, a briefing supported this.

In September 1981 Senator Gareth Evans was told that there were eight drafting staff in the Attorney-General's Department who worked on Australian Capital Territory matters. Estimates Committee E was told that discussions were continuing with the Department of Territories over the transfer of these drafting staff. How many staff are now involved in the drafting process? When is a transfer likely to take place? What are the impediments to this transfer? It is important, if we are to get effective management of the Territory and an effective interface between whatever the new body is and this Parliament, that that drafting facility be available and that the administrative problems that I brought up be investigated. I ask the Minister to comment on the general matters which I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) is reeling from the questions asked by Senator Vigor. While she is seeking some instructions and trying to find some answers to the very pungent and telling questions which Senator Vigor has asked the Department, I wonder whether she could also ascertain something about the titles to land on Christmas Island. The departmental officers will be aware of my concern over this matter. The situation is that the phosphate mining on Christmas Island is running down, and it is to be hoped that some private enterprise will take place on the island. It is extremely difficult for any private entrepreneur to establish any form of business without being able to get some title to the land that he or she wishes to occupy, even if it is for a term of only a few years.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a market gardener on Christmas Island who has been in possession of an area of land for nearly three years. He has done a wonderful job in endeavouring to provide some island grown fruit and vegetables for the population on the island.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he import fertilisers?

—I will explain to the honourable senator that it is not as easy as that. Apparently, one of the great difficulties is that the island is full of fertiliser but is not full of soil. One cannot really grow things in fertiliser. The great difficulty is getting soil which is suitable for growing food. This fellow has put in a lot of work into this area. He has put in an irrigation supply and has done a lot of work to clear the land, but he is still waiting for a title to the land. I do not know what the Department of Territories is on about. I hope that that has given the Minister an opportunity to obtain some instructions from the Department as to progress in surveying the island or parts of the island. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some advice from departmental officers. I remind Senator Lewis that it is advice and not instruction that Ministers seek from officers. In respect of Christmas Island the new land lease arrangements are almost finalised. Some entrepreneurs are already starting up. The issues raised by Senator Lewis's questions are agreed to be important and are high priorities in the Department of Territories. There will be no change in the leases at Jervis Bay. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has already issued a statement on this. Senator Vigor asked a number of questions and concluded by asking generally what the attitude of the Government is to these matters. TALK.START.PARA: —I tried to interject. I do not know whether the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) thinks she will get away with it, but of course I am going to stand up and ask her what is almost finalised? What on earth does almost finalised mean? We have been hearing that for at least two years. Would the Department of Territories be prepared to give a date when the title situation will be finalised?
—The Department of Territories is waiting on a draft of the legislation from the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a couple of things about the Department of Aviation. First, it is quite notice- able, having watched the estimates for many years, that the cost of aviation services in this country is continuing to rise. We see almost $8m--
—It has to pay for all your accidents.

—I have not had an accident for a long time. The cost in these votes is almost an additional $8m. These costs are being criticised by a lot of people associated with aviation. As was mentioned earlier by Senator Puplick we have seen recently an attempt to levy charges on general aviation. I believe that that had not been thought through properly because when I questioned that in the Estimates Committee, the departmental officers did not seem to quite know how it would be done, particularly in regard to some of the smaller aircraft. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) has held up the application of those charges for a year so that an examination of just how to do it and how much to charge can be made.
