However, for a little airline such as Airlines of Tasmania Pty Ltd the charges would have amounted to something like $360,000 per annum. That is no small amount for a small airline that serves Tasmania very well. I would like to let the Department know, via the Minister, that this is something that senators from Tasmania will be keeping an eye on as time goes by.

SPEECH.PARA: The main point I want to make is that, instead of continuing to impose extra costs on the community, there seems to be a need for the Department to attempt to reduce its expenditure. One area I can think of is pilot training. Some millions of dollars are spent on it. I have noted that expenditure on it has increased periodically since the time I have been a member of parliament. Millions of dollars are spent on pilot training mainly so that the pilots who are trained can examine other pilots. I have always wondered how somebody who, for argument's sake, is trained for eight hours a year in a jumbo examines somebody who is flying 400 hours a year in a jumbo. It seems quite crazy. If one questions this with the Department it brings up the matter of safety. That is something for which the Department of Aviation has been well known for many years. If one looks back at some committee inquiries one will see that that is always what it falls back on. One needs to be a fairly brave Minister to say `we will take the risk' because if something happened the Minister would be in trouble. I believe it is one area in which we could save quite a considerable amount of money.

I was wondering whether pilots have to declare their training as a benefit they get from their employment. From a tax point of view, it seems that they might well have to do so under the new tax legislation because it is probably a part of their contract of employment and it certainly makes them much more valuable people in the aviation industry than they would otherwise be. Maybe that is something the Department should look at.

TALK.START.PARA: —The employer will have to pay it.

—I know that the employer would have to pay the tax. I agree with the honourable senator. In the case of all government departments the employer does pay the tax. If the Department of Aviation has to pay that tax, that is all the more reason for this being one of the areas which it should examine very closely. I ask the Minister: What happens when an individual offers to help the Department to save money? Today on page 21 of the Australian was the headline `Department wastes $100m a year on archaic rules'. I will read some of the article:

SPEECH.PARA: Entrepreneur Mr Dick Smith has accused the Department of Aviation of wasting at least $100 million a year by insisting on enforcing outmoded and ridiculous air traffic regulations which often reduced safety instead of improving it.

Mr Smith, who flies his own helicopter, said the Federal Government had offered him the chairmanship of the Bicentennial Authority but he had turned it down because he would rather save public money than spend it.
That is pleasant to see. At last someone is trying to save a bit of money. The article continued:
`But when I told the Government that it could save at least $100 million a year by updating archaic aviation regulations, they did not want to know . . .

Does the Department have some kind of mechanism for getting help or experience from those people who have worked in the industry, especially somebody as successful as Mr Dick Smith has proven to be in the areas he is well known for-electronics and aviation? If he is prepared to offer help, there should be some mechanism whereby this help can be accepted. No doubt there are many other people-retired airline pilots and such people-who could well help this Department to save some money. I will not go into the areas in which Mr Smith said money was wasted. I am sure that the Department and the country are at a stage where they have to look carefully at any money that is spent. I hope that the Department can accept the offer of a gentleman such as Mr Smith to assist it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask some very short questions on the Department of Veterans' Affairs. At the hearings of Estimates Committee F the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs pointed out that in the financial year to 28 March 69.04 per cent of the entitlement claims were successful at the primary decision level and 52.04 per cent at the assessment level. Some 70 per cent of the entitlement cases and 65 per cent of the assessment cases taken to the Veterans' Review Board have been successful this year. This is a large proportion of successful cases. The whole point is that a fair proportion of the unsuccessful cases go on to appeal and are successful.

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary indicated that steps are being taken at the early stages of the process to get extra information from applicants relating to their change of status-for example, totally and permanently incapacitated status-so that it will be possible to avoid the large number of appeals and the appeal process which results from original decisions being, it appears, wrong. If we are to save a large amount of money for the taxpayer and a large amount of heart ache for the people who are applying for benefits from the Department of Veterans' Affairs it seems very important that we should try to get it right at the start. In relation to this, I ask: What are the specific steps that have been taken to get extra information? Can I have some indication from the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) whether officers are making primary decisions on the information supplied on the existing forms? Are new forms available which make certain that all the information is to hand when a case is considered? Is the telephone being used to get extra information and to communicate with the veteran? How are we improving the process of communication between the Department and beneficiaries?

As the Veterans' Affairs Department is a service department, it is very important that this service be delivered as effectively as possible and that money be spent on giving the benefits rather than on very drawn out processes of appeal and counter appeal. I would like to know at this stage what new procedures are in place and what the Department is planning to do to further improve them. What types of cost benefits does it expect from the steps that the Secretary described?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Townley's queries on aviation, the costs of the estimates are mainly in respect of wage increases which have been partly offset by reductions in staff numbers. The Department of Aviation has been reducing costs attributable to the aviation industry by 2 per cent a year. Apparently the honourable senator is not aware that the cost of flying training is not attributable to the aviation industry for cost recovery purposes. His reference to Mr Smith's views that the Department could save $100m a year by changing the regulations is hard to understand since the cost of the Department's regulatory functions is only $40m a year and in any event there is continual consultation with the private sector about these costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Vigor's question, the new determining system was introduced from 1 January last year. The determining officers have the opportunity to seek additional information by means of correspondence, the telephone or medical examination. The times taken for processing are steadily improving at the primary level. The specific steps are being taken to further improve the timing of this testing.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without requests; report adopted.

Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 246th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Income Maintenance Programs-Response to Report 213'. The 246th report contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's two hundred and thirteenth report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee's report No. 213, tabled on 16 November 1983, examined the administration of Commonwealth Government income maintenance programs. That report considered a range of programs having relevance to income maintenance. The types of programs included income replacement programs, for example, unemployment benefits; income supplement programs, for example, tertiary allowances; and programs subsidising expenditure by individuals, for example, free medical services and home purchase assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: Income maintenance programs were defined as those programs transferring cash to individuals or organisations for the purpose of improving social welfare. I believe that expenditure on the programs examined within this report totalled some $14,000m annually-a very large amount. Departmental submissions to the Public Accounts Committee covered a broad spectrum of programs. Replies on a total of 127 programs were received from 10 departments. That was a surprisingly large number of income maintenance programs. In fact, between the drafts prepared of the original report, more programs were identified, finally totalling 127. Many trees were seen, comprising a very large forest indeed. In its analysis of material contained in the submissions, the Committee concentrated on patterns of administrative practice rather than on the detail of individual programs. The Committee was concerned to identify whether departments pay adequate and joint attention to the ways in which they acquire areas of policy responsibility, exercise management control and evaluate program results. The Committee believed that by improving administrative practices, the results of the programs could be enhanced. The Committee made a number of general findings on aspects of administration which it considered would go some way towards addressing the pressing issues facing policy formulators and administrators.

While the Public Accounts Committee is satisfied that there have been some improvements in the manner in which some programs are administered, it does not accept the arguments put forward in several responses, particularly as regards the need for legislative backing for programs and proper evaluation of program performance. In fact, a number of programs identified in the report have no legislative backing. I seek leave to have the balance of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

One of the most important innovations affecting the administration of social welfare programs post-dates the Committee's Report. The Financial Management Improvement Program (FMIP) was initiated by the Department of Finance and the Public Service Board in mid 1983. The Program is designed to direct closer attention to some of the issues raised by the Committee, including the clarity of administrative objectives for programs and the evaluation of practices and programs. The Committee notes that of the ten departments who responded to its questionnaire the Departments of Defence, Health and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are involved in the pilot program for FMIP and have begun to apply its objectives to their respective operations.

The Committee notes that FMIP is designed to complement the range of government financial reforms, including the consolidation of appropriations, the integration of financial and staffing decision making and program budgeting. Departments should not rely solely on these reforms, which are intended to be introduced progressively and improve financial management systematically.
I turn now to some of the Committee's perceived shortcomings in the response.

Originally, the Committee suggested that, in addition to the then proposed Ministerial review of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, there should be a Joint Management Review conducted by the Public Service Board and Department of Employment and Industrial Relations to consider the Department's priorities, efficiency and effectiveness. The Committee rejects the response tendered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The unqualified confidence claimed by the Department in its administrative ability is clouded by the Public Service Board's agreement to a `Reorganisation of the Department's structure which represents a significant strengthening of its management capability'.

One of the recurrent themes in the Committee's report was the necessity to have objectives for programs clearly specified. The Committee suggested that there be an external review mechanism, such as a Task Force, to consider current operations and fundamental innovations. The Committee accepts that the budgetary reforms announced in April 1984, including program budgeting and improvement in public sector financial management may be of assistance in clarifying organisational and evaluation processes. The Committee is also pleased to note that there have been specific, external reviews of programs, including reviews of the repatriation system and the Income Security Review.

I have referred to a lack of legislative backing for some programs. The Committee acknowledges the need for administration to be able to respond flexibly to a range of circumstances. For this reason, a balance must be struck with broad legislation supported by more detailed administrative instructions, to permit managers to exercise the necessary discretion to respond flexibly and swiftly within the law to a variety of circumstances.

In this report the Committee reiterates its view that the formulation of program legislation is a valuable exercise and suggests that those administering authorities which do not already have such legislation in place should give the matter further attention.

The Committee rejects the responses from the Departments of Health, Aboriginal Affairs and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that their need for flexibility militates against the use of legislation. The broad or `umbrella' legislation which the Committee proposed would permit flexibility, while at the same time fostering careful articulation of objectives and improved administration.

The Committee is less than understanding of the inaccuracies in responses tendered, for example, that the establishment of the Surveillance and Investigation Division within the Department of Health is one of that Department's program measures to enhance monitoring and evaluation. This Division was in fact transferred to the Health Insurance Commission in May 1985 some five months before the Finance Minute was presented to the Committee.

In addition, the response by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in relation to its recommendations for legislation for labour market programs is not accurate. The Kirby Report, to which the Department referred, made no recommendations concerning legislation for labour market programs, although one recommendation suggested legislation and a sunset clause for the proposed Council for Employment and Training. It is the Committee's opinion that the Department takes an unreasonably general interpretation of the Kirby Report on this matter in an attempt to suggest a favourable outcome.

While the Public Accounts Committee accepts that possible reforms to correct anomalies and deficiencies in programs would require Government involvement, it does not consider that it in any way diminishes the need to have such matters drawn to its Minister's or Parliament's attention.
I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to address legal and administrative needs which have become evident in the operation of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.

The Act, which came into force in May 1984, consolidated, into a single piece of legislation, the previous conservation controls on the import and export of plants and animals. The Act enables Australia to meet international obligations for the protection and conservation of the world's wildlife listed in the appendices to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. It also controls export of native Australian plants and animals and their products, and the import of live animals other than some aquarium fish and domestic stock. The Act is a major element of the Government's nature conservation program. It received the support of all parties when introduced into Parliament in 1982.
Mr President, the amendments proposed by this Bill can be grouped into four categories:
To make controls on export and import of certain wildlife more appropriate to their status and the circumstances under which they enter trade;
to simplify and improve administrative procedures which have proved, in practice, to be unnecessarily complex;
to clarify and tighten certain enforcement provisions;
to increase protection for those who provide information leading to the institution of proceedings under the Act.

Although a main purpose of the Act is to implement the objectives of CITES, at present it does not provide for the import of specimens acquired before CITES came into force, or acquired before the species in question came within the scope of CITES. Experience with the present Act has shown that a more flexible approach can be taken where the applicant for a permit to import a pre-CITES specimen is a private individual. The Act will be amended, therefore, to allow permits to be granted to individuals under certain circumstances to import pre-CITES specimens that are personal or household effects, gifts or inheritances.

The Act contributes to the conservation of Australian native wildlife through both prohibitions and regulated trade in certain species, consistent with their conservation status. For example, existing provisions allow trade in live fish which are captive bred or taken in accordance with an approved management program. Amendments will bring the export of invertebrates into line with the provisions regulating live fish exports. These amendments will in no way weaken the protection afforded to invertebrate species, and will enable, for example, the export of cultured giant clams to other countries in the Indo-Pacific region to assist in the re-establishment of seriously depleted wild populations.

Before the Act came into force in May 1984, persons departing Australia to live in another country and wishing to take certain categories of legitimately-acquired pets with them were required to have resided in Australia for at least 3 years and to have owned the pet for at least 2 years to be eligible for an export permit. The Act increased the period of residence to 4 years and the period of ownership to 3 years. Amendments will provide for export applications to be considered on the basis of the previous criteria for owners who purchased pets before the Act came into force in the expectation that the previous criteria would continue to apply. It should be noted that this concession will only be available until 30 April 1987.

The primary purpose of the Act is to regulate legitimate trade in wildlife and to combat illicit trafficking in wildlife, particularly endangered wildlife. It is essential that the maximum resources and effort be directed to that purpose. Therefore considerable attention has been paid in this Bill to making administrative procedures streamlined and more efficient. Current provisions which require extensive consultations between the designated authority and overseas authorities, but which add little to wildlife protection, will be removed.

Regular importers and exporters of prescribed specimens (for example scientific institutions importing specimens for research to develop biological control agents) will not be required to make individual applications for each shipment, and will receive a single authority subject to regular reporting of shipments. Release of biological control agents will still be subject to control under the Act.

I take this opportunity to inform the Senate that the Government will move an amendment to clause 16 of the Bill. The Minister has made it clear that the Government has no intention of relaxing controls over the export of live native vertebrate fauna, and the amendment which I foreshadow will remove any possibility that clause 16 could be used to circumvent the strict controls currently applying under the Act.

Duplication in the existing procedures, for gazettal of information on permits and authorities by the Minister will be eliminated. Provision will also be made for inter-change of material between approved zoological organisations and scientific organisations. The responsibilities and options available to the Government and individuals who bring wildlife products into Australia will be clarified with respect to surrendered and seized specimens. Amendments will be made to distinguish between commercial exports and the export by private individuals of legitimately-acquired non-Australian pets, of species listed in CITES. Provision will be made for the designated authority to delegate routine administrative tasks.

There is strong evidence that the rich rewards available to wildlife traffickers have led to the involvement of internationally organised criminals. The amendments will allow Australia to participate more effectively in the existing international network of experts and agencies involved in the detection and prosecution of wildlife trafficking offences. Existing provisions for the certificate of an analyst to be taken as prima facie evidence in a court of law will be strengthened by extension to allow admission in court proceedings of certificates of identification made by a suitably qualified person appointed by the Minister. Provisions will also be made to enable the exchange of specimens between the Australian Scientific and Management Authority and overseas counterparts, for the purposes of comparative identification, education and training of inspectors and to facilitate investigation by Australian and overseas authorities of wildlife offences.

The Act provides severe penalties which are appropriate to the high potential rewards involved in wildlife trafficking. Nevertheless, experience has shown that certain provisions need to be tightened. Particular amendments are required to:
Prevent traffickers from escaping prosecution by surrendering specimens after they have been detected, or in circumstances where a quarantine officer is obliged to destroy seized specimens;

Clarify the powers of inspectors to search baggage and goods, to seize personal property which they believe has been involved in an offence, and to seize documents and invoices as evidence of an offence; and
Clarify the powers of inspectors to seize articles containing prohibited specimens.

Other amendments will protect the confidentiality of the source of information leading to a prosecution. Mr President, the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 is an important piece of legislation which plays a central role in the protection of Australia's wildlife and contributes significantly to protection of the wildlife of the world. The amendments proposed in this Bill will make it even more effective. It is with pleasure that I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will replace the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 and provide for continuation of a Commonwealth program of general purpose financial assistance for Local Government in the States and the Northern Territory.

The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services explained on 10 April that the Government following consultation with the States and Local Government, had accepted the overall finding of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance that the Commonwealth should maintain a program of general purpose support for Local Government but that the character of the program should be changed in certain respects. This Bill gives effect to those changes which are necessary to bring about a gradual improvement in the effectiveness and equity of the program.

I am particularly pleased to be able to introduce this legislation which consolidates past achievements and lays the foundation for future progress. The Whitlam Government developed the first Bill which provided for Commonwealth financial assistance for Local Government. The Grants Commission Act 1973 was an historic breakthrough in inter-government financial relations. It created the precedent for direct Commonwealth involvement in the field of Local Government.

To the credit of the Fraser Government, our initiative in 1973 was built upon and improved through the introduction in 1976 of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act. The main improvements related to the provision of funds for every council and the introduction of a system for allocation of funds by Local Government Grants Commissions in each State.

This Bill introduces some changes designed to bring stability, clarity and accountability to the allocation of untied grants to local councils. Fundamentally, it represents continuation of a bipartisan commitment to the development of Local Government.

The Hawke Government is active across a number of fronts in strengthening Local Government capabilities and in fostering cooperative inter-government relations. We recognise the important contribution that Local Government makes in its own right and through its involvement in Commonwealth-sponsored programs to social and economic development. We value the diversity, decentralisation and responsiveness of Local Government. We understand how Local Government has been evolving as a sophisticated, multi-functional level of community government in Australia.

In this regard, we have sought the participation of Local Government on the Economic Planning Advisory Council. We have upgraded the Office of Local Government for the purpose of strengthening links and improving information exchange among the three spheres of Government.

We have participated actively through the Local Government Ministers' Conference on inter-governmental Task Forces concerned with the role of Local Government in Economic Development and in Community Development. We have sponsored over the last three years through the Local Government Development Program some 400 projects designed to spread the best ideas and practices throughout the Local Government system. We have launched a series of National Awards for Innovations in Local Government and we have pursued the Constitutional Recognition of Local Government.

These various initiatives come together for the mutual benefit of the Commonwealth, the States and Local Government. For all concerned, past barriers to communication and consultation are breaking down. Cooperation and trust is building up. From the Commonwealth perspective, and in the light of the fact that Federal Government expenditure flowing to Local Government exceeds $1 billion, the improving relations allow us to achieve more cost-effective returns for the nation's investment in the Local Government system.

Over half of that Commonwealth contribution to Local Government is in the form of untied grants. This Bill provides for continuity and growth in the provision of these grants but in so doing it establishes a new basis for the provision of funds.

Under the Act that is being replaced, the grants for local government were tied to a percentage of personal income tax receipts. This formula led to great variations in funding from year to year and created difficulties in local government's relationship with the States. No such linkage will be provided in the new Act.

Instead the Bill provides for a base level of funding that is equivalent to the level of funding received by local government in the States and the Northern Territory in 1985-86 plus an adjustment to bring Northern Territory per capita payments into line with those in the States. This provides a base figure of $540.9m.

The Bill provides that the actual payment for local government in 1986-87 shall be this base figure multiplied by either the increase in the consumer price index for that year or by the percentage change in Commonwealth general purpose payments to the States, whichever is the greater. The payment calculations for 1987-88 shall be the same as those for 1986-87.

For all subsequent years payment calculations will be based simply on the percentage change in Commonwealth general purpose payments to the States. That is, Local Government will be treated no less favourably than the States in terms of periodic adjustments to the funding level of the program.

These new financial arrangements will provide a stable financial base from which local government will be able to plan with a greater degree of certainty than under the previous arrangement. The volatility that characterised the previous tax sharing arrangements will be eliminated.

As under the previous Act, the Bill provides for the payments for local government to be made to each State in one lump sum early in the financial year. If the estimates on which the grants are made turn out to be incorrect there is provision for a subsequent adjustment to be made to the grant. This would normally occur through an adjustment to the following year's grant. Such an adjustment might be necessary if, for instance, the rate of inflation turns out to be lower than anticipated.

Each State's share of the total grant will, from 1989-90 onwards, be equal to that State's share of the Australian population. In the two years before then, the shares of each State will be gradually changed from the present relativities to a population basis. As a result of these changes Victoria and South Australia will increase their share of the grants. The other states will reduce their share but in such a way that there will be no reduction in the payment to any of these states in money terms from one year to the next.

The principal objective of this program is to provide financial assistance to those local councils who are most disadvantaged with respect to their ability to raise revenue and to provide services. In attaining this objective, the States will be required to allocate funds in such a way as to equalise each local council's ability to undertake its functions with respect to the average standard performance of other local councils in the State concerned.

At the same time the Government recognises that Local Government, as a whole, has a restricted base from which to raise revenue to finance its expanding functions. Because of this the Government has ensured that every council continues to receive benefits under the program. The legislation provides that the grant received by any council will be at least the amount it would have been entitled to if 30 per cent of the funds available to each State had been distributed among local councils on a straight per capita basis.

In each State a Local Government Grants Commission will continue to be responsible for determining the allocation of funds among local councils. A new requirement is that eventually each Grants Commission must have at least two members who are, or have been, associated with local government in that State.

The Bill requires that these Grants Commissions hold public hearings and that at least once every three years they publish a report setting out details of the methods they use in recommending allocations among local councils.
The Grants Commissions are also required to observe principles that are established under the Act for the purpose of allocating amounts among local councils.

It is recognised that these principles will take some time to develop and to put into effect. Consequently the Bill allows five years for the introduction of such principles. In the meantime Grants Commissions are required to observe the methods of allocating amounts used under the preceding Act or, alternatively any agreement that has been reached between the responsible State Minister and the Commonwealth Minister.

The development of principles for the purpose of allocating funds between local councils is designed to bring an element of uniformity between States without requiring that every State adopt exactly the same principles.

It is intended that these principles will be drawn up by each State in accordance with the purposes of the legislation and submitted to the responsible Commonwealth Minister for approval. This submission is required by 1 July 1987.

In the event that a State refuses to draw up principles or draws up principles which do not accord with the purposes of the Act, there is a fallback power of the Commonwealth Minister to determine the principles for that State.

The Bill provides for the varying, revoking and reviewing of the principles. The review mechanisms will enable the principles to be kept fully up to date with improvements in the practices of the Grants Commissions and with their understandings of the results of their distributions.

A State will not be entitled to a payment in any one year unless the responsible Commonwealth Minister, is satisfied that allocations of funds have been made in accordance with approved principles or in accordance with the alternative arrangements outlined above.

The new Act will result in a redistribution of funds provided under this program to the more needy councils. This is one of its prime objectives. The Government however is concerned to ensure that changes are made gradually so that councils will have time to adjust to the new arrangements.

It is for this reason that the Bill provides for up to five years for changes to occur in the equalisation arrangements and in the method of calculating per capita entitlements. It is for this reason also that the changes in State shares of grants are to be phased in.

The Bill is different from its predecessor in that it provides for an important role for local government itself to participate in establishing the principles which will govern the allocation of funds between local councils.
It also provides for local government to be represented in any review of the Act that the Minister may require after 30 June 1992.

This Bill provides important advances on the arrangements that were introduced under the Whitlam Government and improved upon by the Fraser Government. It will provide continuity and certainty for an important element of Local Government finance while at the same time providing for a more equitable distribution of funds than has previously occurred.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1986, an omnibus Bill which makes a number of changes to social security and compensation legislation. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill but, on behalf of the Opposition, I will move an amendment to the second reading, similar to that moved by my colleague in another place, which seeks to condemn the Government for some of the features of the Bill. The amendment is not being circulated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
``, but the Senate condemns the Government for-
(a) implementing the amnesty for the clients of the Department of Social Security who have received overpayments as the proposal:
(i) establishes a double standard,
(ii) disadvantages honest clients,
(iii) undermines the work of Departmental field officers,
(iv) sabotages field investigators' morale, and
(v) provides no guarantee that overpayment and fraud will not occur in the future, and

(b) its economic policies such as the capital gains tax and the prohibition on negative gearing which have increased the cost of housing and rent necessitating extending the rent subsidy to the long term unemployed.''

At a time when poverty is increasing and after three years of broken promises in the social security and community services area I want to use this opportunity to say a few words about the direction and effectiveness of some of the Government's social security policies. First, some of the provisions in the legislation are straightforward. We do not object to them. The decision that there should be a bar on the payment of unemployment, sickness or special benefits to full time students who are eligible in principle for an education allowance is an appropriate step by this Government and we support it. The change in the treatment of lump sum compensation payments for sickness beneficiaries is one in which we support the Government. A change in the rate of benefit that applies to legally-married but permanently separated unemployment beneficiaries is very technical but once again we support the Government for a sensible move.

While the Opposition does not oppose these provisions it has some concern with other features of the legislation. First, we are concerned with the way the social security amnesty has been conceived and conducted. We are concerned not with the principle behind the youth homelessness allowance but with some of the consequences which may flow from it. This is associated with some of the provisions for rent assistance for the long term unemployed. We are concerned about the style of the amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. The amendment which I moved on behalf of the Opposition draws attention to some of those concerns.

Let us look at these in turn. We are unhappy about the social security amnesty because we are not sure that it is the right way to deal with fraud and abuse of the social security system. I acknowledge immediately before Senator Grimes does it by way of rebuttal later that many of the overpayments which are discovered are the result of genuine error. I comprehend that they are the result of a failure to notify a change in circumstance without any intent to defraud. Such errors can be taken care of. We are concerned about that group of people which has sought to defraud the social security system, to obtain payments to which the people are not entitled and in some cases to obtain multiple payments. Senator Grimes will recall the celebrated case of the gentleman who received 37 payments and was finally found out and brought to court.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not covered by the amnesty.

—Senator Grimes tells us that person is not covered by the amnesty. We are concerned about the whole matter of fraud and fraudulent behaviour in social security. For example, we are concerned that anyone engaging in that activity is cheating his or her fellow citizens. Even though that group is a minority in ripping off the social security system it is ripping off every taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: My son who is an apprentice is paying tax. I resent the idea of a tax paid by him going to someone who is cheating the system, often quite knowingly. People who take advantage of the system to the detriment of the majority of honest, genuine and needy social security beneficiaries are cheating the rest of society and making it more difficult to provide adequate relief for those for whom the system was designed. The Auditor-General regularly draws our attention to these abuses, as do our friends and other parliamentarians by anecdotal experience. It is rather sad that one of the features of the Australian ethos is that people knowing about abuses are often prepared to do nothing about them. The responsibility for the health of the social security system belongs to every one of us.

We should not just scapegoat the Department of Social Security by saying: `It is your job'. I generally tell people who say to me that they know someone who is doing the wrong thing to give me their names. People generally will not. They know about such situations but they will not say who is responsible. If they did tell me I would advise the Department of Social Security and expect action to be taken. I am sure that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) would agree and would have the same expectation. People tell me that they come into contact with social security fraud in their day to day lives. I support the system and programs, all the way from Franklin Roosevelt's moves in 1933 and the ethos of using the resources of society to respond to need. What worries me is that this kind of activity makes it more difficult for us to respond and legitimise the kinds of activities in the social security area that we think proper for a just and compassionate society.

We are concerned about the social security amnesty because it creates different circumstances between classes of beneficiaries. For example, those covered by the amnesty who have received overpayments may be able to go scot free and avoid any consequences that they might otherwise attract while other beneficiaries who have not ripped off the system, who have operated properly and observed the rules and regulations, will not enjoy the extra benefits. They can see that their fellows have not only received benefits to which they are not entitled but also will now have the benefit of the amnesty to protect them. There are equity issues concerning the different classes of beneficiaries which are not addressed by the way the amnesty was conceived or enacted. We do not see it as being fair and thus are unhappy about it.

The Minister, Mr Howe, has actually admitted that the way the amnesty has been presented represents a double standard in behaviour for one group of beneficiaries against another. Yet he is prepared to legislate for the amnesty and press on with it. It is unfair that the large number of people who have to rely on welfare to sustain themselves and their families and who do so within the rules-the people who report changes in their circumstances and find that their benefits are reduced but who do so because those are the rules-now sit back and watch those who have not done so and who have taken advantage of the system and now use the amnesty to gain a personal advantage which they would not have had without it. I acknowledge that the amnesty will enable the system to be cleaned up to some extent. Nevertheless, there is injustice in the way that the amnesty will operate and that concerns us. Our question is: Is it just and right? Is it what the community expects from a welfare system which draws very heavily upon the resources of society?

The Department is the largest spender of money of any Commonwealth Department. The annual budget is $17 billion with about 30 per cent of the total budget going to the welfare and benefit system. One of the characteristics of that system needs to be that it be honest and honestly administered and where people do not observe the rules, that appropriate recoveries be made. I am concerned that if we lose confidence in our welfare system as is happening in society, in the end that may limit our capacity to extend welfare in the future to those who continue to need it. I make it clear that the Opposition understands that this amnesty will be put in place. When we come to government we will introduce modifications to the welfare system. We hope to improve the system, to increase benefits to help respond to unmet need. But there is one thing we will not do. We do not intend to introduce more amnesties and where we can find any deliberate fraud or any deliberate misuse of the system we will respond to it with severity and rigour. I am talking about intentional misuse of the system. We think that society would expect us to do no less. We would expect in government that the Department of Social Security and the Department of Community Services-particularly the Department of Social Security-would assist the Government in policing the system. We would like to think of the Department of Social Security as a department with a good auditing record as well as a good giving record.

I refer to the proposal to provide a young homelessness allowance. This allowance and rent assistance for the long term unemployed will help respond to a major cause of poverty among the young, but it raises some problem of its own. I have a friend, Theo Van Gestal, who, I am sure, is known to the Minister and who works with the St Vincent De Paul Society and is stationed in the Parramatta area. When he first went to the Parramatta office-he had previously been in Liverpool, and before that in Sydney-he discovered very quickly that each night 300 to 400 young people were sleeping rough in the far western suburbs of Sydney-maybe more. He discovered that the extent of homelessness amongst the young was appallingly high and greater than anyone has understood. I understand that the Senate has investigated this matter and has confirmed the extent of youth homelessness. Too often it occurs in the context of a broken family, often with poor coping skills, where a mother may find a new partner and then find that it is impossible to keep in one house herself, the new partner and the children. Sometimes, particularly if children are going through a difficult adolescent stage, the solution, unfortunately, is that the children are kicked out.

In that kind of circumstance, I am not opposed-I do not think anyone would be opposed-to the Government's desire to respond to homelessness. However, a problem arises. Senator Chaney has said quite often that behaviour follows the money. On the one hand, the availability of this benefit will help to meet a real need. I do not argue with that at all. I ask the Minister: To what extent might the benefit help other young people to leave home in what are less than crisis circumstances? The Minister has said, and I agree with him, that he will try to ensure that the benefit is paid only in genuine, forced cases of homelessness. I understand that, but it is going to be rather hard to police.

Honourable senators will know that adolescence is often a fairly turbulent time. They will know that many teenagers talk about walking out of the family home and that quite often there is a fair amount of emotional thunder and lightning during the time when teenagers are around. I submit that often it is a fairly close run thing as to whether or not children leave home. When one looks back five or six years later one realises that the crisis was temporary and has passed and a completely different circumstance arises. I ask the Minister-again, I am not opposing the provision of the benefit at all-whether he has considered the possibility that the benefit, in responding to a need, may actually help create more youth homelessness. Exactly how does the Government intend to go about trying to restrict the benefit to those cases which it calls genuine cases and not to cases which it might regard as temporary, avoidable or frivolous?

I also draw attention to the cost of housing in Australia at present. As I say, we do not object to the provision of assistance for obviously needy people. But we are concerned that the cost of housing now is higher than it need be, not least as a result of the policies of the Government in a number of areas. The Labor Government said that it was launching an attack on the rich by ending negative gearing-a method of buying property, often rental property. The Labor Government has now introduced capital gains tax legislation which is to be debated in this place soon. Both these moves, inter alia, have had the effect of forcing landlords out of the rental market, reducing the creation of new rental property and stock and, as a result, have forced up rents, especially in my city of Sydney, where rents are skyrocketing. If someone wants to rent at the moment, it costs the earth. It costs more than it cost a year or so ago. It will continue to cost more because, with a capital gains tax and the end of negative gearing, fewer and fewer people will wish to get into the provision of rental property. One cannot just expect the public sector to take it up because the public sector does not have the capacity.

Further, the situation has been made worse because the monetary squeeze has been so great that interest rates have risen to very high levels. They have risen to their highest real level in 50 years. So up went the cost of buying a house. If people who might otherwise have been in the market for home purchase now find that they cannot afford to buy a house, they, too, come back to the rental market. Not only is there a lack of rental accommodation, but also more people are seeking rental accommodation because they can no longer afford to buy. It is common knowledge now that a Liberal Government will repeal Labor's capital gains tax. We will see that interest rates are reduced. We will do this not least by massively reducing government expenditure and, by so doing, we will reduce government borrowing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you repeal the fringe benefits tax?
—The honourable senator should be patient; he should wait and see.
—It is a fair question.
—It is not a question which I am in a position to answer. I say: `Be patient'. The honourable senator will have an answer.
—What about the capital gains tax?

—I have said that we will repeal the capital gains tax. We will do so the moment we get into government. We think the rental assistance measures would be less necessary if Australia had had a coalition government for the last three years because we would not have had the measures we have had which have had the effect of driving people out of the home purchase market into the home rental market and, at the same time, making rental much more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before us makes changes to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. We think this Act needs to be rewritten completely to forge a new direction for compensation for Commonwealth employees because the present system is not working. The amendments which are contained in this legislation should be withdrawn until such time as the Act can be completely revised. Let me deal with a few of the problems we have in relation to compensation under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. The last annual report of the Commonwealth Commissioner for Employees Compensation shows that there were 60,000 successful compensation claims which led to compensation payments to government employees of $157m. That $157m was more than twice the compensation paid out in the last year of the former Government. We expect a further blow-out in compensation payments to Commonwealth employees for the current financial year. We know that more than $121m of that $157m has gone to officers of the Australian Public Service who have a total incapacity to work. That is an extraordinary figure for incapacity, an extraordinary extent of incapacity. There were 60,000 claims from a work force in departments and authorities of about 530,000 people. Of those claims, 45,000 people had claimed total incapacity. That represents an incredible claim rate of about one person claiming total incapacity for about every 12 employees in the Australian Public Service. One in every 12 employees of the Commonwealth Government has made a claim for total incapacity to work under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. Being an officer of the Commonwealth Public Service, we know, is hazardous; the hours are long and the conditions must be terribly onerous. But it must be an extremely high risk occupation if there have been 45,000 claims for total incapacity in a work force of just over half a million people. It is an extraordinary figure.

I find it almost impossible to believe that this level of incapacity can in any way equate with what is going on in the wider community. I cannot really believe that employment in the Commonwealth is so much more dangerous than employment in the private sector, so we obviously have a problem in relation to this whole question of Commonwealth compensation. Either there has been a sudden surge of some epidemic disease in the Commonwealth Public Service leading to a one-off requirement for total incapacity claims, or there is something systemic that is leading more and more people to regard themselves as totally incapacitated. There have been 45,000 claims in the past year. No doubt the Government will address that.

I turn now to say a few words in the time left to remind people that when this Government came to office it made a number of promises in the area of social security; promises about which people should be reminded. In relation to income support programs, the Australian Labor Party, in its 1983 policy speech, promised:
We are committed to raising over a three-year period the basic pension rate from 22 per cent of average male earnings . . . to 25 per cent.

Labor has been in office for more than three years and that promise remains unfulfilled. In December 1985 the pension was $97.90; still nowhere near the 25 per cent level. That promise has not been honoured. In 1984 the Labor Party was rather more circumspect, when it said:
. . . we will continue to work towards the goal of raising the basic pension rate to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.
They are fine words and that is something that it can say it has done, even if it does not get there. In relation to the rate of unemployment benefit, in 1983 Labor promised:
Unemployment benefits will be progressively increased until adult beneficiaries reach equality with single pensioners.

In November 1985, the last figures I have, the rate of unemployment benefit was $88.20 and the rate of pension was $3 more than that; another promise not honoured. In relation to the family income supplement, in 1983 Labor made the promise that it would:
. . . reform . . . the family income supplement . . . by relaxing the income test so that the supplement is reduced by only 25 cents for each extra dollar of family income.

That was a promise, in other words, to alter the taper to make the withdrawal rate less severe for people who earn some other income. To date there has been no change in the rate of taper of the income test. That is another promise which has not been honoured in the area of social security policy by the Labor Government in the time it has been in office. In relation to the consumer price index adjustments, in 1983 the Labor Party promised:
Pensions will be adjusted on the basis of the immediately prior six months CPI movement to cut the present lag of four months to one month.

I have to report that pensions are still adjusted on a twice yearly basis, in May and November, in line with the CPI figures for the previous six months to December and June. In other words, the lag is still there, exactly as it was; that promise has not been honoured. Finally, I draw attention to some of the promises in the area of taxation. In 1983 the Labor Party promised:
. . . immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australian taxpayers.
I remember the Labor Party saying those fine words. It said:
A taxpayer without dependants earning $225 a week, for example, will get a tax cut of $4.76 a week.
I tell the Senate that, with fiscal drag, the tax cuts have never materialised and we now face the prospect of a further delay in the promised tax cuts later this year.

Poverty is increasing in this country. We keep hearing about the increases in poverty and about the extra imposts upon our citizens. I need look no further than the statements of the Minister for Social Security, Mr Brian Howe, in talking about poverty in Australia. He has said:
And poverty-especially among women and children-remains a matter of pressing urgency . . . The increasing recognition of this poverty amongst women-what has been called the feminisation of poverty-
I agree with the Minister there-
forces us to think about poverty and powerlessness in different ways.

Mr Gerry Hand has told us that poverty in Australia has increased during the three years of the Labor Government. A member of the Labor Caucus has said that poverty has actually increased since Labor came to government. Of course, this is part of the pre-Budget manoeuvring to try to ensure that the money is not cut out of the social security budget to the detriment of pensioners and beneficiaries. Mr Howe conceded that the social welfare benefit system is `woefully inadequate'.

The Western Australian Labor Government has placed social welfare near the bottom of the political agenda. The report of the Carter Inquiry into Welfare and Community Services in Western Australia has been pigeon-holed. Almost no action has been taken on its recommendations, yet close to a quarter of a million Western Australians live in poverty, according to the Western Australian Council of Social Service. Both the former Minister for Community Services, Keith Wilson, and the current Minister, Kay Hallahan, have given welfare reform a low priority. People concerned with welfare in Western Australian find it hard to establish contact with them. Duncan Graham, the welfare writer for the National Times and the head of the Carter review, Bishop Challen, are two good examples of critics of the Western Australian system. Bishop Challen complained about what was happening in that State and the result was that the Community Services Board, of which he was the Chairman, was axed. After that Board was axed, the Vice-Chairman of the Board, Moira Rayner, said:
Those of us who have worked so hard to reform the antiquated welfare system in this State-
that is, Western Australia-

have been shocked and saddened by the action which removes the only independent advisory body able to act as a check on the Department, advise the Government on the Department's policies and establish links with the community.

The point I am making is that in a nation where we have Gerry Hand telling us that poverty is increasing and welfare continues to be an urgent matter for people whose lives depend on the adequacy of what they receive, the Western Australian Labor Government has failed to meet the aspirations of moderate members of the community. I return to the Bill and say that the Opposition will not oppose it. The Opposition's proposed amendment raises its concerns about the amnesty and other matters in the legislation. I ask the Minister to respond to the concerns I have about the homelessness allowance. Otherwise, the Opposition will assist in the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill makes a number of changes to the social security arrangements, many of which will remove present anomalies. I will speak to just one of those amendments which will introduce a new element into social security. The provision of a young homeless allowance is something which has long been needed and for which I have been campaigning longer than I have been in the Senate. I am delighted that it will apply from 1 July. This allowance will apply to 16 and 17-year-olds who are homeless and without support. The allowance will be at a level which equates with the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance, which is currently just over $73 a week. It will be in the form of a supplement to any benefit to which the young person is entitled, to bring the allowance up to that level. In other words, it is not something which will be received on top of other benefits, as I have heard some people claim.

SPEECH.PARA: There are no firm figures or even very reliable estimates of the young people who are in need of this allowance. In fact, some people even claim that the numbers involved are not significant. I was pleased to hear Senator Peter Baume imply otherwise. Some people would say those numbers are not significant, compared to, say the needs of older people who are homeless or need help. But this group has not really has any provision made especially for them in the past, and society has tended to ignore their existence believing, as I have heard it said here and elsewhere at times, that children-note the word `children'-should be at home until they form a new family of their own or at least until they are 21. That view totally ignores reality, particularly the reality of households where I am sure none of us would wish young people to stay.

Young people who are homeless usually do not have the knowledge, the experience or the support that even a woman leaving a violent marriage may have, because they are young. Until now they have been doubly disadvantaged by not having any safety net which allows them to live with some minimal security if they cannot remain with their parents. As I said, there are no reliable figures available but we do know that youth refuges in most parts of Australia cannot cope with the demand for places-and they see only the tip of the iceberg. Figures for refuges do not necessarily reflect the overall picture, as those seeking emergency accommodations are sometimes accommodated in other ways for a short period, such as in friends' houses. So the demand for medium and long term accommodation is much greater than it is for refuges.

Because what opposition there has been to the introduction of this allowance seems to be centred on the belief that it will actually encourage young people to leave home, I point out that very strict conditions will apply, ensuring there will be no abuse of this provision. I point out, too, that these conditions are much stricter than even, for example, those that apply to the tertiary education assistance scheme which, unfortunately and possibly unavoidably, is widely abused by parents who falsify their tax returns. These conditions are, first, that the young person must be living away from home for one of a number of reasons, these being either that the parents, or neither parent if the parents are not living together, will allow the young person to live at home or domestic violence or incestuous harassment or other such exceptional circumstances that make it unreasonable for the young person to live with his or her parents. That is the first condition. Secondly, the young person must not receive continuous support from either parent or from any other person acting as a long term guardian. That is fairly wide. Thirdly, the young person must not receive continuous income support from any government source, State or Federal, other than a benefit. All those three conditions must be met for the allowance to be granted. I do not think it could be made much stricter.

Those who think this payment will be an incentive to leave home have obviously never been in that situation for themselves. It is simply much cheaper to live at home, quite apart from the benefits which derive from a supportive home and family. This is a second best for those who do not have the option of remaining at home. In the debate in the other place an Opposition member said that the amendment would mean that parents prone to reject their children would have no reason to give them a second thought. It is a tragic fact that some parents do not give their children a second thought. The same member went on to talk about parents who ignore court orders for maintenance. He seemed to believe that the government was responsible for both these evils. I am sure he will be pleased to learn that the present Government is planning to do what no other Government has done in the past-that is, to make sure that maintenance, where an order is made, is paid, as announced by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) last week.

Parents have a legal as well as a moral obligation to look after their children to the age of 18 years, but many do not meet that responsibility or put intolerable conditions on it. I will come to that point in a moment. I worked for a number of years as a student counsellor in a secondary school, so I am speaking from experience. Some young people, as Senator Baume mentioned before, leave home for what, to an outsider anyway, may seem trivial reasons-such as a row about which boyfriend they are allowed to go out with or which clothes they are allowed to wear to school. But these young people usually return home fairly soon, particularly if there is someone available to act as an intermediary between parents and son or daughter. This amendment is designed to help those whose reasons for leaving home, or being thrown out of home, are much more serious-young people who have no reasonable alternative.

To begin with the least dramatic examples, some parents want their sons or daughters to leave school or to stay at school, and make that a condition of their remaining at home. I recall the case of a girl of about 16 who left school against her parents' wishes and was then locked out of the house. We had to get police help to enable her to collect her clothes and personal belongings. On the other hand, there are parents who refuse to maintain their children at home if they do not leave school. Unfortunately this particularly happens with girls, because some parents believe that education is wasted on females. As another example, family break-ups can lead to either a new, blended family or a series of surrogate parents with conflict between the young person and the adults. This situation can become intolerable on both sides and lead to an inevitable break.

Many young people are subjected to domestic violence, or are traumatised by witnessing it being inflicted on a parent or younger sibling. Then there are the young people who are themselves the victims of incest, in some cases over a number of years until they are old enough and courageous enough to make the break and get out of the house. Some young people I know had friends to turn to, if they were lucky, or their friends' parents or house sharers were willing to take them in. The alternative in the district where I worked were the railway station waiting rooms, the carriages in the railway siding at night and, for those small enough to get in, the bins for donated clothing. Other young people have told me that they walk the streets at night so that they can sleep in the daytime when it is warmer. The places where these young people congregate can then become a recruiting ground for prostitution and crime, and drugs can offer to the lonely and depressed a solace, especially if dealing in drugs offers a young person the income that he or she would not otherwise have.

The young homeless allowance is a safety net, consistent with this government's policy of enabling all Australians to live with dignity, their basic needs being met. It follows the Government's increased funding for youth refuges this financial year and is part of the progression towards youth-related allowances for young people who are not in employment. As one with many years experience of working both professionally and informally with young people, I am proud to be a part of a government which is seriously addressing the problems faced by young people. The amendment will not affect vast numbers of young Australians but for those it does affect it could well save their futures or even, if we look at the statistics for young suicides, their lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill before the Senate tonight is an interesting Bill because of the range of issues it covers and the number of problems it seeks to correct. The sorts of issues it covers begin with the question of the granting of an amnesty on unintentional fraud-certainly not the sort of instances that Senator Peter Baume mentioned occur from time to time; that is, people picking up cheques in 37 different names or otherwise deliberately defrauding the system. Nobody in their right mind would want people like that to be given any sort of amnesty. But there is from time to time a necessity to provide an amnesty to people who for one reason or another, sometimes through misunderstanding the system or through no fault of their own, have been part of what appears to be a fraud against the system. They deserve, in fact need, whatever assistance and benefit of doubt that governments can give to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also provides for access of students to various benefits and for ways of assisting young homeless people by way of an additional allowance. It is wide reaching in regard to the number of people it covers and it is far reaching in relation to the potential effect that various sections of the legislation can have on the people who are covered by the legislation. That is not to say that it is not without its problems. The Bill covers a wide range of departments and that means that considerable headache can be caused to likely beneficiaries who are trying to find their way around the various new sections in the legislation.

The involvement of the Department of Education, for example, as I have been made aware in recent weeks, has caused some problems for likely beneficiaries or for current beneficiaries who may have their benefits jeopardised. I have been concerned over recent weeks at the difficulty that I and my colleague Senator Macklin, who is the Australian Democrat's spokesperson for the portfolio of education, have had and that, indeed, the Parliamentary Library had when we finally turned to it to get hold of a definition of what would appear to be a fairly simple thing-what is a full time student. There appears to be nothing in any piece of legislation that we could locate that actually defined it; yet, that definition of the legislation and its impact on the community is vital, I would suggest, to the understanding of the Parliament and the public, and certainly to the understanding of the people affected by the legislation. I would have thought that such a key element of the legislation as the definition of full time students, which in fact is a heading to one significant clause in the legislation, would have been made. These sorts of definitions deal with beneficiary's incomes, maintenance and education allowances, and need to be much better defined than we have had defined to us.

I say now to the Minister and to the officials present who are presumably from the relevant departments that if we cannot get some clearer definition of just what exactly a full time student is, we are going to contemplate moving an amendment to oppose clause 33. It is quite ridiculous to have the sort of gobbledegook that is in clause 33 about full time students when nobody seems to know just exactly what a full time student is regarding access to the tertiary education assistance scheme, unemployment benefits or any other sort of benefit under this or any other piece of legislation.

In addition, I have been approached by a number of organisations concerning the provisions of this Bill that relate to the so-called young homeless allowance. This Bill provides for an increase in the level of income support received by unemployment, sickness or special beneficiaries who are 16 or 17, who are single, who are without dependents, and who are classified as homeless. Clause 28 of the Bill provides for a new section 112 (4e) which defines a homeless person as one who, first, has not lived with either parent for a period of six weeks, either due to parents not allowing them to do so or because of domestic violence, incestuous harassment or other such exceptional circumstances. I am not quite sure how everybody is supposed to prove that or how capable the people they are expected to tell this to are of assessing the likelihood of these things having occurred. The second definition of a homeless person is a person who is not in receipt of any other continuous support from parents, other guardians, of course, or any other government source. New sections (4f) and (4g) define the increase in benefit with the effect that the allowance takes this homeless rate of unemployment benefit, et cetera, up to the independent level of TEAS.

I must say that the Democrats are delighted that the Government has finally responded to the demands that we and other concerned groups in the community have made over the years for the extension of assistance for rent and housing beyond the supplementary assistance which has been available to certain beneficiaries but which has not until now been extended to the large number of unemployment beneficiaries, many of whom are in very grave need of this sort of assistance. Sadly, of course, as Senator Baume indicated in his speech a little while ago, these moves are essentially band-aid measures in the face of the major problems of unemployment and housing-problems which are facing this Government and which it has yet to actively address.

I must, however, take up Senator Baume's comments about the fact that negative gearing across Australia in the months since that legislation was mooted has caused a considerable drop to the private rental sector. In fact, the figures on rental vacancy rates do not hold this to be true to any real extent in any capital city except Perth, where the relative rates for January and February this year are considerably lower than the relative rates for January and February last year. I suspect that has less to do with negative gearing than it has to do with preparations for the America's Cup. In Canberra, for example, the rates have gone up significantly in the 12 months since January and February 1985. They have gone up in Adelaide in the same period. In Adelaide in January 1985 the monthly vacancy rate was 2.5 whereas in January of this year it was 3.1. In Brisbane in January 1985 it was 3.9 and in January of this year it was 4.2. In Canberra last year it was 0.3 which is extraordinarily low given that 10 times that amount is accepted as an adequate monthly average vacancy rate, and it was 2.7 in January of this year. Perth, as I said, dropped significantly. Sydney dropped marginally and Melbourne dropped marginally, but there certainly has not been any significant drop across the country in monthly vacancy rates in the private rental market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think next year might produce a change?

—If one looks at the monthly vacancy rates across any given year, they bounce up and down, and the variation is anything up to point five of a per cent. When talking in terms of between 1 per cent and 3 per cent, 0.5 per cent is not particularly significant. It happens on an annual basis because of seasonal problems. If what people are arguing at the moment is that the January, February and March figures are an indication that negative gearing is making it harder for people who need to get housing in the private rental market, I suggest they look closer at those figures because there is no real justification for it in any city other than Perth. As I have already said, I really suspect that there are other outside reasons, slightly damper reasons, for that happening.

SPEECH.PARA: While the general principle behind this particular amendment is something that we believe is laudable, there are certainly shortcomings concerning the youth homeless allowance in the form it is provided for in this piece of legislation. The definition of homelessness provided in clause 28 (2) is particularly narrow, which in many ways is appropriate, as has already been indicated tonight, but it in fact fails to allow for adequate account to be taken of emotional and psychological factors which may make a home environment intolerable and, in fact, in some instances, dangerous for a young person. The attempted exclusion by clause 33 in the Bill of students from access to various benefits would have the effect essentially, at least as far as my interpretation of it is concerned-it is a fairly tortuous clause-of denying special benefits to homeless students who may currently have access to income support through other avenues or, in particular, who would like to have access to income support through this particular benefit but for a variety of rather prolix reasons expressed through this Bill may not. The consequence is going to mean some incentive for some students in this group to be forced to discontinue their study through lack of support.

Organisations such as the Australian Capital Territory Youth Accommodation Group have also brought to my attention, as I imagine it has also brought to the attention of Senator Baume and no doubt members of the Government, a number of other problems associated with this Bill. These include the six week waiting period prior to the payment of benefits during which special benefit was previously available to young people who wished to study.

Another area is the inevitable administrative problems which will be involved in the co-ordination of the responsibilities of the departments of Education and Social Security in this area. I repeat that Senator Macklin and I-we have a joint interest in this Bill-have had some difficulty in collating the various definitions that are needed from those two departments. Furthermore, the Department of Education is not necessarily staffed with personnel with the counselling skills that would be appropriate and necessary for dealing with the young people who have suffered the domestic violence, incestuous harassment or other exceptional circumstances which are required by the Bill.

It has also been put to me that the Department of Education is proposing to investigate young people's claims of homelessness by writing to ask their parents whether they have been telling the truth about domestic violence, sexual harassment, incest and so on. That strikes me as a most peculiar way of going about helping students who seem to me to be in a most awful psychological and emotional state anyway. That may or may not be correct, but it certainly is the information I have been given. I should be delighted to find out that the Department will use some other touchstone to find out whether these students are accurate when they make allegations about having to leave home because of those three criteria. So, very real concerns have been raised, including one relating to the secrecy provisions contained in clause 5 with regard to the information given by students to departmental personnel. Those secrecy provisions are considered to be inadequate.
