The attempt in clause 33 to abolish the access of full time students to benefits is a matter that is also of considerable concern to us, and to the students who perceive that they will have much more limited access to a benefit that they consider is essential to their continuing with a course of study. Many students who in the broadest sense may be eligible for an allowance but who through no fault of their own, such as their parents' income, are disqualified from eligibility for those allowances will now find themselves without any adequate avenue of support to enable them to undertake study-either to begin it or to continue it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that there ought to be an alternative education allowance?

—No, I am not suggesting that, although we have suggested for a long time-and this Government to its credit has come to accept-that the levels of the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance and the unemployment benefit have been considerably out of kilter. Students who are attempting to go through a post-secondary course, presumably not just to improve their minds but to improve their value to the community, ought to have ready access to a reasonable level of benefit, whether it is the unemployment benefit or the TEAS allowance. It does not matter what it is called, so long as they have access to some benefit that allows them to continue that field of study without an additional impediment being put in their way.

SPEECH.PARA: The main people with whom I have had dealings are an Australian Capital Territory group who wrote to me saying that they were concerned that the legislation putting the youth homeless allowance in place would pass through Parliament without any real consultation with those groups. I am sure that in a moment the Minister will tell me how much consultation did take place with the groups concerned with this legislation. The letter said:
It quite clearly will make it harder for young people to stay in full-time study if they are not supported by their parents.
That is, that the contents of the legislation will make it harder. The letter continued:

At the moment the Social Security Act 1947 makes provision for the payment of Special Benefit to these young people and this is supported by recent Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions. Income maintenance is a Commonwealth Government responsibility. The Commonwealth has clearly abdicated its responsibility for the 6 week waiting period, during which it intends to do nothing and hope that these young people drop out of the education system.

I hope that that suggestion made by my petitioners is not true and that the Government is not hoping that people will drop out of the education system. I imagine that the Government acknowledges, as we do, that we need all the help we can get in the next few decades and well-educated people are an asset to any country. The letter continued:
State and voluntary welfare agencies will once again cop the brunt of a Commonwealth cost-cutting exercise in welfare.

The letter included a copy of a letter that had been sent to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and his reply, which the group judged to be unsatisfactory, and I must confess so did I, because it was a rather patronising attempt to mollify and soothe people but did not address any of the issues they raised. The reply simply said:
. . . the government has sought to deal with the very difficult underlying social issues involved in youth homelessness and the outcome is a most innovative example of social policy.

I do not know that the people who have been writing to me doubt that it is an innovative attempt to come to grips with the issues. They are arguing that it might not be a particularly successful one. The group's letter continued:
It is clear that it is going to be an administrative nightmare to involve the Department of Education in the implementation of a welfare-based scheme when they have no expertise and no resources.

The group put to me a number of other issues, including problems of the eligibility criteria, the whole question of proof of domestic violence and sexual harassment and the capability of officers to judge that, the question of the six-week waiting period, the adequacy or otherwise of the level of benefit, and the problems I mentioned earlier of what they perceive as lack of consultation. I trust that the Minister will be able to inform me that there are no problems in that area. I certainly hope that is the case, because it would appear that the Senate is not in a position to make any amendments to the legislation to correct some of the problems these people see as existing.

The other major area covered by this legislation is the social security amnesty. Again, I applaud the Government for taking socially responsible and sympathetic action in this area. The recognition by the Government that many ordinary people have real difficulties with the complexity of the social security system and the attempt to avoid ongoing overpayments in cases where the Government has not been able to find the staff to correct them in any other way are overdue. We accept that that is the position. We certainly do not expect-I do not think anybody expects-the sort of person who deliberately defrauds the system, the sort of person mentioned by Senator Peter Baume, to be given any sort of amnesty at all; but in the social security system we are dealing with a lot of elderly people who can get themselves caught up in a treadmill unwittingly, through no fault of their own, and who need to be dealt with by these sorts of extraordinary measures from time to time. In fighting the problem of social security fraud the Government has drawn the distinction that must be drawn between those who systematically rip off the system and those who, because of the inadequacy of the benefits or their lack of understanding of how the system operates, are more or less pushed into a position of receiving overpayments to which they are not entitled.

The other action the Government ought to take is to increase staff in the Department of Social Security. The Government acknowledges that inadequate staffing has led to the problem, and the problem has led to the need for this proposal to clear the decks before the Department can get on with its job. But it offers no long term increase in staff as a method of catching the systematic cheats. I acknowledge that the Government has a problem here. The people who scream about the problem of fraud and overservicing will be exactly the same people who scream if the number of public servants in the Department of Social Security is increased in order to stop the fraud and overpayments.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Visits of Nuclear Powered Naval Vessels: Safety Procedures-Queensland Economy

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some remarks to the port safety scheme concerning the visits of nuclear-powered warships to Western Australia. Since all my remarks will be directed to that document, I seek leave to table a copy.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This copy of allegedly a draft document, which would be better called a secret document, has unofficially become available to me. It was first ordered in 1976 by the then Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair. Since that time 67 nuclear-powered vessels have visited Western Australian ports. Some 10 years later that document is still in a draft form. The document is quite extraordinary, more for its omissions than for what it contains. There are three blank sections which are of great significance to the public. After 10 years and 67 nuclear-powered warship visits, these sections are still blank. They are part 4, an evacuation plan; part 6, the issue of potassium iodate tablets-to be prepared; and part 7, a public information plan-to be prepared. These pages are absolutely blank. It has taken some 10 years for the relevant authorities to get even that far. This document is dated November 1984. Evidently, some work has been done on it since then but it is the most recent copy I could manage to get.

SPEECH.PARA: Decontamination procedures are not even mentioned in this document. There are many confusions contained in the document. I will list just some of those. For example, it is very unclear as to whose responsibility it is to remove an immobilised nuclear-powered warship. In section 3-3, sub-section 73 (j), the Commonwealth Government is given this responsibility. In section 4a-3, sub-paragraph a14, the Fremantle Port Authority is delegated the task of removing the warship. In another section, section 3-4 (76f), the Royal Australian Navy is given the task of removing a leaking vessel, contaminating the area of the port as it goes, to a safe area away from the population centres.

There is also confusion in the emergency procedures. For example, the State police are given control of the evacuation of the public from a threatened area. In another section the State Emergency Services are given the duty of arranging emergency powers. Another section deals with the implementation of controls and restrictions of foodstuffs. That is given over to the Department of Health. One would think that one organisation ought to have all those duties to perform. There is no single organisation which has those duties, so I believe there is a great overlapping of tasks and a confusion of responsibilities which in an emergency situation would be untenable. Unless it was a well practised program-for example, a fire drill or a cyclone drill-there would be absolute chaos if these so-called safety plans had to be put into operation.
The document does contain prepared statements in the event of an accident, with varying degrees of urgency. If it were a serious accident, the report handles it this way:

As a result of the radiation accident aboard the nuclear powered warship USS ..............., it is considered advisable, as a precautionary measure, to evacuate residents within the following areas ................
There could be many suburbs in the coastal strip in Perth and Fremantle which would need evacuation in the event of a serious accident. I quote again from the document:

Police and State Emergency Service officers are on duty in the affected areas to notify and assist those people required to be evacuated. If requested, please leave your homes and places of work in an orderly fashion. Arrangements have been made for transport, for the collection of the incapacitated and for the subsequent security of the evacuated area. Take only that which you deem essential for a 48 hour absence.

Yet, as I mentioned, there are no evacuation plans listed in the document. Since this document was released to the Western Australian media a week ago my office has had calls from fire brigade officers, from members of the Pharmaceutical Council of Western Australia and from State Emergency Services workers, all of whom say that they are unaware of any emergency procedures to deal with a nuclear accident. If the professionals are not trained, one wonders what would happen in the event of an emergency. The people who would have to to deal with such a critical situation do not have any training for it; they do not know what to do. So if an accident occurred there would be total chaos.

I would like to outline various responses we have had to this document being released. First, from the Government. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) very unwisely talked on a radio talkback program in Perth last Tuesday and exposed the total inadequacy of this plan. He said quite categorically that there are three things which the Federal Government is doing to regulate this situation. First, it is conducting 24-hour radiation monitoring whenever these warships are in port. That is not questionable and it is certainly the least that can be done. The second thing the Government would do is remove the vessel to a safe anchorage. The place where the nuclear-powered submarines tie up in Western Australia is Cockburn Sound. There is a very narrow channel into Cockburn Sound. For a warship to get out of that channel, presumably leaking its radioactive contamination all the way, it has to go right past the coastal strip, right past the population centres, to get to whatever would be a safe anchorage. That was the second thing that Mr Beazley said the Government would do. The third thing that he said the Government is doing is monitoring the situation around the clock when the ships are in port. His No. 1 and No. 3 items are absolutely identical. If there was a list of three, he could not even remember the third item. It shows what a total farce it is for the Commonwealth Government to invite these ships in and then not to follow through and make sure that adequate emergency procedures are in place.

In the State Government's response, the Minister for the Environment, Mr Hodge, said that more work had been done on the document since November 1984, the date on the document I have just tabled, and that it would be presented to Cabinet soon. I remind the Senate that that is 10 years and 67 nuclear-powered warship visits later. The decision then would be made about whether to let the public know what is in the document. I think that that is an outrageous statement. That was the only statement that the State Government made on that matter. What a cheek! People have a right to know what is in that document and they must demand that information. The Ministers for Environment, Health, and Emergency Services in Western Australia were all invited to give the Government's view to various media outlets in Perth last week. All declined. That is typical of the Burke Government. If an issue arises which it does not want to deal with it just goes silent and it is very difficult to get a public debate on the issue. However, there has been a certain amount of public debate on this issue because other people have been prepared to speak when the Government Ministers have remained silent.

In the response from the Public Service we heard from Mr Jim McNulty, the Executive Director of Public Health, who announced that he had brought in a store of 50,000 potassium iodate tablets about five years ago. In the statement he made he was really saying: `Do not worry, folks. That is okay. We have this store on hand'. He also admitted that he was not sure about how those tablets would be distributed. There are many questions that need to be asked in the face of such a pathetic response. Are those potassium iodate tablets out of date by now if they were bought five years ago? Where are they stored? Who has access to them in an emergency? Does Mr McNulty seriously believe that 50,000 potassium iodate tablets would be enough to prevent thyroid problems for the hundreds of thousands of people who might be affected in the coastal strip in the case of an emergency? Potassium iodate tablets must be distributed immediately radiation occurs, or they would be useless. So, if there is not that distribution process ready to go into place smoothly, those 50,000 tablets-pathetic as that stock would be-would be totally useless. Those tablets could only help with one of the three types of radiation damage from which people could suffer in the event of a nuclear accident. There is nothing that can be done to alleviate the problems caused by caesium 137, which attacks muscle tissue, or strontium 90, which attacks bone tissue. Even if the public did feel some sense of security about Mr McNulty's statements that potassium iodate tablets were in store, the public needs to know that that would deal only with a possible one-third of the problem, only one of the three types of radiation sickness that could result. Therefore, I believe that it is a gross irresponsibility for the Director of the Department of Health to try to placate the public's worries by saying: `All's well folks, we have 50,000 of these tablets hidden somewhere'.

The United States Consulate in Western Australia, Mr Steve Ecton, also made a response. He replied to the publicity by defending the United States Navy's safety record. In other words, he is saying: `Don't worry, folks, an accident will never happen'. This is a little like the man who jumped out of a twentieth storey window and who was heard to say as he floated past the tenth storey: `Well, so far so good'. It is more by good luck than good management that we have not had a problem with a nuclear-powered, or for that matter a nuclear-armed, ship in an Australian port. Until now we have been lucky. But we have news for Mr Ecton. Accidents do happen. Of course, in this situation we hope that they will not. For example, crews of three nuclear-powered vessels failed their safety tests in 1985. I quote from the West Australian of Tuesday, 30 April 1985:
The crews of three US Navy nuclear-powered warships recently failed annual tests of their ability to operate nuclear reactors safely, according to Defence Department officials.
The officials said the crews of the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson-which last week visited Fremantle-and the guided missile-cruisers California and South Carolina failed the tests.

The test, known as the operational reactor safeguard examination, has been administered each year since 1967 by a board of four officers, one a former commander of a nuclear-powered ship, and the other three engineers who have served aboard nuclear-powered ships.

Naval officers said a typical test, which would run from two to five days, was designed to check every aspect of operation, including training, maintenance and administration. The test also included casualty drills.
In 1985 crews on three United States naval ships failed the test, so that is not very reassuring.
A report released by a private research group-the Fund for Constitutional Government-published in the West Australian on 21 July 1983 stated:

US Navy ships have leaked radiation at least 37 times since they began using nuclear reactors, contaminating coastal and inshore waters off Japan, Britain and the United States on more than a dozen occasions.

Two United States submarines-Thresher and Scorpion-have also been lost at sea and there have been many more accidents with nuclear powered vessels of both the Soviet Navy and the United States Navy. However, here we are concerned about United States ships because they are the ones that come into Australian ports.

Mr Ecton also said that nuclear reactors on board warships were safe and that they were not as dangerous as the one which has had such a bad problem in the Ukraine. However, I believe that nuclear reactors on board warships are more dangerous than ground-based reactors for several reasons. The 352 reactors on board those Navy ships have no independent monitoring facilities. A test to which I referred earlier was carried out by that Navy, and the same is true of the French Navy, the British Navy, the Chinese Navy and the Soviet Navy. They manage their own affairs. Defence departments are notoriously secretive about what goes on inside their environs so there is no independent monitor, nothing like the International Atomic Energy Agency. Of course, many people think that that agency is inadequate but there is not even anything like that agency to keep check on the operation of the nuclear navies.

There is no heavy containment dome around any of the 352 reactors on board nuclear naval vessels. If there were they would sink. They are contained in steel containers but if there were a melt down that would rapidly melt and the reactor core would go through a hole in the bottom of the ship and also blow out of the top; so, there is no heavy container dome on any of those ships. The nuclear reactors have to be compressed into a very small space because space is extremely limited, particularly on submarines. These reactors are mobile and therefore they are liable to collisions, as are all ships. So there is that problem as well. Reactors also use highly enriched weapons-grade material, therefore contamination relative to the size of the generators is more dangerous than what came out of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor.

Finally, this document deals only with nuclear powered warships. Ships bearing nuclear weapons, which tie up right alongside Fremantle harbour and in other Western Australian ports, are not even mentioned. This document does not even pretend to deal with nuclear weapons accidents which can also occur while ships are tied up in port. I do not want to scare people by suggesting that nuclear weapons can accidentally explode. Unless they are triggered they will not explode but they can suffer piercing accidents and they can also be involved in fires on board ship. Their radioactive contamination can leak out if there are those kinds of accidents on board the ships when they are tied up in ports.

I believe that all State governments which receive visits from nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships should release their port safety plans to the public in each State. People have the right to know the risks that are involved and they have a right to know what precautions the State emergency services have ready in the event of an accident. This port safety scheme was drawn up by a committee consisting of a member of the Royal Australian Navy, the Fremantle Port Authority, the Premier's Department, the State Police, the Australian Federal Police and State emergency services. If all of those groups, working together for 10 years, have still failed to come up with a plan, I believe that we are taking far too great a risk by even allowing warships to come into our ports.

Obviously the so-called experts are not ready in the event of an accident. As I have said, we hope that one will not happen, but if it does happen, there will be chaos. I believe that the Federal Government, which invites these hazardous ships into our ports, should do one of two things: It should come clean with the public, admit the risks, make public the emergency plans and actually practise those emergency plans. It should make sure that there is a store of potassium iodate tablets in every home in every port in Australia that is visited by these dangerous ships. There should also be a booklet in every home, something like the drug offensive booklet, which outlines to people the dangers and the risks they are being subjected to and which also lists assembly points, decontamination procedures, evacuation plans, what foods and what behaviour should be avoided in the event of an accident. Those items should be in every home in every port in Australia which is visited by nuclear warships. Preferably, the Federal Government should refuse entry of such environmentally hazardous ships into our ports. That is the option I would prefer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last 12 months the Queensland Government has been subjected to some vicious attacks in the Senate and in the other place. Today was no exception. We continually see the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, being asked dorothy dixers by either Senator Reynolds or Senator Jones which allows him to put the boot into the Queensland Government. I am not complaining about that; all is fair in love and war. But I want to record today some accurate statistics sourced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I believe that Senator Walsh, Senator Jones and to a degree Senator Maguire are selectively quoting from statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Maguire has taken a quite uncommon interest in the Queensland economy, since he is a senator representing South Australia. I quote Mr Will Buttrose, an economist with Lloyds Bank. He said that the South Australian economy is the worst in Australia. I suggest to Senator Maguire that he lease or give his meagre talents to Mr Bannon and see whether he can help the South Australian Government to lift its game. One of the accusations made recently by Senator Walsh and the leader of a political party in Queensland was that Queensland has the highest rate of unemployment in Australia. I think we should examine that statement in the context that the Australian Bureau of Statistics looks at it. I quote directly from the Australian Bureau of Statistics because that statement needs to be examined in the correct context. The ABS states:

The decrease in unemployment in Queensland in the past 12 months, ended April 1986, has been 4.8% (-4.8%) or 5,600 and represents the fastest decrease in unemployment of any State. It is well above the -0.5% achieved nationally.
In the 12 months ended April 1986 employment in Queensland grew by 72,600, or 7.1%. Queensland's employment growth rate of 7.1% is the highest of any State and well above the national rate of 5.4%.
The ABS continues:
It would be expected that Queensland's strong employment growth would have made greater roads into unemployment in this State.
The reason for this lies in the combined high growth rate in the State's work force.
In the 12 months ending April 1986, Queensland's labour force growth was 5.9% which was the highest rate of increase of any State and compares with a 4.9% national labour force growth rate.
The growth in the Queensland labour force reflects a sharp increase in the labour force participation rate which rose from 59.5% in April 1985 to 62.2% in April 1986.

It is hard to determine precise reasons for such a movement in labour force participation rates, however an answer may lie with the problems confronting rural industries. Low international commodity prices, drought conditions, high interest rates and the proposed fringe benefits tax are impacting. This in turn may have led wives and children of rural producers and some small business people to stabilize family incomes. e.g. participation rates in the Fitzroy/Mackay region was 61.6%, in north western Queensland 61.4% and in north Queensland 63.4%-well above the Queensland average participation rate of 59.9%.

As I see it, as high interest rates and lower commodity prices impact on the farming community, particularly in the sugar areas, wives are having to go out to work. They are seeking jobs in restaurants, hotels and motels to be able to sustain their properties and just to hold the line. I know of many people who are going through this. The wives are getting jobs simply, so to speak, to keep the wolves from the door. Queensland has created more jobs than any other State, with 7.1 per cent compared with the national growth rate of 3.8 per cent. It has created 72,000 jobs in real terms, or 20 per cent of all jobs created in Australia. That is a record of which any government in Australia should be proud.

Another accusation is that Queensland has the lowest numbers of tertiary education places and students in Australia. That is correct; that is dead right. Queensland has 16.2 per cent of the population yet the Federal Government returns to Queensland in tertiary education funding only 14.4 per cent of Commonwealth grants for universities and 15.7 per cent of Commonwealth grants for colleges of advanced education. That represents a short changing in money terms of $28m and a loss in tertiary places and educational opportunities of 2,900 university places and 1,000 places in colleges of advanced education. In addition, Queensland misses out on funding for technical and further education institutions by receiving only 14.16 per cent of Federal Government funding. The lack of places is the result of Queensland's receiving a disproportionately low share of Commonwealth funds in the three areas of tertiary education-universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions.

In 1984-85 an allocation of Commonwealth funds to Queensland based on 16.3 per cent of the Australian population would have provided an increase in funding to Queensland universities and colleges of advanced education of $34.9m. To bring Queensland up to the national average would require in excess of 6,000 extra student places and associated funding for the universities and advanced education sectors alone. Tertiary education numbers are, therefore, not an economic factor. It is a factor that relies on Commonwealth funding. Commonwealth funding is around 14.4 per cent when Queensland has 16.2 per cent or 16.3 per cent of the population.

Another accusation that has been levelled at the Queensland Government is that Queensland has had no increase in full time employment. That is false. The source for my figures is the Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force statistics for Australia for April 1986. In the month of April 1986, full time employment in Queensland increased by 11,000 or 1.3 per cent to 879,400. In Australia as a whole, full time employment increased by 18,500 or 0.3 per cent to 5,620,000. For the 12-month period ended April 1986 Queensland recorded an increase in full time employment of 55,000 jobs.

Another accusation made is that Queensland is the only State in which juvenile unemployment has increased. That is also false. The source for my figures is the same as for those just given. During April 1986 the number of 15- to 19-year-olds looking for full time work decreased by 3,100 to 19,700. This represents an unemployment rate of 20.1 per cent. In April 1985 the rate was 21.4 per cent. In March 1986 it was 23.4 per cent. Thus, it has fallen 3.4 per cent in the matter of a month.

Another allegation is that Queensland is the only State that has experienced a percentage decrease in new housing starts. That is also false. I want to put that on the record too. My source is the Australian Bureau of Statistics building approvals for Australia for March 1986. For the 12 months ended March 1986 all States except Western Australia recorded a percentage decrease. For New South Wales the decrease was 28 per cent, in Victoria 34 per cent, in Queensland 37 per cent, in South Australia 14 per cent, in Tasmania 40 per cent and the overall decrease in new home starts for Australia as a whole was 29 per cent. Only Western Australia had an increase of 3 per cent. That is an indictment of the Federal Government, not of the Queensland Government. It is an indictment of this Government's policy of high interest rates.

Another accusation that should be laid to rest is that Queensland has experienced the lowest increase in new motor vehicle registrations. Again, that is false. Continually, false accusations are made. The source for these figures is the ABS registrations of new motor vehicles in Australia in March 1986. For the month ended March 1986 the increase in the number of new motor vehicles registered in Queensland was 8.4 per cent, compared with a national increase of 6.86 per cent. For the 12 months ended March 1986, Queensland's registrations decreased by 30.6 per cent-which is a very low figure-compared with a national decrease of 31.58 per cent. Victoria led the decline with 38.78 per cent and in South Australia, where a great many motor vehicles are manufactured, the figure was 36.15 per cent. Again, that is an indictment not of the Queensland Government but of the impact already, before the legislation is passed, of the fringe benefits tax. Of course, those registrations will fall a lot further. I am sure it is of concern to the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, who I know is greatly worried about the economy of Australia.

Another accusation is that Queensland has experienced the greatest percentage increase in bankruptcies. I cannot claim that that accusation is false. But I do dispute it because I cannot qualify it. From July 1985 to April 1986 Queensland had 885 bankruptices, New South Wales had 1,097 and Victoria 812. Queensland had 212 fewer bankruptcies than New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, or 73 more than Victoria. I suppose one could say that the populations of New South Wales and Victoria are greater and that therefore the figures would show Queensland with a higher percentage. But when we research these bankruptcies we find that a great number of those recorded are for families who have gone beyond their means in debt and for pensioners who have bought things that they cannot afford. With increased interest rates people are finding that they cannot meet their commitments. They are not all business bankruptcies. There are many domestic bankruptcies in those figures. That is why I dispute them. I cannot say which are retail bankruptcies, which are business bankruptcies or which are farmers bankruptcies. But I can say that many of the bankruptcies are domestic bankruptcies. I again say to Senator Grimes that that is no economic indicator.

Another accusation is that Queensland has the second worse decrease in private capital investment. Again, I dispute those figures. My source is the Australian Bureau of Statistics State estimates of actual expenditure of new fixed capital expenditure by private enterprise in related industries for the September quarter 1985. For the September quarter this statement is correct. However, for the 12 months ended September 1985, the percentage increase was 13.8 for New South Wales, 28.8 for Victoria, 18.7 for Queensland and 7.3 for South Australia. Tasmania led the field with an increase of 89.7 per cent. The figure for Western Australia was 35.8 per cent and the figure for Australia as a whole was 22.4 per cent.

It is also said that Queensland has the greatest number of days lost through industrial disputes. I dispute this because the Queensland electricity dispute accounted for 212,000 working days lost. If we look at the figures for October, November and December 1985 and January 1986 we will find that Queensland recorded a lower number of working days lost than did any other State. In October the figure was 8,100; in November, 29,300; in December, 3,700; and in January, 1,000. New South Wales had figures of 43,000 in October, 29,600 in November, 22,700 in December and 5,700 in January. In Victoria the figure in October was 120,000 man hours lost; in November, 62,800; in December, 6,900; and in January, 4,700. In three of the four months for which information is available Queensland had under 9 per cent of the total days lost. I want to have recorded in Hansard what the editor of Rydges magazine said on 23 May 1986:

I think there are a lot of people concerned about the Queensland economy, because they see it as the health of the economy being very much dependent on the state of, well, commodity markets, which aren't looking very strong at the moment, and there's very few people predicting that they're going to improve substantially in the next 6 to 12 months. But really, when you compare what's going on with Queensland to other States, it's certainly not the worst performing State in Australia.

That quotation is from a very prominent economist with the Rydges business journal. No debate on the economy of Queensland can be discussed without looking at the low taxes that Queenslanders pay. Queensland is a low tax State. Everyone acknowledges that. The Australian Bureau of Statistics' financial estimates, its estimates of taxation revenue for Australia in 1984-85, Commonwealth Grants Commission documents and State budget papers statistically prove and show beyond any doubt that Queensland is the low tax State. They show that Victoria pays $338.50 more per capita annually than does Queensland. For New South Wales the figure is $254.73, for South Australia it is $227.90 and for Western Australia it is $117.96 more than any person pays in Queensland.

Queensland has no petroleum tax, tobacco tax or financial institutions tax. It lives without all of them. The Queensland economy is steady and reliable. It is not flash but it is making its contribution to the general economy of Australia. When it comes to exports, again Queensland leads the way. For the 12 months ended March 1986, Queensland produced 23 per cent of the export trade. For the nine months ended March 1986, Queensland's exports amounted to $5,804.7m or 23 per cent of the nation's exports. Queensland's contribution was as high as that of New South Wales. In March 1986 export trade was worth $579m or 22 per cent. Again, Queensland with 16 per cent of the population is holding its own, or more than holding its own, on exports despite the fact that exports of commodities such as sorghum, grain and wheat are down and exports of coal are down. Queensland still makes a great contribution to the Australian economy. Only 16.2 per cent of the nation's population for the 12 months ended March 1986 produced this result.

Queensland has expected new fixed capital for the 12 months to June 1986 of $2,278.9m or 16.7 per cent of the total money invested in Australia. It recorded 19.8 per cent of the dwelling unit approvals commenced in Australia for 1984-85, 19.7 per cent of total dwelling unit commencements completed in 1984-85 and 20 per cent of the total dwelling units commenced and completed for the December quarter in 1985. Queensland contributed 20.2 per cent of the value of non-residential building approvals in Australia in 1984-85 and 18.5 per cent of the value of total building approvals in 1984-85. It recorded 22 per cent of the non-building construction commencements in 1984-85 and 16.3 per cent of the new motor vehicle registrations in 1984-85. The details and statistics given in my contribution are reliably sourced. They record what is actually happening in the economy in Queensland. Even though there have been high interest and taxation rates and an absolute massacre of rural and primary industry, and Queensland has a great number of primary producers, Queensland is still hanging in there. It is playing its part in providing jobs and exports for the good of the Australian economy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 12 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory authorities currently exist under the auspices of the Minister's Department.
(2) What are the names of these authorities.
(3) What appeal mechanisms, if any, exist for the general public to lodge a complaint against these authorities.

(4) If it is proved that any member of staff of any of these authorities is guilty of incompetence, what action, if any, could be taken by a member of the public to sue the authority for compensation; if it is not possible to sue the authority, why is that the case.

(5) How many cases concerning these authorities are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and what is the delay at present between the listing of a case and its hearing before the Tribunal.
(6) If any statutory authority under the Minister's Department cannot be sued, will the Minister consider amending the relevant legislation to make this possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Six.
(2) Academic Salaries Tribunal, Australian Electoral Commission, Australian Federal Police, Commonwealth Grants Commission, National Crime Authority, Remuneration Tribunal.
(3) Appeal mechanisms are as follows:

Academic Salaries Tribunal-A person aggrieved by a decision of the Academic Salaries Tribunal of an administrative character, or conduct for the purpose of making a decision, or failure to make a decision, may be able to apply to the Federal Court for an order of review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 on the grounds set out in that Act.
Australian Electoral Commission-Rights of appeal open to the general public are provided under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Electoral and Referendum Regulations as follows:
(a) enrolment matters and registration as a general postal voter-Part X of the Act and Regulations 40a, 40b, 40c
(b) registration of political parties-s.141 of the Act
(c) validity of election results-Part XXII of the Act
Australian Federal Police-Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981.

Commonwealth Grants Commission-The Commission is responsible for providing advice to the Government on matters of federal financial relations which have been referred by the Minister for inquiry and report. Decisions of the Commission do not impact directly on the rights, privileges, benefits or other conditions of individual or groups of individuals in the general public.

National Crime Authority-Decisions of the Authority are subject to review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. Applications may also be made to the Federal Court for review of decisions under s.32 (1) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984.

Remuneration Tribunal-A person aggrieved by a decision of the Remuneration Tribunal of an administrative character, or conduct for the purpose of making a decision, or failure to make a decision, may be able to apply to the Federal Court for an order of review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 on the grounds set out in that Act.

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. For example, incompetent driving would probably be tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts. None of the authorities listed in answer to part (2) of this question is statutorily protected against general liability in tort.

(5) There are currently seven cases before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, all concerning the Australian Federal Police. All cases are listed for hearing as soon as they are lodged. The time lapse between listing and hearings varies widely depending on particular circumstances.

(6) Officers of the Australian Electoral Commission acting as Returning Officers in industrial ballots conducted under the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are protected against proceedings for defamation under Regulation 146aj (5c) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Regulations. Any amendment of this regulation is a matter for the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

Members and Acting Members of the National Crime Authority performing their office in relation to a hearing of the Authority and legal practitioners and witnesses appearing at such hearings are afforded privilege under the provisions of s.36 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 which prevents the Authority from being sued in this limited circumstance. These provisions are usual for tribunals established under Commonwealth legislation and considered necessary for the effective operation of the Authority in this role.

Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts.
None of the authorities listed in answer to Part (2) of this question is statutorily protected against general liability in tort.
(5) Cases concerning statutory authorities under the auspices of the Minister for Defence and his Department currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are as follows:

(a) The Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority is currently concerned with 6 cases, including one on which decisions are awaited as at 24 April 1986. The delay between listing and hearing varies significantly, depending upon the nature of the appeal, the type of decision the subject of the appeal, the availability of witnesses and the Tribunal's sitting timetable.

(b) The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has jurisdiction in respect of the Royal Australian Navy Central Canteens Board, Royal Australian Navy Relief Trust Fund, Australian Military Forces Relief Trust Fund, Services Canteens Trust Fund, Royal Australian Air Force Veterans' Residences Trust, Royal Australian Air Forces Welfare Trust Fund and Army and Air Force Canteens Service only in respect of applications made under the Freedom of Information Act. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sleeping Bags: Use of Imported Nylon

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was the by-law referred to in the front page lead article in the Queanbeyan Age newspaper on Friday, 14 February 1986, allowing Mont Equipment Pty Ltd to import special down-proof nylon to make its sleeping bags at a duty of 2 per cent allowed to expire.
(2) If expiry of the by-law was considered appropriate why were no transitional provisions made to maintain a reasonable level of duty on this nylon.
(3) Is the current level of duty at 40 per cent plus a $1 per square metre penalty considered an appropriate level of duty.

(4) If the answer to (3) above is no, what has been done and why was it not done sooner, to have the level of duty reviewed since it remained at this level for at least 8 months and especially as the Minister has received representations from Mont Equipment Pty Ltd.

(5) What is the Minister's attitude to the objection of the Melbourne textile manufacturer mentioned in the article to the granting of a concessional duty to this nylon on the basis that he may manufacture a nylon at some time in the future.

(6) What procedures does the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce have in place to monitor the expiry of by-laws and other similar developments that can change the rate of duty on products to ensure that a duty rate is not unintentionally allowed to change as has occurred in this case.
(7) Has the Minister put in place any changes to these procedures in the light of the expiry of the nylon duty referred to in (1) above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The by-law referred to lapsed with the termination of the Commercial By-law System on 30 June 1985. Importers were given two years notice that the by-law would lapse. They were informed of this situation in the Consolidated By-law References published by the Australian Customs Service (ACS) and by notices in Commonwealth Tariff Concession Gazettes which advised importers of the affected goods to lodge applications early to minimise possible processing delays.

(3) Yes, subject to an importer establishing that a concessional rate of duty is appropriate because goods serving similar functions are not and are not capable of being produced in Australia in the normal course of business.

(4) and (5) An application for a Tariff Concession Order was not lodged by Mont Equipment Pty Ltd until 1 August 1985, two months after the previous concession lapsed. However, the proposed concession was opposed by an Australian manufacturer who had claimed capacity to produce this material. This matter had to be resolved before the application could proceed in terms of Section 269c of the Customs Act. A prima facie case for a concession was eventually established and a proposed concession was gazetted on 23 April 1986.
(6) The duty rate in question was not unintentionally allowed to change.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What action is proposed to rectify the problem of lack of self-esteem identified among Australia's 38,000 defence spouses in the report `Supporting Service Families' now submitted to the Minister for Defence in the following areas:
(a) improved service housing accommodation;
(b) increased terms of stability in the length of postings; and
(c) improved acceptance by service hierarchy of modern attitudes towards the status of women.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) To redress the deficiencies in the housing programme for service families and thus assist in raising the self-esteem of defence spouses, the Government has embarked upon an expanded Defence housing programme that over the next decade will lead to a housing stock of greatly improved quality and meeting current community standards. Of the 22,000 houses currently managed by Defence the worst 6,000 will be progressively replaced and other houses of inadequate standard will be refurbished.

An expanded funding programme of more than $750m during the next decade is to be used to bring the current stock of houses up to standard and service people are to be given a greater degree of choice of housing.

It is the Government's intention to establish a Defence Housing Authority which will operate as a Statutory Authority, but under the Minister for Defence, to manage the total Defence Force housing stock. Legislation to establish the Authority will be introduced in the Autumn Session of 1987. An interim Defence housing agency will be established on an administrative basis in the new financial year.
The interim agency will be able to assist with much of the necessary preliminary work towards developing strategies for meeting the Defence Force housing need.

(b) The Government acknowledges the difficulties placed on many Service personnel and their families through the requirement to change location frequently. These difficulties were highlighted by Ms Sue Hamilton when she submitted her report to the Minister.

While recognizing that there are numerous reasons why Defence Force personnel are required to change location, such as, to gain and maintain operational skills appropriate to a fighting force, the Government wishes to ensure that all opportunities to provide maximum family stability have been identified.

Accordingly, the Government is to support the recommendation made by Ms Hamilton that a senior person be appointed to undertake a thorough examination of posting policies within the Services to identify as many cases as possible where geographic stability over at least three years can be achieved in peacetime. The person conducting the review will also be asked to recommend ways in which current posting systems could be redesigned to be more responsive to family requirements such as crucial stages in children's education. Announcement of the appointment of the Senior person can be expected shortly.

(c) Under the auspices of this Government, the Defence Force has become significantly more attuned to providing equal employment opportunities for women within the force. In this way, it has gained a better appreciation of the growing diversity in the roles women are playing in the Australian way of life. Consequently, its attitude to spouses has been changing, and it will be considering those recommendations made by Ms Hamilton with regard to assisting spouses, who want to join the paid workforce, by:
(1) providing some full and part-time employment for spouses within its own organisation as family liaison officers, spouses employment officers and education liaison officers;

(2) providing at a central co-ordinating unit nationwide monitoring of the employment needs of, and development of co-ordinated strategies for improving the employment opportunities for, service spouses;
(3) providing within each local area, spouse employment officers who will implement the policies decided and be in frequent contact with spouses; and
(4) providing both nationally and locally, information on the kinds of educational activities that spouses may wish to pursue.
The Services will also consider:
(1) adopting a policy that recognises the special child care needs of Service personnel and their families, and
(2) setting up a National Consultative Group of Service Spouses to act as a source of advice on the implementation of the Hamilton Report recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1986, (Hansard, page 765) Senator Puplick asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Trade the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade aware that an export market development grant of some $25,000 was credited last year to a rat-bag organisation known as the Creation Science Foundation Ltd? Has this so-called foundation, which is tax exempt as a religious organisation, written off $92,000 because of the failure of the company's investment agents-an amount equal to 60 per cent of the total donations which it received? Is the Minister concerned that export grants are being used to subsidise religious organisations, and particularly that such a bogus organisation can be a recipient of a large payment of public moneys, which is then wasted? Will he also draw to the attention of the Treasurer for review the tax exempt status of this body?
The Minister for Trade has provided the following responses to the honourable senator's question:

The Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) scheme is designed to encourage Australian exporters to seek out and develop overseas markets for goods, specified services, industrial property rights and know-how which are substantially of Australian origin. It provides financial incentives in the form of taxable cash grants based on eligible expenditure incurred on overseas activities where the promotion of export sales is the objective.

The scheme is embodied in legislation-the Export Market Development Grants Act and the Australian Trade Commission Act. The EMDG Act sets down the criteria to be used to determine the eligibility of firms or organisations for assistance under the scheme and the calculation of actual grant entitlements. The scheme is, by design, a general access one, and firms or organisations which satisfy the requirements of the legislation are entitled to grants. With the exception of majority-owned South African companies, no individual organisation or the goods they promote overseas have been excluded from the EMDG scheme on the basis of moral grounds. Of course this is not to say that the Government necessarily endorses the views of any or all claimants under the scheme.

The Creation Science organisations were paid EMD grants on the basis that they had incurred eligible expenditure on the overseas promotion of Australian made goods and satisfied the requirements of the EMDG legislation. I should add that the secrecy provisions of the legislation (Section 94 of the Australian Trade Commission Act) preclude the Australian Trade Commission from the publication or divulgence of information concerning the affairs of individual claimants.
